Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY COUNCIL BILL 1986

Mr President, this is an historic occasion. The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the introduction of a democratic, responsible form of government for the Australian Capital Territory. The population has been without an effective and representative form of government for over seventy years. It stands as the last remaining significant community in the Western World having no form of local or state administration answerable to the people.
The ACT was conceived amidst the squabbling between Sydney and Melbourne at the Constitutional Conventions staged in the 1880s and 1890s.

A reading of debates of the time the ACT was excised from New South Wales and the historic records, show Canberra was not readily accepted, and probably still hasn't been accepted, as Australia's national capital.

To indicate the depth of feeling, I refer Honourable Senators to the following excerpts from the Melbourne `Argus' newspaper in 1910-``Canberra is in a dip subject to intense heat, having a soil too poor for herbage and with no adequate source of water supply . . . The facts suggest that Yass-Canberra is very near to being `no man's land' and no sane people would expend treasure and labour in trying to make a modern city in such surroundings''.

Canberra is now regarded as one of the best planned cities in the world that all Australians can be proud of. It has a thriving economy and a growing population of over 250,000 people. After the Seat of Government Acceptance Act was passed in 1909 the then residents were struck off the electorate rolls for both state and federal voting. It has only been in the last twenty years that the people of Canberra were given the right to elect a member with full voting rights in the Federal Parliament. Canberra has always had a battle to gain democratic rights-the opposition reached a peak in 1974 when certain State governments and conservative parties opposed the ACT having the right to elect senators. The Bill was taken to a double dissolution, a joint sitting of both Houses and the High Court.

``Taxation without representation'' is a long-heard and valid catchcry. The people of Canberra have a right and indeed a responsibility, to elect representatives to oversee the spending of the revenue raised in the ACT.
The Federal Parliament cannot reasonably provide a forum for decisions which affect the residents of the Territory.
Canberra has had a fully elected House of Assembly since 1974, but that Assembly has only advisory powers. It lacks legislative, executive and financial control and accountability.

Despite the efforts of the Assembly members-and I note that some former members are now sitting in this Parliament, like my fellow Senator, Susan Ryan-the Assembly cannot fully represent the ACT community.
This Bill will ensure the Australian Capital Territory is properly represented.

In 1982 the Labor Party made an electoral commitment to bring self-government to the Australian Capital Territory. The Government is now introducing a form of government which allows Canberra's citizens to manage their local affairs while the Commonwealth retains management of the national interests. It is a commitment to an appropriate sharing of functions and responsibilities.

The Council will have a wide range of municipal and territorial functions and powers, including welfare, housing, tourism, the environment, water, gas and electricity, public safety, transport and taxation.

The Government has taken significant steps to prepare for self-government. We have initiated an integrated budget process to set priorities and allocate resources. We have asked the Commonwealth Grants Commission to conduct an inquiry into the financing of Government services in the Australian Capital Territory for 1985-86. The Council can decide to instigate regular reviews.

Instead of the past situation of an administration divided among a number of Commonwealth Departments, there will now be a single, effective administration, in the Council, delivering a wide range of municipal and territorial services. In addition, most remaining Commonwealth functions of a local nature in the national capital have been consolidated in the one port- folio. This will provide for economy in administration and for efficient co-ordination with the Council's activities.

The Council will consist of thirteen members, twelve part-time and a full-time Chairperson elected at the first meeting. The Government will review the part-time status of members at the time it considers the transfer of additional responsibilities to the Council.
Members will be elected for a four-year fixed term from single-member electorates by optional preference voting.
Now Honourable Senators will be aware that this appears to be the main cause of concern voiced against this Bill.
The criticism is misguided and underestimates the intelligence of the Australian Capital Territory community.
Surely Honourable Senators can recall Members from both sides of the other Chamber being voted out by the electorate of the Australian Capital Territory.
Single-member electorates will ensure that the duly elected council members perform and if they do not they will not be re-elected.

The system the Government is proposing is the most democratic system for the Australian Capital Territory. It is consistent with the position taken by the Government and the Joint Select Committee on the type of electoral system most suited to elections to the House of Representatives. It accords with the practice in all mainland State lower houses or single chambers. It allows the electorate to select its representatives in the most direct way, avoiding the complications and uncertainties of other systems. It provides for stable government, yet allows change in voting patterns to be directly reflected in the Council's composition. It provides for small electorates where members' performance can be subject to close local scrutiny.
The Bill also provides for public funding for political parties for the first election. The Council will decide its own policy on public funding for subsequent elections.

There are also provisions in the Bill dealing with the holding of early elections in extraordinary circumstances. There is provision for an early election in the event of a deadlock being unresolved within thrity days. There is also provision for the Governor-General to dismiss the Council. This is a power to be used only in an extreme situation, for example if the Council was unable to govern.

The system of government has been designed for the particular requirements of the Australian Capital Territory and therefore has no direct parallel elsewhere in Australia. It protects both local interests and the national interests in the Federal capital.

As well as legislative and executive authority for a range of prescribed matters, the council will exercise executive powers under various Commonwealth laws and through agency and other arrangements made with the Commonwealth.
In all the years of debate about self-government in the Australian Capital Territory, the greatest myths have revolved around the question of finances.
Canberrans believed they would pay more while the States believed they were paying for the facilities in the Australian Capital Territory.
The studies leading up to the Government's decision have, I hope, exploded most of those myths.
The financial aspects of self-government will be satisfactory for both the residents of the Australian Capital Territory and the Commonwealth Government and thus the taxpayer.

Commonwealth funding will be guaranteed for the first two years to maintain per capita real standards at the time of transfer, provided the Australian Capital Territory maintains its per capita real revenue effort at the time of transfer. For the following three years funding levels will be agreed with the Australian Capital Territory Council to smooth the transition to financial arrangements consistent with Commonwealth, State and Local Government financial arrangements and principles of fiscal equalisation. The Commonwealth-Australian Capital Territory financial arrangements will also recognise the unique circumstances prevailing in the Australian Capital Territory.
The Australian Capital Territory Council will have the right to apply to the Commonwealth Grants Commission for periodic reviews of its financial arrangements with the Commonwealth.
These arrangements will ensure that in financial matters the Australian Capital Territory will be treated as fairly and equitably as the rest of Australia.
Most State-type taxes and charges are already levied in the Australian Capital Territory. Revenue-raising powers of this kind will be passed to the new Council.

The opportunity is being taken by the Government to rationalise Australian Capital Territory public finance. The co-ordination and integration of the processes of budgeting of territorial expenditure and receipts which we began last year will continue and be further refined.

The Parliament, the Council and the Australian Capital Territory community will, as a result, then have information available to assess the efficiency and effectiveness of government in the Australian Capital Territory.

While there will be initial costs to be met by the Commonwealth for the establishment and election of the Council, as well as short-term increases in recurrent costs until administrative and staffing arrangements are integrated, these will be kept to a minimum.

The Government has taken the opportunity of rationalising planning, development, lease administration and land management. The changed arrangements provide that the Commonwealth and the Council work in partnership.

Planning and development will be undertaken by the National Capital Development Commission which will be restructured consistent with this Bill. Parliamentary oversight of the planning of Canberra will remain. However the newly constituted Commission will be the servant of both the Commonwealth and the Council. The Commission will be required to reach agreement with the Council before proceeding with planning and development proposals.
The Bill provides that the Council will not be able to pass laws with respect to the planning of land use or for the development of land, except as may be prescribed by Commonwealth regulation.

For efficiency and effectiveness the government has decided to integrate lease administration with planning. This will be accompanied by changes to planning controls. Land use classifications will be broadened, lease conditions will be standardised and in only a limited number of cases will special lease conditions be applied.

Land development and lease marketing will be undertaken by the Commission on a commercial basis-subject to Commonwealth policy directives. Land will be provided to the commission as equity capital at valuation with development funds being provided from borrowings and sales revenue. These changes will remove this activity from budget cycles, making it more responsive to demand and ending the swings in supply of land to which Canberra has been subject. The question of recognition of the Council's lack of access to, or control over, land revenues will be taken up in the negotiation of the financial agreement with the Council.
Details of the Government's approach are contained in the paper entitled ``Planning, Development, Lease Marketing and Lease Management''.

The Bill now before the Senate to amend the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957 was drafted before the form of self-government for the ACT was decided. The Government will withdraw that Bill.

A new Bill to amend the National Capital Development Commission Act 1957, will be brought before the Parliament shortly. It will make changes to the corporate structure of the National Capital Development Commission and to its powers and functions, consistent with the changes I have outlined.

Management of all land, with the exception of lease administration, will be undertaken by the Council. The Commonwealth has defined nationally significant areas in which it will set the standards and bear the associated costs. In addition, the Commonwealth, for national capital purposes, may desire a higher quality of land management in other designated areas and in such cases will negotiate with the Council on standards and financial responsibilities.
I now address individual Parts of the Bill.

Part I provides for the usual preliminary matters of commencement and interpretation. Senators should note that the Jervis Bay Territory is a separate Commonwealth Territory and is not affected by the Bill.
Part II establishes the Council and covers the range of procedural matters necessary for the conduct of the Council's business and proceedings.

Part III deals with the election of the Council and redistribution processes. These are consistent with the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918. The Council will not have legislative power to change the electoral system.

Part IV covers the Council's legislative heads of power and specific Commonwealth laws to be transferred to the Council which are listed in Schedules 1 and 2. The Attorney-General shall decide whether the Council has power to make a proposed law. This will be a technical legal decision. The Attorney will not be second-guessing the Council's decisions as a government.
Senators should note the Council will not be able to establish its own courts but, with the approval of the Commonwealth Attorney-General, can vest jurisdiction in existing courts.

Part V will permit the Council to implement its own administration, management and staffing. The Council may establish standing and ad hoc committees to conduct its business. The Council will appoint its most senior executives and provision is made for their remuneration and allowances to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. The Head of Administration will be responsible to the Chairperson for the business of the Council and the general conduct of the Council's administration.

The Council will be able to make laws determining the conditions of employment of its employees or those of its authorities. The establishment of separate staffing legislation for the Council will be a very significant task requiring extensive consultation with the Commonwealth and staff organisations. The Commonwealth expects to reach agreement with the Council before it enacts that legislation. To this end, the Bill provides for consultation on staffing, terms and conditions of employment, and industrial questions relating to employees, to take place between the Commonwealth and the Council.

In the longer-term these consultative arrangements will also ensure that the Council will have regard to the effect of its decisions on the Commonwealth's interests as an employer operating side by side with the Council in the ACT. The Government is concerned to ensure that national wages and industrial relations policies, and its commitment to the Accord, are kept clearly in consideration through this consultative mechanism.

The Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act will continue to apply in the ACT. Accordingly, the Council will not have legislative power in industrial relations matters except in relation to its own staff and as may be prescribed. In view of the Council's responsibilities, however, it will be necessary to develop arrangements to ensure that its views on ACT industrial relations issues are taken into account. The Government will be giving further consideration to the appropriate arrangements.

Financial and Audit provisions are covered in Part VI. The Council will operate its own treasury and accounting system. All Council borrowings will be subject to the Commonwealth's approval. Borrowings may be guaranteed by the Commonwealth and any financial guarantees given by the Council will require Commonwealth approval.

The Council can make its own Audit Law. The Commonwealth would expect this law to be consistent with the high standards of accountability required of the public sector. The Commonwealth Auditor-General shall be the Auditor-General of the ACT Council.

The Commonwealth will be able to protect its unique national interests through a variety of mechanisms. If the Attorney-General certifies that in his opinion the Council does not have the power to make a proposed law it will not come into operation. Commonwealth law is, of course, supreme in those cases where there is an inconsistency between Council and Commonwealth law.

The Governor-General will have power to disallow any Council law or by-law within six months after the law is made. Council law will not bind the Crown unless the Commonwealth so provides by regulation.

These protections are essential in the national capital. It is the Government's intention, however, that any potential conflicts between the Council and the Commonwealth be resolved as far as it is possible by consultation rather than by legal process.

Part VII attends to miscellaneous provisions and constitutional guarantees. The ACT will be brought into line with the States and the Northern Territory by applying the provisions of Section 92 of the Constitution, guaranteeing free trade. This will not bind the Commonwealth.

Transitional provisions and consequential amendments contained in the Australian Capital Territory Council (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1986 will ensure a smooth transfer of powers and functions to the incoming Council. Until the Council enacts its own staff legislation the Bill provides for staff involved in functions transferred to the Council's administration to be employed under existing Commonwealth legislation and existing awards. The staff therefore retain the normal Public Service conditions of service during this period, including the right to seek promotion or transfer to other Australian Public Service departments and authorities.
The Government proposes that the Consequential Provisions Bill and the ACT Council Bill be considered in cognate debate.

The Commonwealth will negotiate with the Council on arrangements for transfer of functions; application of administrative law; the financial agreement including budgetary arrangments for the remainder of 1986/87; formal consultative procedures; and establishment action. The Commonwealth will also discuss with the States the status of the Council in Commonwealth/State forums and agreements.

Following enactment of this Bill the Australian Electoral Commission will initiate the established process of electoral distribution, including public participation, to permit the first Council election to be held in September of this year.

It is most important that we adhere to this timetable to give the Council time to complete negotiations with the Commonwealth, take up administrative responsibility, and formulate and introduce its budget for 1987/88.
It will be clear to Honourable Senators that this legislation is both comprehensive and well-conceived. It provides for a most democratic, practical and economic form of government for the ACT.
It provides an electoral system the same as that available at the Commonwealth and State level.
It provides the incoming Council with a wide range of powers and functions.
It safeguards the Commonwealth's interest in the National Capital.
It provides for an efficient and effective administration.
It puts the ACT on a proper financial basis.
It protects the interests of those staff who are to be transferred.

In short, the residents of the Australian Capital Territory will now be properly and effectively represented in the management of their affairs. The Commonwealth and the Council will work in partnership in the administration and management of the ACT. This is indeed a milestone in public administration in this country. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY COUNCIL (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1986

This Bill provides essential transitional and consequential amendments relating to the establishment of the Australian Capital Territory Council. The provisions of this Bill are largely of a technical nature and are designed to ensure a smooth transition of responsibilities to the incoming Council.
Part I deals with commencement and interpretation.

Part II deals with transitional matters. It provides for the Minister to convene the Council's first meeting; the Council's law making power during the period between the first election and the formal transfer of functions to the Council; the Council's interim staffing arrangements under the ACT Council Bill and the Public Service Act 1922; the status of the nominee of the House of Assembly on the ACT Electricity Authority following the abolition of that Assembly; the transfer of contracts from the Commonwealth to the Council, the Commonwealth indemnification of the Council; exemption from stamp duty of land transferred from the Commonwealth to the Council; and application of the Commonwealth Audit Act 1901.

The Commonwealth Audit Act, with appropriate modifications and adaptions, will apply to the Council until its own audit law comes into effect, consistent with the high standards of accountability required of the public sector.
Part III effects consequential amendments to the various Commonwealth Acts specified in the Schedule. The amendments principally relate to references to the ACT House of Assembly.

The Bill provides for the Council's administration to be part of the Australian Public Service until the Council passes its own staffing legislation. Staff will therefore retain their existing rights and entitlements during this interim period. It provides for consultation with the Commonwealth before the Council enacts its own staffing legislation. The Commonwealth expects to reach agreement with the Council before it enacts its own staffing legislation, and appropriate provisions on this matter are included in the ACT Council Bill. Unions and staff associations will also be consulted.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a message from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, Mr Conquest, a member of the House of Representatives, has been appointed a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the place of Mr Sharp, discharged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulation 5 of the Student Assistance Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1985 No. 354 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

Regulation 5 of Statutory Rules 1985 No. 354 amends regulation 34 of the Student Assistance Regulations. The amendments alter the progress rules for tertiary education assistance scheme recipients and make a number of consequential amendments, among them paragraph (r) on page 7, which substitutes a new sub-regulation (12) which is substantially the same as existing sub-regulation (12). The effect of this sub-regulation is to limit another sub-regulation, that is sub-regulation (5), which provides that a student's unsatisfactory progress will not result in the loss of TEAS if the unsatisfactory progress was due to illness or other circumstances beyond the student's control. Sub-regulation (12) provides:

The reference in sub-regulation (5) to the failure of an applicant to complete successfully any work of a course due to the illness of the applicant, or to other circumstances beyond the control of the applicant-
and this important part-
does not include a reference to an illness diagnosed, or other circumstances applicable, when the applicant commenced to undertake the work of the year in which that failure occured.

According to the Department the regulation was introduced to prevent students with permanent disabilities from avoiding the TEAS progress rules. Frankly, I think that this is a classic piece of bureaucratic paranoia invoking images of hundreds of disabled people milking the Education Department by enrolling year after year in courses which they are incapable of passing. The Australian Democrats will move for the disallowance of sub-regulation 12 and our position is very clear. First, failure due to circumstances beyond the student's control should not result in the loss of TEAS. Students suffering from some known disability with a physical manifestation, for example, chronic asthma-and I wish to look at that particular disease in some detail in a moment-or other types of disabilities, such as breakdown in a family or death of a close relative or a child, should be encouraged to undertake tertiary studies where there is a reasonable possibility that despite the disability the student can successfully complete the year's study.

I wish to refer to the report of recommendations by the working group of the Committee for Student Services, which is a Melbourne University study, and in particular at page 10. We find that reported there are the results of various other studies that have been undertaken on the types of disabilities that affect progress in studies. It is very interesting to note that the major item in the Finlay study of 1976 in the United Kingdom was diseases of the respiratory system. The Melbourne study, which was undertaken in 1978, also showed that respiratory diseases represented 15 per cent of disabilities, the top `disability' after contraception-in other words, pregnancy. Again in Monash University respiratory disease was second with 19 per cent. These interesting similarities were pointed out in that report. It is also interesting to note that respiratory illness is either the most or the second most frequent reason for consulting in all the data collections.

In Australia the most common disease suffered by people is respiratory disease. Currently in this country 23 per cent of all children suffer from asthma or a similar disorder with chronic respiratory problems. One would conclude from that data that we are facing a situation in which at least a quarter of our tertiary students, in the normal course of events, will suffer from some type of respiratory disease. This is a classic situation. It is a pre-existing condition and, in many circumstances, the occurrence of an attack is unable to be predicted. Such an attack could occur during a vacation period in which case there would be no problem. However, it could occur at a very crucial time in studies and the pattern of control of such respiratory diseases is quite typically that most of the sufferers do not suffer a severe attack throughout a year. However, many do and although the control systems that are available are extraordinary and have developed considerably over the past 10 years, nevertheless attacks can reoccur for a whole variety of reasons. I have selected asthma because it is of that nature and it is the most widespread disorder suffered by Australians and certainly by university students. Therefore we believe, as I have already said, that failure which is beyond the student's control should not result in the loss of TEAS and students suffering from this particular disability should be able to continue their studies.

Thirdly, if students subsequently fail due to the disability, they should not lose TEAS. We believe that in those circumstances the removal of TEAS benefits would amount to a punishment for a disability. Fourthly, we believe that the repeal of sub-regulation (12) would not, as the Department contends, result in `students with permanent disability avoiding the TEAS progress rules'. Each tertiary student has to abide by progress rules within the tertiary institution. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has taught in such an institution, as Senator Peter Baume and I have, and we know that students are subject to quite rigorous rules within the institutional framework in terms of their progress.

There are elaborate mechanisms to deal with students who have failed and who wish to appeal against that failure. Every faculty in every university has an appeal mechanism for students who are excluded because of unsatisfactory progress. Any student who fails recurrently would obviously be suspended according to the normal rules of tertiary institutions as they currently operate in Australia. It seems to me that it is far better to allow those institutional rules to operate in a one-to-one situation where there is a personal context and the people making those decisions can have input from the people engaged in providing lectures and tutorials and providing counselling to students with regard to the progress of their work. It seems to me extraordinary that we should wish to impose on that educative process a bureaucratic decision which will be made in vacuo without the benefit of that intimate knowledge and understanding of the student's educational progress.

The recently introduced provisions were most welcome and the Government now confirms them by allowing students with permanent severe physical disabilities to enrol on a part time basis to receive TEAS. That is an extraordinarily useful advance which this Government has made as a result of the report delivered to it from a professor in my old department, which had been the subject, prior to the Government's announcement, of a notice of motion on my part.

I believe that that Government advance does not ameliorate the effect of sub-regulation (12). It makes no provision for a disability which is not physical, nor for a physical disability of fluctuating severity. Nor does the appeal to the Students Assistance Review Tribunal limit the ambit of sub-regulation (12). In 21 of the 31 cases which have gone before the Tribunal, where the Tribunal found that failure was due to a pre-existing diagnosed illness, the entitlement to TEAS was removed. I emphasise the point that in 21 of the 31 cases to which I have referred, TEAS was removed. Appealing to the Review Tribunal is absolutely useless for those people because in every case where there has been a pre-existing condition the people have lost TEAS and were punished for that disability.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some successful appeals.
—There have been none. In a minute provided by the Department, five examples are given of successful appeals.
—That is what I am saying.

—The minute provided shows that the successful appeals suggest that the Tribunal had the power to modify the effects of sub-regulation (12). I go back to my remarks when I said that they did not limit the ambit of sub-regulation (12). We are talking about sub-regulation (12) in a new context. The appeals did not modify the effect of that sub-regulation. The third example refers to a student with a hearing disability whose appeal was upheld on the basis that that disability could not have been anticipated.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no reference in sub-regulation (12) as to whether the effects of the disability could have been anticipated. Sub-regulation (12) is direct in its wording. According to the Department the Tribunal was incorrect in allowing the appeal, and the Department would be entitled to ask the AAT to reverse the decision. That is the Department's position in regard to that matter, although it does not even come into play with regard to sub-regulation (12). This suggests that sub-regulation (12) is so strict and unreasonable in its terms that the Student Assistance Review Tribunal is forced at times to reach decisions which clearly repudiate sub-regulation (12).

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Department has not gone to the AAT.

—No, it has not, but it said that it would be entitled to do so. That gives us an indication of the thinking of the Department. I have informed the office of the Minister for Education and the office of the shadow Minister that the Australian Democrats would support leave being given to the Government to immediately reintroduce a new regulation, identical to regulation 5 in all aspects, except for the inclusion of sub-regulation (12). We would expect that the Minister, if this regulation is disallowed, would take that option.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there is a further opening to the Government-to bring in a new sub-regulation (12) which would avoid the types of problems that I have suggested. I will rehearse what we believe that type of regulation could look like. We believe that if a student is in receipt of TEAS and fails due to illness, the student will retain his entitlement to TEAS for the following year, but will first be required to undergo an examination by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service, which presently does the assessments for the enrolment of TEAS recipients with severe physical disability. If the CRS assesses students as capable of successfully carrying out only 75 per cent or 50 per cent of the course load, students would retain their TEAS entitlements only if they enrolled for the 75 per cent or the 50 per cent, or whatever the CRS recommendation is. In other words, they would be required to carry that out as a pre-condition to receiving TEAS.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is the current situation.

—No, this is in regard to physical disability. I am rehearsing how we could alter the regulations in regard to people who do not fall under that category. If, on the other hand, the CRS assesses that the student is capable of completing a full load and the student subsequently fails that year's work due to a recurrence of the type of physical disabilities that I have been talking about-for example, a severe asthma attack at a crucial time such as leads to failure-because the student has followed the recommendation of the CRS, that would not be grounds for losing TEAS entitlement. In other words, we would be able to have the type of control that the Minister and the Department are obviously seeking with regard to a number of students. We would not be having open slather. We would know specifically the probablilities and the possibilities according to a close diagnosis of that person's medical condition or physical disability, as is already the case, and we would then be able to make an assessment. The assessment done by the CRS, I would suggest, is an assessment based on a reasonable prediction. Surely we can ask no more of the individual student.
—What do you think would be the consequences of this disallowance if it were successful?
—As I have already said, if this is disallowed we would be happy for the Government to bring in the rest, leaving that sub-regulation out. I would then hope that the Government could seek--
—We couldn't do that for six months.

—That could be done-by leave. I have just said `by leave', Minister; if you had not been nattering to the people beside you, you might have heard. I have already informed the Minister's office and Senator Peter Baume's office that we would be quite happy to give leave. I am quite sure that Senator Peter Baume would be happy to give leave to the Minister to reintroduce a regulation identical to regulation 5 in all aspects, except for that particular sub-regulation (12). The Government could then move to bring in a new sub-regulation. I have rehearsed how I believe that sub-regulation could be worded to carry out what seems to be the intention of the Government without, I think, any added burden to those people who suffer from a disability. I think that at the moment we are being incredibly unfair with regard to those people who suffer from, for example, respiratory ailments or other problems. In fact, we are adding increased pressures to them. One is aware that in fact pressures can affect people suffering from such respiratory conditions by, for example, bringing on an attack. Stress is one of the major contributory items, certainly in regard to asthma. I believe that what we need to do is to make sure that we are not putting in place bureaucratic mechanisms which in fact provide further stumbling blocks for such people.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very much aware that the regulation has been in the Student Assistance Regulations in almost identical terms. However, I have moved this disallowance at this time because it gives us the opportunity of raising yet again what I believe is an unfortunate regulation. It is an area in which I think we should err on the side of compassion and support, not on the side of rigidity. I believe this is a very important point. Although we do not actually have any statistics covering university students, the general community statistics show that 23 per cent of people suffer from some type of respiratory problem. They show, indeed, that that seems to be a continuing medical problem in our community which can exhibit itself at any time and which may, in fact, exhibit itself at a time of maximum sensitivity, such as during a student's educational progress.

I hope that the Minister will look favourably on this suggestion. It seems extraordinary that there should be such a defensive operation in regard to what I believe is a matter that we should seek to deal with as compassionately as possible. I finish by commending the Government for the moves it has already made, particularly with regard to allowing the continuation of the tertiary education assistance scheme to those people who suffer from physical disabilities to allow them to have a reduced work load and hence its support for additional educational opportunities for disabled students in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the attempt to disallow regulation 5 of the Student Assistance Regulations as explained by Senator Macklin. Although I recognise that Senator Macklin is making this attempt in good faith he is quite misguided. First of all, he is misguided as to the effects of the present regulation and the opportunities for students who suddenly suffer from a disability to have that recognised. Also he is misguided in his understanding of the legal effect of his disallowance motion should it be successful.
—How?

—I am just about to explain that. In the first place, the successful moving of this disallowance would mean that the old regulation, which is very similar, would be reinstated. However, more seriously, the beneficial effects in this entire regulation would not apply.
—You could do it by leave.

—I do not think that we really need to be instructed about Senate procedures by Senator Macklin. The regulation has introduced beneficial changes to the current academic progress rules and the rules covering course changes. It clarifies the distinction between various levels of courses to reflect existing policy more accurately and it makes drafting changes consequential on substantive changes. Senator Macklin's concern is about sub-regulation (12), which modifies the tertiary education assistance scheme concession for students who incur failures due to illness or other circumstances beyond their control and withdraws the concession if the illness or circumstance was apparent at the beginning of the year in question.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulation is not new but repeats, with some drafting changes, former regulation 34 (12). The disallowance motion would revive that former regulation 34 (12), which in its initial form took effect on 1 January 1979, and would deprive the students of the beneficial changes to the TEAS rules. About 30 students a year would be adversely affected by the regulation and the cost of repealing it would be $90,000 a year annually. We oppose Senator Macklin's attempt because the underlying policy that students with permanent disabilities should not avoid the normal progress rules is sound and has been accepted by successive governments. I point out that for students with severe permanent physical disabilities, modified progress rules were introduced from the beginning of this year. The case of a student who has a permanent disability-

TALK.START.PARA: —Physical.

—Physical disability, yes-has been covered. Senator Macklin spoke at great length about asthma sufferers. If a student can establish that he or she has a permanent condition which is likely to disrupt his studies, that student would benefit from the concession. My colleague Senator Peter Baume would be much more competent to comment on this, but I would think that a severe asthma sufferer would have a history of that and would not have difficulty in establishing his or her entitlement to that concession.

SPEECH.PARA: As for non-physical problems, if a student has some sort of nervous breakdown, of course there is the possibility for an appeal to the Student Assistance Review Tribunal in that circumstance. Indeed, at the beginning of the year it does not seem that the student's progress is going to be affected by a disability, but where those circumstances change during the year, there is the appeals procedure. I simply disagree with Senator Macklin, who says the fact that 10 out of 31 appeals were successful suggests that the Tribunal is not working. I think those figures suggest that it is working. I think a third of appeals being successful is quite a good result. It seems that Senator Macklin thinks that unless every appeal is successful, there is something wrong with the appeals procedure.

I simply repeat that there has been a modification of the progress rules for students with an established disability and that students who find that their disability does affect their studies in a way that they were not able to anticiapte during the year are able to appeal and that the success rate of the appeal procedure is very high. Over all the regulation provides many benefits to students and those benefits add up to a good case for not accepting Senator Macklin's suggestion. I think that the procedures established in this regulation are fair. Certainly student bodies generally throughout Australia are satisified with the Student Assistance Review Tribunal. There is a good rate of success and I am not aware of any discontent amongst student organisations about the way the procedures are operating.

Should Senator Macklin's disallowance motion be successful, it would be quite chaotic because previous regulations would apply and the opportunity to amend those problems would not present itself immediately. I understand that the Liberal Party of Australia is satisfied with the operation of the present regulation, will not be supporting Senator Macklin's disallowance motion and I thank it for its co-operation in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition parties gave very careful consideration to the motion which has been proposed by Senator Macklin. The motion goes to issues of fairness, to issues of a fair go and to issues of equity. We considered that it required the most careful consideration to see the balance that should be struck and the way in which the disallowance should be approached. We are aware, of course, that there is not a single equity issue. There are the issues of equity as they apply to students with disabilities, and they are matters to which Senator Macklin has referred. There are issues of equity as they relate to those students as against other students who may wish to have access to the tertiary education assistance scheme and, of course, there are issues of equity as they relate to the benefits of students as against the interests of the whole body of taxpayers. There are a whole series of issues of equity and Senator Ryan, in responding, has indicated that there are rules which try to make sure than the various issues of equity are approached in a reasonable way. We took very great care about the motion which has been proposed by Senator Macklin because if there are students with particular disabilities who require special attention and special consideration we wanted to make sure that they receive that consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: First, we are aware of the special provisions which already operate to help students with disabilities. I understand that Senator Ryan has referred to the fact that students with certain disabilities can have altered progress requirement; they can take twice as long to complete a course and still be considered to be making satisfactory progress. This suggests that there is some recognition of the special circumstances and the special needs of people with disability. In the procedures and the rules there is this particular provision to allow for some of the needs of these students. Senator Macklin referred to this I thought with generosity. We would all agree that this is one response which will help the class of students about whom we are talking today.

Secondly, I understand that students can, if they need to, as a result of their disability, withdraw from the course up to two-thirds of the way through the year and do so without forfeiting their right to TEAS. This privilege is not available to other students. It is another recognition of the special needs which these students have and of the way in which the regulations have been cast to try to take account of the needs of these students. Thirdly, we are aware that they can appeal to the Student Assistance Review Tribunal. From the example which has been given we are aware that the success rate in some of these appeals is not inconsiderable. I make the point that the initial decision to withdraw TEAS is not taken lightly; it is a decision which is taken only after a lot of departmental consideration. The Tribunal still finds in favour of students on appeal, indicating that the appeal mechanism is not one which can be criticised.

The next point that concerns the Opposition is that the rules presently in place already provide for the procedures to which Senator Macklin is objecting. The effect of disallowing this set of regulations would be to leave the existing regulations in place. They are regulations which do almost the same thing. As Senator Ryan said, all that is being achieved in the regulations which are sought to be disallowed is a redrafting of an existing situation, one that has been policy and which has been in operation since 1979. If in fact it was a change of policy, if in fact the Government was proceeding to change the rules of the game in a significant way, that would be quite different. The Government is not changing the rules, it is changing the drafting within which these rules are presented. The Opposition has taken all those matters into account.

We do not support the disallowance motion, but we do it against the background of a continuing and very deep concern for the difficulties which are faced by students undertaking tertiary education, students who are carrying into that tertiary course disabilities, whether they are chronically ill or disabled, which add to the load which they have to bear. We are aware of their special needs. Everyone who has taken part in this debate has acknowledged their special needs. The fact that we are not supporting this disallowance in no way lessens the concern we have.

The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has a capacity to follow the course which has been proposed by Senator Macklin whether or not this disallowance succeeds. If Senator Macklin wants the rules changed, it can be done whether or not this disallowance succeeds because if the disallowance did succeed, the rules to which he objects would still stand by virtue of their being presented in previous regulations. On behalf of the Opposition I indicate that we do have a willingness to look at any changes to the student assistance regulations which may be presented in the future should firm evidence come to light that students are being disadvantaged, that students with disability are being disadvantaged and that the regulations are not operating to their benefit.

I conclude by observing that while students do not hesitate to make representations to us on many matters, and while we have had many representations on a number of matters before the Senate in the last year, we have not had representations on this matter from students who are adversely affected by the present arrangements. We are grateful to Senator Macklin for bringing this matter forward. As I say, it has caused us to make a very deep examination of this matter and to give careful consideration to it. It is only after that consideration that we have determined not to support the motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am disappointed that in fact my motion will not succeed. It is a pity, and I find it passing strange that many of the reasons-I am sorry, Senator Harradine. I shall be closing the debate. I do not know whether Senator Harradine wishes to contribute.
—I am sorry, senator, but you have started to address the Chair and by so doing you are automatically closing the debate for others.

—I apologise to Senator Harradine. I did not know that he wished to participate in the debate. I think it passing strange that some of the reasons that were given for opposing my motion were reasons that relate to the way in which this chamber operates in regard to regulations. I must say that I found extraordinary the argument that the disallowance of the regulations would in fact mean the reinstatement of others. It was argued that that is one of the reasons why we should not agree to the motion. It seems to me that unless this chamber is able to use its disallowance power, in terms of the fact that it does not agree with the regulations which are now being promulgated, regardless of the subsequent activity that has to go on, the ability of this chamber to do its work in regard to looking at those regulations is severely denigrated. If regulations are dis- allowed, the Government should have to go back, look at them and bring new ones into this chamber-after this chamber has expressed its views. We should not have to express our views on the basis that something then might or might not happen. Surely we should express our views on the basis of the value of the regulation itself.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that I also do not buy the argument that since the student assistance regulations have been in existence since 1979, they should remain. I expressed in my previous comments the view that since a new regulation was to be introduced, it was obviously the time to look at the regulations again. I only wish to express my disappointment that those types of arguments should have been used as reasons why the disallowance should not take place. I also indicated that this chamber has control over whether or not leave is given to deal with a subsequent set of regulations. That matter again seems to have eluded the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) entirely. I still do not believe that the essential item I raised has really been addressed, and I think that the problem will remain. I also find its extraordinary that the Minister and the shadow Minister said that they have not received representations. That might reflect on what the students feel might be the type of response they get if they make representations to the Australian Labor Party or the Liberal Party of Australia.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 April, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, perhaps I may explain that I thought that there was going to be a vote on Senator Macklin's motion. As a result I was not in the chamber when the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Amendment Bill 1986 was called on for debate. I presume that we are dealing with the three veterans' entitlements Bills as a package?
—No.
—The indication is that at this stage we are simply dealing with the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Amendment Bill 1986.
—We will deal with the three at the Committee stage.
—The proposal is that they will be dealt with together in Committee.
—We would be happy to have a cognate debate.
—They ought to be dealt with cognately.
—Is leave granted for a cognate debate on the three Bills at the second reading stage? In fact, two of the Bills have passed the second reading stage.
—Mr Deputy President, the other Bills are at the Committee stage. I am not quite sure how we can have a second reading debate and a Committee stage debate together.

—I was only repeating a request. It seems to me that the only sensible procedure is to go ahead with the second reading debate on this Bill-that is, the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Amendment Bill 1986. The Bills may then be considered cognately at the Committee stage, if the Committee so orders.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I am glad that has been clarified. The situation is that on 29 November the Senate sent back to the House of Representatives the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985 with a number of requests for amendments. On that date, and before dealing with that Bill, the Government adjourned the House of Representatives. Therefore, the Bill has remained on the Notice Paper of the House of Representatives since 29 November 1985. This week, for the first time since that date, the Government has at last brought the Bill into the House of Representatives and dealt with the Senate's request. So the delays that have occurred in dealing with that Bill are entirely the responsibility of the Government. Yet the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has been disinforming people that the Opposition has delayed the Bill. The whole machinery available to the Government has been engaged on a massive disinformation campaign. In fact, the Opposition has been totally responsible in its approach to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill, as it will be in relation to the measure before the Senate now, the 1986 transitional provisions Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the actions that we have taken to date. The Opposition has moved or supported 41 amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. There were other amendments which we considered but which we did not put or, if the Australian Democrats moved them, which we did not support. In some cases we accepted the Government's arguments in relation to amendments. In other cases we acknowledged that there were policy differences between us and the Government. We also acknowledged that the Australian Labor Party was in government and therefore we should not attempt to substitute our policies for those of the Government. I believe that our approach should be recognised as being fair and responsible for an opposition to adopt. I hope that when the Australian Labor Party gets into opposition it adopts a similar approach to our measures. Within the parameters that I have outlined, we moved or supported only those amendments which we believed to be essential. There were 41 of them. That our judgment was right has been proven by the Government's response to those amendments. The Government has accepted 40 of the 41 amendments. During debate on those amendments the Minister for Veterans' Affairs argued bitterly against every amendment and complained about the 41 which were carried. But, as I have said, since then he has been promoting the view that our action in carrying those amendments had delayed passage of the Bill.

Let us look at the facts. The simple truth is that the Government has accepted 40 of the 41 amendments. So our judgment and our bona fides in this matter have been proven, not by rhetoric from us, but by the actions of the Government. The correctness of our judgment as to the essential need for those amendments is now a self-evident truth because the Government has accepted them.

Why are we sticking on that forty-first amendment? Why do we just not accept that we won 40 amendments and we should give in on the last one? The simple reason that we are sticking on the forty-first amendment is that our judgment on it is also correct. Honourable senators will remember that I explained that this was not simply the last of the amendments which we could or might have supported if we wanted to be difficult or behave badly as the Opposition parties. This forty-first amendment is the last of those amendments which, on a careful and proper analysis and within the parameters that I have mentioned, we decided were essential to the Bill. What is this amendment? It proposes to delete-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Lewis, some of the points you are developing now would be more appropriate at a later stage. All we are dealing with at the moment is the Veteran's Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Amendment Bill.

—I recognise that, Mr Deputy President, but the situation is that the Government is in effect rejecting all of the 41 amendments that were carried and it is bringing in its own 40 amendments. That Bill deals with those. Of course--
—It does not deal with any of them.

—No. But the transitional Bill will implement the decisions of the Government with the carriage of the veterans Bills. I shall endeavour, where I can, to limit my speech to the transitional Bill. One has to acknowledge that that is not easy. I merely say that, in due course, I will be moving the amendment which proposes to delete the retrospectivity in clause 119. I shall deal with that amendment in the Committee stage. I must point out that we will be endeavouring to persuade the Senate to stick with the forty-first amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister's disinformation attack which I have been talking about has caused great uncertainty within the veteran community, as it was clearly intended to do, because he threatened to renege on the 40 amendments successfully moved by the Opposition parties and the Australian Democrats, all of which greatly improved the Bill, together with the removal of other anomalies that will be removed by this legislation. In consequence, some organisations have waivered under pressure. In addition, the new legislation is so complex that few ex-service organisations really understood the full ramifications, the exceptions being the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council, representing 16 ex-service organisations, and the Victorian branch of the Returned Services League, both of which vigorously exposed the shortcomings in the legislation.

I must say that the spiteful attacks on the Chairman of the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council, Rear-Admiral Guy Griffiths, and the intemperate language used in correspondence to him has been deplored by ex-service organisations. I suggest that the Minister simply did not like the shortcomings in the legislation being exposed; in other words, he did not like being found out. I said previously, when addressing the Senate on the other veterans Bill, that veterans expected that they would be compensated for the reduced life span that many were likely to suffer as a result of war service. Under the guise of simplifying the legislation they are being exposed to a shabby cost cutting exercise at a time when a growing number of veterans are entering their twilight years.

In Senate Supplementary Estimates committee hearings this continued erosion of benefits was revealed. There was a reduction of between $20m and $24m in the granting of totally and permanently incapacitated pensions and a reduction of $3m in travel allowances. These cuts come on top of the cutbacks introduced with the assets test as it is applied to service pensioners. That burden has fallen very heavily on service pensioners, more so than on general pensioners. It seems to me that significant cost cuts could be achieved by the Department adopting a less adversary role towards its clients.

As I said, the Opposition has been most responsible in pressing amendments. These have been moved after careful consultation with veterans' organisations. Defects remain in this legislation. There is clearly a need, in our view, for a monitoring committee to be established, but I shall talk about that later. I understand that the reason the Government has finally brought this legislation back before the Senate is that there have been some defections in the ranks of the Australian Democrats. I do not know what it is all about, but, no doubt, in due course we shall see what the result will be. The bulk of the blame for this cynical cost-cutting exercise against veterans must rest firmly on the shoulders of this Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Veterans' Entitlements Bill was passed by the House of Representatives on 12 November last year. Then this chamber, in a subsequent debate later that month, made 35 amendments to the Bill and requested the House of Representatives to make another six amendments. The Senate exercised its powers to request the House of Representatives to amend the definition of `allied veteran' in clause 35 (1) of the Bill to recognise eligibility for service pension of service rendered after September 1957. It also decided to make various amendments to clauses 68 and 69 of the Bill so as to continue repatriation cover for new enlistees in the Defence Force after the commencement of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The House of Representatives-where governments are made-rejected those requests, together with the 35 Senate amendments. However, the Government has, properly and adequately, in a spirit of compromise and co-operation, indicated that the requests would be acceptable in a form set out in a message to the Senate, which we will be subsequently discussing in Committee of the Whole. It also proposes other amendments in response to and in place of those moved by the Senate. In all, the Government will be dealing with 39 of the 41 requests and amendments made by the Senate. One other amendment will be resolved by administrative action. In all cases the spirit, if not the form, of the Senate amendments will be preserved.

A great deal has been said by Senator Lewis of the delays with this legislation. The Government, as Senator Lewis conceded, is entitled to present legislation in accordance with its policies and its program, and it has done precisely that. The Opposition is entitled to take a contrary point of view, as indeed are other representatives in the Senate. However, the Government still had to make decisions in respect of its legislative program and its commitment to the various constituents that make up the Australian community, in the belief that the Bill finally presented to the Senate represents a compromise and represents what can be said to be the views of the overwhelming majority of the veteran community.

The Government has treated with respect the concerns of the Senate in the way in which it has debated and dealt with its requests. The service pension eligibility of allied veterans who served after 1 September will be preserved. Repatriation cover for new enlistees in the Defence Force will continue, pending the development of a military compensation scheme. So it is not true to say that the Government has not sought to accommodate the views of the Senate. The Government has met the Senate more than half way in regard to its other amendments. It is not true to say that the legislation has been in a dormant position because of the Government's intransigency. The purpose of the delay in dealing with the legislation has been to consult further with the veteran community. There has been an extensive consultative process during both the pre-parliamentary determination period in 1985 and in the period since the sunset clause was established by decision of the Senate.

It is true that there has been some criticism of the legislation. Of course, there is criticism of most pieces of legislation. However, the Government, in a spirit of conciliation and co-operation, has sought to accommodate the various views that have been expressed by the veteran community. I have had in writing from a great number of the leaders of the veteran community their support for the early passage of the legislation.

Senator Lewis spoke about the complexities of the Bill. Of course, it is a complex piece of legislation. But it has been designed to bring in- to one piece of legislation 65 years of government legislation, most of which has been ad hoc and most of which has related to a particular set of circumstances or conflict in time. The purpose of it, with all its complexities, is never- theless to rationalise and simplify the process for those who operate in the administrative side of the system as well as those who aim to become part of the system as applicants. The areas in which each of those parties will operate will be clearly defined.

There has been, of course, a great deal of misrepresentation and a great deal of concern as a result of misrepresentation. Some veterans groups have clearly misunderstood the Government's intentions. They have clearly not appreciated the many gains that are encompassed in the legislation. Such organisations have said that the veterans are losing benefits. Of course, that is not so. There are many gains in the legislation. Those gains, of course, have persuaded most veterans organisations which have looked at the legislation sincerely and conscientiously, to support its early passage. In the intervening period-that is, during 1986-I have had, as has the shadow Minister for Veterans Affairs, Mr Tim Fischer, numerous conferences with the veterans organisations. There was a summit meeting earlier this year which unanimously agreed to the early passage of the legislation. This was done subsequently by the special national executive meeting of the Returned Services League.

Most correspondence from a variety of organisations, supported the general thrust of the legislation, while recognising that not every aim, objective or agenda item of the veterans community has been encompassed in the legislation. It was never the intention that this piece of legislation would include all the ambit claims of the veterans community over the last 20 or 30 years. In fact, Senator Messner, in establishing the advisory committee, made the very point that it was not to be seen as a net to take into account all of the various claims, justified or unjustified as they may be. It was never the intention of the legislation to accommodate all of those demands. If governments were able on the basis of a healthy economy to accommodate all those demands, one would almost see the end of the veterans organisations. They are in place for the purpose of raising issues from time to time which have some justification and to present those points of view to government.

I conclude by saying that the view has been expressed that there are a number of matters that are still outstanding which are not embraced in this piece of legislation, with all its positive features. They are matters which will be taken up in a Budget context. Of course, that is the way in which the veteran community has operated in its relationship with government ever since the veterans movement was established after World War I. We ask, therefore, that the Senate take a mature position in respect of this legislation and take on board the positive aspects of the legislation, so that we have its early passage and those benefits that are conferred upon many people in the veteran community will be able to be enjoyed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

I draw the attention of my colleagues on the other side to the fact that we are dealing with 60 amendments. I believe this procedure would be the most expeditious way in which to deal with those matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with 60 amendments that have been moved by the Government. As has already been indicated by Senator Lewis, they are substantially the amendments which were considered last time that we debated the Bill before Christmas, some four months ago. They are a significant advance on what was contained in the original Bill. I think it is important that it be noted by the veteran community that the Government has acceded to these requests. They are not just of an inconsequential kind. Many of them go to fundamental points with regard to the legislation. They seek to maintain as far as is possible, given the numbers in this place, the types of benefits which have been provided to veterans over the years. I think it is a pity that there are some in the community who would wish that there be changes to these types of benefits in a way that suggests that we should no longer pick up the community's obligation in this area. Undoubtedly we will face a significant growth in costs in the future. These amendments seek to rectify a number of defects in areas where we believe the allowances should not have been denied. For example, they seek to continue the extension to the allied veterans, and certainly this is the wish of the wider community.

SPEECH.PARA: The acceptance of these amendments will present a Bill which obviously has the support of the majority of people within the veterans community. The Returned Services League, the War Widows Guild, Legacy and the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association have all indicated their support for the Bill's passage once these amendments have been accepted. The Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council has disagreed with that view. I must say that I wish to associate myself with some of the remarks made by Senator Lewis about the inc- redibly intemperate way in which much of this debate has gone on and the vilification of individuals who in fact operate solely for the benefit of other people-to support their previous comrades in arms and to try to ensure that they now receive the support that is their due from the community. Senator Lewis referred in particular to Rear Admiral Guy Griffiths. Certainly, in his dealings with the Australian Democrats Admiral Griffiths has always behaved in the most honourable and forceful manner in pursuing the aims of the organisation of which he is the President.

I believe that many of the stumbling blocks to the progress of this legislation were the very odd letters and even odder Press releases that went out in a flurry from the Minister's office on various occasions and which, in many ways, sought to pit one section of the veterans community against another with a view to the early passage of the Bill. In fact all that those letters and Press releases have managed to achieve is the four-month delay which has occurred in the passage of this legislation because the tone of them and the way in which they were put together lent no honour or dignity to the way in which the Minister was conducting this campaign to get his legislation through. The suggestion that all may be fair in politics is bad. Some things are obviously unfair and unjust, particularly when they apply to individuals who are merely going about the support of their comrades and are trying to get for them the benefits to which they believe they are entitled.

I hope that in future, when obviously we will be addressing this issue again-if not by way of amendments, then at least when the various items in this regard are raised-subsequent debates will be carried on with the acknowledgment that the people who operate in this area all do so with good will. While we may not and cannot agree with everybody-this is fairly obvious as groups within the veterans community take opposing views-we do not have to disparage one group in order to support the other. We can acknowledge that they all put forward their views with sincerity and, if we agree to disagree with them, we should disagree on the basis of argument.

I would also like to raise the fact that since this Bill will pass through the House today or tomorrow, depending on how we get through the amendments, it will in fact clear the way for the Government to make announcements about the various programs that it has claimed it has had to put off making decisions about until it saw what happened to this Bill. Of particular concern to me is the situation we obviously face on repatriation hospitals. The greying of the World War II veterans, who form the vast bulk of the veteran community, presents us with a significant problem in the next 20 or 30 years. Obviously those problems will grow apace. By and large, those veterans are now in their sixties and in the normal course of events aging will exacerbate any problems that they are suffering. I am sure that we will find increasing demands made on our repatriation hospitals.

The Government has announced upgrading and refurbishment of the various repatriation hospitals around Australia and we certainly expect that this will continue apace. I refer here to the warning of the Brand Committee of Review of the Repatriation Hospital System which recommended 6 per cent across the board staff increases. I believe that that recommendation must be met, and met urgently. The suggested cost of that is about $10m in 1986-87. Considering that we have recently had evidence in the Estimates committees about one area-I sought to move an amendment but was unsuccessful-in which it seemed that the Government would recoup about $75m from the totally and permanently incapacitated area and the disability award area, I see absolutely no reason within Government economic statements why that full 6 per cent should not be given, and given immediately. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made a very strong statement that there will be no cutbacks in 1986-87 and I am sure that the Minister is as thankful as I am that the Prime Minister has made a public statement on that matter. I am sure that it strengthens his hand in the Budget negotiations. I would also hope that that might be seen in the light of the types of savings that the passage of this Bill undoubtedly will make and that the redirection of those liberated funds should be towards the veterans community and must fulfil the major recommendations of the Brand Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the remarks of Senator Macklin and refer to and repeat some of the remarks that I made earlier. Again, I wish to point out the responsible attitude being taken by the Opposition parties, including the Australian Democrats. In effect, we are abandoning the wording of the amendments that we carried some four months ago and accepting that the Australian Labor Party is in government and that the Government has picked up the spirit of our amendments and wishes to use its own wording and formulate its own amendments. We will not argue about words; we are prepared to accept the Government's proposals. The result is, of course, that the effect of the amendments that we moved will now become law. I refer particularly to the removal of that discriminatory 40-year rule which, I believe, no decent government applying its mind to the subject would ever have dreamed up. I really cannot understand how the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) could have proposed such a measure. Also I cannot understand how he could have proposed a measure that he has now agreed to remove-the discrimination against allies who fought alongside us during the Vietnam war. There is a host of other minor improvements in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, there remain defects in this Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Amendment Bill 1986 and we are aware of them. In our view there is clearly a need for a monitoring committee to be established. That committee should be independent and have particular reference to the totally and permanently incapacitated changes which are causing very real concern to many veterans organisations. That committee should also ensure that the legislation is not having effects that were not intended. If clause 119 is passed without our amendment, that committee should closely scrutinise the effects of it. Indeed, the Opposition calls on the Government to establish such an independent committee as soon as this legislation is in place. We can assure the TPI community that we shall direct our attention to the consequences of this legislation on its members during the course of the next election campaign. However, as I have said previously, the Opposition parties are adopting a responsible approach to this legislation. We will not be supporting the amendments of the Australian Democrats to that part of the legislation which the TPI community would wish us to change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that the Veterans' Entitlements Bill was dealt with by the House of Representatives last year. A number of amendments were made by the Senate and it requested the House to make other amendments. The House of Representatives has rejected those requests for amendments, but in a spirit of co-operation and comprise it has indicated that in dealing with these matters the requests would be acceptable in the form set out in its message. The Government also proposes to move amendments to the VEB in response to and in place of those moved by the Senate. I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for the spirit in which they have referred to some of those amendments in globo.

SPEECH.PARA: In all, the Government proposes to deal with 39 of the 41 amendments or requests made by the Senate. Because of drafting and practical difficulties, not all of the Government's amendments are in the exact form proposed by the Senate. I appreciate what Senator Lewis has said; the spirit of the Opposition amendments has been considered in the redrafting of those amendments. The Opposition indicated in the House of Representatives that it accepts the Government's requested amendments. However, as was indicated by Senator Lewis, the Opposition proposes to move amendments to clause 119. That is a pity, because a great deal of discussion took place with the veteran community in respect of that clause.

I would like briefly to outline the requests and amendments that the Government proposes should be made to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. The Government proposes that amendments should be made to clause 35 of the Bill which will remove the limitation on the eligibility for service pensions of allied veterans who served after 1 September 1957. This will mean that allied veterans of the Vietnam conflict will be eligible if they satisfy the eligibility criteria for members of the allied forces. In keeping with the agreement reached with the ex-service community, the Government proposes that requests should be made for the amendment of clauses 68 and 69 of the Bill to continue compensation coverage for those members of the defence forces who enlist after the commencement of the VEB, until such time as a military compensation scheme is in place. The Bill provides for termination of this coverage on a date to be proclaimed. A proclamation will not be made until legislation to establish the military compensation scheme is in place.
