Arising from the Senate amendments related to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, the Government proposes amendments to provide for the Administrative Appeals Tribunal review of decisions relating to allowances and other benefits; limitations on the scale of charges able to be fixed for treatment in repatriation institutions; prescription by regulation of the conditions for payment of travelling expenses under clause 110 and 131; the tabling in Parliament of the vehicle assistance scheme and the veterans' children's education scheme; and the amendment of clause 208 so that an offence occurs only where a person knowingly contravenes the provisions detailed in the clause. Other amendments which the Government proposes should be made to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill in response to the Senate's amendments include the extension of the list of decorations which attract payment of a decoration allowance under clause 102 to include the Cross of Valour and the Star of Courage, tabling of Veterans' Review Board annual reports, and the deletion of clause 206 which provides a statutory defence of civil suit in respect of the contraction of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

I point out to the Committee that the Government has not accepted the Senate's amendments to clause 119 of the Bill, which relates to the standard of proof to be applied to claims for pensions lodged prior to 15 May 1985. I do not think it is unreasonable to require that there be evidence of a reasonable hypothesis of a service relationship in the determination by the Repatriation Commission of such claims. The Returned Services League and other major ex-service organisations referred to by Senator Macklin accept the provision made by clause 42 of the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Amendment Bill for the application of the reasonable hypothesis requirement.

The Returned Services League has asked that I deal in my remarks with one concern it has regarding the interpretation of sub-clause 119 (3) of the VEB. The concern is whether the question of whether there is a reasonable hypothesis should be determined on the civil standard of proof. As was indicated in the opinion I tabled in the Parliament last December, the opinion as to whether a reasonable hypothesis remains or does not remain constitutes satisfaction beyond reasonable doubt.

The Senate also sought a right of review of decisions made by the Repatriation Commission under clause 122, which related to the distribution of unpaid moneys on the death of a pensioner. Because of practical difficulties this amendment has not been accepted. The Commission will institute administrative procedures, however, in order to ensure that equitable distribution will take place. In particular, the Commission will give notice of its intention to disburse unpaid moneys by the placing of notices in newspapers. The Opposition has indicated-I thank it for this-that it accepts the Government's response to this amendment.

Two Government initiatives have been included in the Government's proposed amendments. The first will give a legislative basis for the decision to extend benefits to those servicemen who served in Vietnam in continuous full time service, in any capacity, between 31 July 1962 and 11 January 1973, but who were not allotted for service. Included in this group would be, for example, service personnel who served on the HMAS Sydney. This amendment will provide that a person or unit will be taken to have been allotted for duty in an operational area where the person or unit was allotted for duty in accordance with Defence Force administrative arrangements, or where the person or unit is deemed to have been so allotted by an instrument in writing signed by the Minister for Defence.

The second amendment relates to an increase in the guardian's allowance payable to single service pensioners with children on 1 May 1986. This initiative was announced in the 1985-86 Budget and was included in the Social Security and Repatriation (Budget Measures) Amendment Bill 1985. The provision was not included in the Veterans' Entitlement Bill when it was introduced last year, but it was intended to introduce an amendment Bill in these sittings to allow the increase to apply from 1 May 1986. As the VEB did not become law last year, the amendment is being proposed at this time. The Government has proposed also that a formal amendment be made to the Veterans' Entitlement Bill to provide for a commencement date to be fixed by proclamation.

In conclusion, for the information of the Committee I mention that the Repatriation Commission has advised that arrangements were put in place to implement two understandings reached with the Opposition and the Australian Democrats last year. The first of these was not to make adverse determinations on the basis of the 40-year rule embodied in the standard of proof provision applying under the present legislation. In response to the second understanding, the Commission has also identified cases where the application of the new standard of proof provision made by clause 119 of the VEB could lead to a favourable decision for review after the VEB comes into operation. I urge the Committee to support the Government's amendments. They are offered, as I said in my second reading speech, in a spirit of compromise to enable this important piece of legislation to come into effect as soon as possible.

I would like to make some brief reference to the remarks made by Senator Lewis and particularly the remarks of Senator Macklin in respect of Rear Admiral Griffiths. I was present at the summit meeting of veterans organisations convened by the Returned Services League, at which representatives of all the major service bodies were present, including Rear Admiral Griffiths. A unanimous decision was taken at that meeting that the Bill should be supported and that outstanding matters would be subject to further negotiation in the Budget context. At that meeting Admiral Griffiths assented to that agreement. Subsequently, however, he made public statements, which were circularised to all members of parliament, repudiating that agreement and setting out opposition to the proposed legislation. I ask honourable senators who have raised this matter what they would do in those circumstances. Members from all political parties, including my own, wrote to me seeking information in respect of Admiral Griffiths's comments. I had to point out the misrepresentations that were inherent in those circularised statements. I do not resile from the fact that he is able to criticise the Government, the Minister and the decision made by the veterans' summit meeting, but I am entitled, and in fact I am obligated, to reply to those criticisms. I do not believe that there is any justification for the criticism. If one gets involved in the political processes, one is entitled to the `give' and one is obliged to take what one gets in respect of the public controversy that arises thereupon.

In regard to the question about the totally and permanently incapacitated pension, I point out that that is not a point of contention. In respect of this legislation, I addressed, as did the shadow Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, the Totally and Permanently Incapacitated Congress of the Australian Federation of Exservicemen and Women earlier this year. They have unanimously pressed for the passage of the legislation and did not raise the questions that have been raised by some persons in respect to this debate. I offer that not in the spirit of seeking to widen the controversy, but to explain the Government's position, the Minister's position, and the reasons why, in the political process, one has to set out, to the best of one's ability, the facts as one sees them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to speak further on these amendments, but I have been drawn into responding to the defence of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) of himself in regard to what I can only describe as his spiteful attacks on the Chairman of the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, Rear Admiral Guy Griffiths. The Minister's intemperate language used in correspondence to him is deplored by the Opposition parties. I do not want to speak for Senator Macklin, but it is obvious from his previous remarks that he deplored the language. It is deplored by ex-service organisations and people throughout the ex-service community. It is grossly unfair to Admiral Griffiths that not only has the Minister attacked him in correspondence, but also he has now made that attack worse by expressing similar views in the Committee in this debate. I regret very much that he has done so.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the matter of the totally and permanently incapacitated pension is concerned, I simply say to the ex-service communities which are concerned about that pension that this is a decision of the Government. It is prepared to carry the can, and we are not prepared to support the Australian Democrats' amendment-which I gather they will move in relation to that matter-for the very reason that we recognise that the Australian Labor Party is in Government and needs to raise revenue and to spend the money in the way that it determines-it has to carry the can for its decisions. That is different altogether from the matter of retrospectivity, which is not a question of raising the money and spending it in accordance with principles; it is a matter of carrying out a fundamental principle. I will debate that at a later stage.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 147, after sub-clause 119 (7), add the following sub-clauses:

`(8) Notwithstanding any provision of any other Act, where a claim for a pension of a kind referred to in sub-sections (1) and (2) or an application for a review of a decision relating to such claim for a pension was made before 15 May 1985 and not determined before the commencement of this Act, this Act shall have effect in respect of that claim or that application as if this section required the Commission to grant a claim for a pension unless the Commission is satisfied, beyond reasonable doubt, that there is no sufficient ground for granting the claim.

`(9) Where a claim for a pension of a kind referred to in sub-sections (1) and (2) or an application for a review of a decision relating to such a claim for a pension was made before 15 May 1985 and determined before the commencement of this Act, the person who made the claim or the application may request, in writing in accordance with a form approved by the Commission, the redetermination of that claim or that application.

`(10) Where a request is made under sub-section (9), the claim or the application in respect of which the request is made shall be deemed not to have been determined, and shall be determined in accordance with sub-section (8).

`(11) A claim or an application determined under sub-section (9) shall be deemed to have been so determined on the day on which that claim or application was determined before the commencement of this Act.'.

This amendment adds paragraphs after sub-clause 119 (7). The effect of the amendment is to delete retrospectivity in clause 119. Retrospectivity is not some political philosophy which can be ignored when it is inconvenient, or, as Senator Walsh would have people believe, and in particular as he would have the back bench of the Australian Labor Party believe, ignored when the Government wants to take some money away from some people so that it can use it in some other way which it believes might have a higher priority. That is the approach which Senator Walsh has apparently persuaded members of the Labor Party to adopt in regard to numerous measures. In particular, I refer to taxation measures. Apparently he has been so persuasive in his arguments along these lines that he has persuaded the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, to adopt a similar attitude in regard to retrospectivity so far as it affects the veterans community. However, the Liberal and National parties say that retrospectivity simply cannot be ignored because it is convenient or because the Government wants to spend the money in some other ways. No.

Let me explain the word `retrospectivity'. It has come to be a sort of shorthand way of expressing a simple principle which is, or should be, fundamental to the people living in a democracy. That principle is this: The people-and after all, this is their country, not this Government's or the Treasury's-of this country are entitled to know at any one time what the law is. When they act in accordance with that law, no government has a right at some later stage to alter the law so that it is different at the point in time prior to the date of their actions. It follows that if a law is to be changed, it must be changed for the future; that is prospectively, not retrospectively. That is a simple truth for all governments in a democracy, as opposed to a dictatorship. It should be a simple truth for this Government. If this Government were seriously concerned about the rights of Australians, this principle would be enshrined in its so-called Bill of Rights.

There is one exception to this principle which has come to be accepted. That exception is where a government decides to confer a benefit on a citizen or citizens retrospectively. But it must be acknowledged that even when a benefit is conferred retrospectively, a group of people in Australia suffer as a result of that retrospectivity. They are the taxpayers. The taxpayers at large foot the bill. I understand and accept that exception. However, it is, of course, not relevant here.

What happened in this case was that in May 1985 the Government said, in effect: `Decisions of the High Court in interpreting the Veterans' Entitlements Bill have allowed applicants for pension to succeed when the Government believes they should not succeed. Therefore, we are going to change the law to stop them from succeeding'. We of the Opposition say: `Okay, you are the Government. If that is your decision, so be it. You carry the can. That is your responsibility'. In other words the Government is endeavouring to overcome the decisions of the High Court of Australia in the O'Brien and Law cases. We say that that is fair enough, that the Government is entitled to do that as long as the veterans community understands what it is doing, However, the Government is not satisfied with that approach of the Opposition parties. It now says: `Look, we want to go back and alter the law for all of those people who have applied for pensions and whose cases had not been dealt with as at May 1985 when we told you about this'. We of the Opposition say: `Hang on, you cannot go back beyond May 1985 when you told the people about this decision. That would be changing the law retrospectively'. Some people say `retroactively'. I do not care one way or the other. In other words, the change will be activated right back so that it will not matter when people made their applications for pensions because they will not be dealt with on the basis of the law as it stood at that date when they made their application for a pension; they will be dealt with on the basis of law which the Government announced in May 1985.

We say: `You can only change the law in regard to the future as from May 1985-from the date you announced it'. However, the Government says-we understand this argument; we have heard it before: `We reckon we can save about $40m if we deal with all those applications under the new principle. When we get that $40m we will do all sorts of good things for the veteran community'. However, we say: `You cannot do that in a democracy. It is as simple as that'. This is a democracy. Even this Government acknowledges that it is a democracy. We say that the Government cannot go back in dealing with those applications. We understand that there is at least one application which is 20 years old. We say: `You cannot go back and just alter the law and say that those applications will be dealt with under the new law because it will give you an extra $40m to spend on all sorts of goodies for the veteran community if it lets you have that $40m back'.

We say that we understand the Government's dilemma. We faced this dilemma when in government and we failed. We took that action once. We will never do it again. That is a basic and fundamental rule of this country which ought never to be broken if possible. Sometimes there are screaming reasons why one feels that the law ought to be broken. Sometimes these reasons are overwhelming. However, at least some on our side of the Parliament say: `We will never do it again. We have fallen for that argument once but will never fall for it again'.

What I can say to the Senate is that there are no screaming, overwhelming reasons to break that fundamental principle of democracy in this case. The Government's desire to save $40m is not an overwhelming reason. Indeed, notwithstanding the Government's statements that it wants to spend the money on this and it wants to spend the money on that, how can it face up to the people of this nation and say: `We are prepared to change this Act retrospectively in order to save $40m'? Once the Government has done that what will be the situation with regard to all other laws which the Government could change to save money. The Government could go back, for example, and increase the fees in court cases in order to raise revenue. It could increase fines. It could do all sorts of things retrospectively if the only argument in favour of such an action is that one can save some money.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has persistently stated, and stated quite erroneously, that the ex-service community has not supported the Liberal and National parties' amendment to clause 119 in respect of retrospectivity. However, I say that as late as 2 February this year the Partially Blinded Soldiers Association of Australia said:

The retrospectivity clause is outrageous. It appears as a deliberate attempt by the Minister or the Treasurer, or both, to avoid paying the disabled veteran money to which he is rightfully entitled. The Government is quibbling about a national debt to its disabled fighting men, those who preserved for us the benefits and way of life we enjoy in Australia today.

What response can the Government make to that allegation? I suggest that it cannot make any response. That was the way the law stood when these applications were lodged. The applications ought to be dealt with on the basis of that law. The Federated TB Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Association of Australia said:

. . . until your Government returns to meaningful discussions with the ex-service community as a whole, and eliminates the ill-feeling engendered by the contents of your letter to Rear Admiral Guy Griffith, then the atmosphere of goodwill which has existed between veterans and governments since 1916 will continue in limbo.

I draw that statement in the letter to the Minister's attention in regard to his massive disinformation attack on us. The question of retrospectivity is a matter which I understand causes governments great concern. However, when we come to realise that we are not talking simply about political philosophies but are talking about fundamental beliefs in a democracy, we see that governments must be required to face up to and accept the cost of not altering laws retrospectively. So the legislation will cost $40m. The Government will just have to find that $40m. That certainly cannot be put as some overwhelming reason for going back and changing the law in regard to all of these applicants who lodged their applications before May 1985. That is why the Opposition has moved this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment the Opposition has moved is similar to the amendment moved by the Opposition last time we debated this piece of legislation. It refers basically to those people who have either put in a claim for determination prior to 15 May or who are in a situation where there is a review with regard to a claim and that review was put in place prior to 15 May. This is an area that obviously involves something which in the last few years has become a very important political item and one which is not easy to deal with.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember very well being abused by members of the Government, now the Opposition parties, when I opposed the retrospective application of tax laws introduced by the Fraser Government. Those laws were, in fact, an immense intrusion into the civil liberties of many Australians. I maintained at the time that those matters could have been dealt with by the law as it then stood if that law was applied by the people who were then in Government in the way that it should have been applied. The position I took at that stage has subsequently been vindicated by judgments of the Federal Court of Australia and the High Court of Australia.

Subsequent to that date there have been a number of occasions on which a benefit has been conferred retrospectively. Senator Lewis suggested that there was one exception. There is not one exception; in fact, there are two exceptions. The exception he mentioned was where a benefit might be conferred and, indeed, this place has conferred a benefit retrospectively. The other exception was one that, in fact, Senator Lewis and every member of this House voted for, when we passed a piece of retrospective legislation in regard to our own salaries. In other words, the other exception is where those people so affected accept the situation. That is relevant to this particular debate because there is a considerable body of opinion within the veteran community that they wish to accept this situation with regard to the current context, for reasons it has put forward in letters to all members of this chamber and the House of Representatives.

It is also interesting to note that a little later in the debate I will move another amendment to clauses 20 (3) and 20 (4) identical to the one I moved last year in regard to totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners. That undoubtedly is retrospective because everybody over the age of 65 is now deprived of the right to actually put in an application, is deprived retrospectively of the ability to make a claim. The cost of that will be far higher than the cost of the amendments the Opposition is currently supporting. I cannot quite see how the Opposition says that this is the Government's business with regard to 20 (3) and 20 (4) where there is obviously a retrospective application of this to all those people over the age of 65, but with regard to this amendment, it is sticking on that matter of principle. I hope that the Opposition will support me when it comes to that subsequent amendment I intend to move, possibly not on the basis of the substance of the argument but hopefully on that matter of principle with regard to restrospectivity.

I presume the Opposition's argument will be that it is not retrospective and, indeed, this is one of the difficulties we are facing with this particular clause because the sixteenth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills said:

While it is clear that this provision will put applicants in a new and less advantageous position, the Committee indicates as a matter of record that it accepts the Government's view that the application of the altered standard of proof in the determination of claims and appeals after the date on which the amending legislation came into operation does not involve any retrospectivity . . .

It is a seemingly fairly clear statement from that Standing Committee. In other words, there is certainly a considerable area of disagreement. It is interesting to note that in the middle of last year the forerunners to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985, which still lingers on in terms of various pieces of legislation, will be moved aside by this Bill being enacted and I was the only senator to raise this issue.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee at that particular time found itself in somewhat of a quandary, as it seems that the Government had probably accepted two versions, had them both drafted and put them both into the Bill at the same time. It is understandable how the Scrutiny of Bills Committee managed to get itself into difficulty, but it is interesting that no other senator in this place at that time raised any difficulties with regard to the retrospective elements of the Bills that have now gone through various changes and which now appear in the amendment that the Opposition has moved. I would have thought that if those amendments are not to be accepted at this time, they ought not to have been accepted previously. The reasons given at that time were that the Opposition did not actually see them as retrospective, so I would suggest that already there is a fair history over some nine months of a difficulty with regard to what type of retrospectivity is involved here. The type of retrospectivity involved here, if any, is certainly not of the kind that the Fraser Government introduced or the Hawke Government attempted to introduce in the 1983-84 Parliament and, indeed, in this Parliament with regard to taxation measures.

I personally opposed those items of retrospectivity. Speaking as the Australian Democrats spokesperson with regard to veterans' affairs, my colleagues have accepted the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I personally do not and hence I will be supporting the Opposition's amendment because I feel that the element of retrospectivity which is there ought not be there. However, my colleagues, in reviewing the matter, have come to the decision that the continuing support we have given in the past to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee ought be continued in this case.

One other item was raised in passing by Senator Lewis, which I think is an important one. That item is the point I have raised already of the problems facing the repatriation hospitals. Whether we like it or not, it seems to me undoubted that the Government would use the passage of this amendment-can I say that it would have been successful because undoubtedly the Government would back down if pressed-to avoid fulfilling any of those further commitments which are pressing. Whether we say it is on their head or anything else, that undoubtedly would be the political case, so my colleagues and I had to approach the matter not simply on the basis of the way the Government continuously in debates says we do not have to worry about types of decisions that are made because we are not in government, but on these particular occasons it gets terribly concerned about the types of decisions made. I wish it would be consistent with regard to its position because, even as late as yesterday, Senator Ryan said in this place that we did not have to worry about decisions that were made. If that is the case, I would be very interested to hear from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) at the table whether we do not have to worry about decisions made in this case.

With regard to the decision that is made, I and my colleagues had to look at the political consequences. We believe that if a decision had to be made as a matter of priority as to where that money should be spent, we had an obligation to make a priority judgment with regard to whether or not that money should be spent on upgrading the staffing in repatriation hospitals, in carrying out the obligations that the Government has said it wishes to carry out in regard to those ex-servicewomen who are currently being denied their rightful entitlements with regard to a gross operation of sex discrimination which this Government said it is reviewing, but that since it costs money it had to review it in the Budget considerations. I hope that it will review that and, in fact, remove that sex discrimination in regard to ex-servicewomen and that it will carry out a range of other vastly needed reforms that all those who deal with this area know need urgent attention, urgent support and that it will cost money. In our deliberations on this matter my colleagues and I believed that we then had an obligation to make a decision with regard to where that money should go. Quite clearly the decision was made that other needs were, undoubtedly, more pressing. I say to the Government: The Minister has not indicated to me, in any shape or form-I say this for the record because we do not want to get into a misunderstanding-anything with regard to any of those areas. We have had no discussions on them whatsoever other than the representations that I have made in a formal way to the Minister. So there is no undertaking on the part of the Minister on this matter.

We will be expecting to see those types of urgent needs satisfied in the Budget because the savings the Government has made-this has been displayed in the Estimates committees which are in process at the moment-are of such significance as to enable the Government to fulfil each of those areas that have been either under review or are currently under review. The Government has expressed some desire to look at this matter in a Budget context. We believe that it has now freed up sufficient funds to be able to undertake expenditure in all of those areas without quibbling about the cost. The Government has already saved far more money than it would spend on any of the urgent proposals that the veterans community has put to it for 1986-87. I reiterate that my colleagues will be opposing this particular amendment on the basis of the support of and judgment by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills after long and careful deliberation that these particular clauses do not involve any retrospectivity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be as brief as I possibly can. I think I should respond to Senator Lewis's views in particular because he has made a great deal of what he calls retrospectivity in respect of clause 119. The Government disputes, I dispute and the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills disputes that retrospectivity is involved and, therefore, we should not lose sight of the basic issue in question.

SPEECH.PARA: The Veterans' Entitlements Bill maintains the right of every person who lodged a claim prior to 15 May 1985 to have that claim determined on the basis of the criminal standard of proof of beyond reasonable doubt. The changes which apply from that date require that in respect of every claim, including claims lodged before that date, there be material raising a reasonable hypothesis of a connection between incapacity or death and service for the claim to be granted. The irresponsible alternative view put by the Opposition is that claims made prior to 15 May 1985 should succeed even where there is not even a scintilla of evidence of a war service connection. In other words, automatic acceptance of all claims lodged before 15 May 1985 is what is really being advocated by the Opposition. I point out that this view is not supported by any of the major ex-service organisations which seek just and equitable benefits for their members. What is the purpose of having a determining system if the O'Brien decision was going to be the general rule by which applicants for pensions or increase in pensions were going to be determined.

Senator Macklin has quite correctly drawn attention to the fact that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, in its sixteenth report, has agreed that no retrospectivity is involved in this matter. I will not repeat the arguments because they are there for those who want to examine the Committee's views. Senator Tate, the Chairman of the Committee, wrote to me confirming the view that I have expressed. He also advised that the form of words I have quoted was agreed to by all members of the Committee who were present at its meeting on 27 November 1985 and that there was no request by any member of the Committee to note any dissent as to the wording adopted prior to the meeting of the Committee on 19 February 1986. When the Opposition decided to make an issue of this, the matter was brought forward for further consideration. I do not think that anybody in the veteran community of any substance would suggest that the O'Brien decision should be the general decision for applicants who appear before tribunals. The Government is entitled to take the necessary legislative steps in respect of that decision which was such an open-handed decision as to make the determining system superfluous. The major ex-service organisations do not support the Opposition's stand on this matter, and neither indeed does the majority of the Australian Democrats.

Every person who has looked at this fairly and objectively has agreed with the Government's propositions. Yet we have Senator Lewis quoting one organisation-the Partially Blinded Soldiers Association of Australia; an important organisation, but a very small organisation-on its attitudes to the retrospectivity issue. I should quote back to Senator Lewis what that organisation said: That the whole Bill should be scrapped. Even Opposition senators would not put themselves in a position where they had to support that view. Obviously they have been misinformed or are uninformed on the positive features of this Bill. Senator Lewis, from the views he expressed, is aware that the National Secretary of the Returned Services League wrote to me on 13 February this year on behalf of all of the major ex-service organisations. Time will not permit me to deal with all the points in the letter other than to say that that meeting that he informed me of, which embraced all the veteran community's principal organisations, recognised:

. . . the retrospective nature of the legislation but felt that this was not unreasonable given the additional undertakings that the Government was prepared to make, especially in regard to cover for the regular forces. The meeting also felt that if there was insistence on the principle of retrospectivity it would need to apply not only to the standard of proof but also to dependants' allowances and eligibility for special rate TPI pensions.
Given the above, the meeting considered that the Bill should be enacted as soon as possible.

That is what we are seeking to do. As we do have a timetable problem, I will leave my further argument on this matter to be argued at some other time because there is an urgency to get this Bill dealt with by the Senate today so that the matter can go back to the House of Representatives and then back to the Senate before we rise this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Macklin for all his assistance in this regard. As I understand it, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was, in effect, saying that there was no technical retrospectivity because decisions had not yet been made on those applications so it could not be said that benefits were being taken away from people. I want simply to say that, as a former Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and as the current Deputy Chairman of that Committee, which is constantly looking at retrospectivity matters, from time to time fine lines have to be drawn. Quite frankly the Liberal and National Parties draw that line in regard to the provision to which Senator Macklin referred in relation to the Australian Democrats' amendment to section 24 because we believe that that relates to future applications. However, very fine lines need to be drawn from time to time.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give the Committee an example of the sort of thing that worries me considerably. Every union organisation in Australia has lodged with the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission an ambit claim which relates to all sorts of things, including retirement at age 45, the payment of very large sums of money on retirement, a large amount of annual leave, and a 25-hour week. The unions have lodged all sorts of outrageous ambit claims that at some stage or other they may wish to press. Does that mean that no future government dare pass legislation which would affect those ambit claims? Because those claims have already been lodged, could it be said that we should not deprive those unions of the opportunity to press them because to do so would be acting respectively? That is a much finer line for Senator Macklin to think about than the one that he raised with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would put your colleagues in difficulties.

—Yes, it certainly would do that. It would certainly put me in difficulties. But that is the sort of problem that one can get into when one looks at questions of retrospectivity. However, I cannot believe that one can honestly say here that the applications which were lodged prior to May 1985 will not be affected by this legislation. In fact, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has clearly indicated in his remarks about the different kinds of onus of proof that they will be affected. So there is no doubt that retrospectivity is involved, and in our view that should be opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Lewis's amendment) be added.

ROW.ENTRY: (Senator Maguire did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Missen.)

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 17, sub-paragraphs 13 (2) (c) (i) and (ii), lines 7 to 11, leave out sub-paragraphs, insert ``, in receipt of a pension under this Part,''.
(2) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 17, after sub-clause 13 (4), insert the following new sub-clauses:

`(4a) Where a person who is a dependent of a member of the Forces within the meaning of the Repatriation Act 1920 was, prior to the commencement of this Act, in receipt of a pension under Part III of that Act, and the Commonwealth, but for the operation of this sub-section, would not be liable to pay a pension to that person under this Act, the Commonwealth is liable to pay a pension to that person as if the Repatriation Act 1920 were in force after the commencement of this Act.

`(4b) Where a person entitled to pension under sub-section (4a) elects to receive, in lieu of that pension, a payment equal to the amount of pension payable to that person during the period of 5 years following that election, such an amount is payable to that person in lieu of that pension.'.
(3) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 19, after sub-clause 13 (8), add the following new sub-clause:

`(8a) Where a pension payable under the Repatriation Act 1920 to a person who is a widow of a member of the Forces within the meaning of that Act ceased to be payable by reason of that person's marriage, and that person is divorced or that person's husband dies, the Commonwealth is liable to pay a pension to that person in accordance with this Act as if that person were the widow of a veteran.'.
(5) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
Page 27, paragraphs 23 (1) (a) and (b), lines 3 to 9, leave out the paragraphs.
Page 27, paragraph 23 (3) (b), lines 41 and 42, leave out ``, not being a veteran who has attained the age of 65 years,''.
(6) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
Page 28, paragraphs 24 (1) (a) and (b), lines 11 to 18, leave out the paragraphs.
Page 28, paragraph 24 (1) (c), line 19 leave out ``that''.
Page 28, paragraph 24 (2) (b), lines 35 and 36, leave out ``, not being a veteran who has attained the age of 65 years,''.
(7) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 29, after clause 24, add the following new clause:
Exceptional disability allowance
`24A. (1) Where
(a) a veteran is not entitled to receive a pension under section 24 by reason only of the operation of sub-paragraph 24 (2) (a) (i); and
(b) the Commission is satisfied that the degree of incapacity of the veteran from war-caused injury or war-caused disease, or both, increased after the veteran ceased to engage in remunerative work,
pension is payable to the veteran under section 24 notwithstanding that sub-paragraph.'.
(8) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:
Page 108, after paragraph 81 (1) (b), add the following new word and paragraph:
``or (c) an allied veteran within the meaning of Part III, and who is an Australian citizen,''.
Page 109, paragraph 81 (2) (a), at end of paragraph, add ``, or an allied veteran within the meaning of Part III who is an Australian citizen''.
(9) Amendments:
Page 23, sub-clause 19 (4), lines 13 and 14, leave out ``the claim shall, by force of this sub-section, be deemed to have been refused'', insert ``the Commission may refuse the claim''.
Page 160, paragraph 137 (2) (b), at end of paragraph, add ``or as the Board requires for its purposes''.

These amendments and requests take up again various items which we have raised previously and which we still consider to be defects in the legislation itself. The first amendment applies to clause 13, which limits the payment of a pension to a dependant if the death of a veteran is due to a war-caused injury or disease, unless that veteran is receiving a special rate totally and permanently incapacitated pension. Amendment No. 1 would have the effect of ensuring that on the death of a general rate pensioner from non-accepted disabilities his widow would continue to receive a pension. Amendment No. 2 relates to sub-clause (4) of clause 13 and it covers dependants' pensions also. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Geitzelt) has maintained that none of the benefits available to veterans prior to the passage of this Bill will be removed. Here in the Bill we see the removal of such a benefit, and that amendment seeks to retain that benefit.

Amendment No. 3 relates to clause 13 (8). That provision in the legislation would enable war widows who marry after 29 May 1984 to retain their war widows' pension. My amendment provides for the restoration of a pension to a war widow who has lost it under the existing legislation because she has remarried. The rights of that very small group of people have actually been lost in the amendments that have been made. In all fairness and justice the amendment should be accepted because they are the only group of people who are now disadvantaged under the Government's expansion of benefits in this area.

The proposed amendment to clause 19 (4) seeks to take out the words `deemed to have been refused' and to insert the words `the Commission may refuse the claim'. This is being proposed to try to provide some flexibility and discretion to the Repatriation Commission. I rehearsed at some length the arguments for that proposition in the previous debate on 28 November 1985. They are to be found in Hansard of that date at page 2453. Amendments Nos 5, 6 and 7 deal with the TPI pension. I suggest that is really the last remaining major item that has not been effectively dealt with. I am still extremely concerned about people over the age of 65 who have subsequently lost their right to make application. I predicted-I will be interested in the next year to see whether my prediction comes true-that the changes the Government has made to the legislation will cost the Government money rather than the reverse.

I am quite sure that veterans, on advice from their organisations, will now make application at the time prior to retirement when they have the ability to sustain a case under those amended provisions rather than, as many of them have done, wait until they feel they can wait no longer. It is now in their interests to make the application at the earliest possible date, and I believe that the effect of such action will to add considerably to costs. There are many veterans-all of us in this chamber have met some of those veterans-who have not applied for pensions that are available to them but have rather soldiered on, as it were, because they believed that they were capable of looking after themselves and they did not wish at that stage to be a burden on the public purse. I believe they must now put aside those feelings in their own interests and in the interests of their spouses and make sure that they put in their applications at the earliest possible date.

Amendments Nos. (8) and (9) cover items that I have raised previously. First of all, amendment No. (8) relates to an allied veteran who is an Australian citizen. The arguments in that case were rehearsed previously at quite some length when we debated this question and I do not wish to go over them again. They are to be found in the Hansard of 28 November of last year. Likewise, that is the case with the arguments with regard to clause 137 (2).

I believe that of all those amendments the most important one relates to the TPI. It seems to me that the situation could very well rebound on the Government. At a later stage we will have to review that issue because I believe an injustice is being perpetrated on those veterans. At the close of my remarks may I say that the submission of the Australian Veterans and Defence Service Council rehearses quite a number of those points. While it also supported the Opposition's position with regard to the amendments that the Senate has just voted on, it also supported, probably in even stronger form, the proposal that something be done with regard to clauses 23 and 24.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats are largely those which were moved in the Senate last year, and they are not accepted. Honourable senators will recall that arrangements for dealing with amendments were agreed on 5 December last year. Those arrangements were in conformity with views agreed on by the major ex-service organisations. In the light of that understanding reached in December, the Government is not prepared to accept the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of amendments have been moved by Senator Macklin. I want to have one of them clarified and that is amendment No. 3, relating to the insertion of an additional sub-clause after sub-clause (8) of clause 13. I suppose that a number of us have received representations on these questions. I certainly have. I have a particular case in mind of a person who had been receiving a veterans' allowance and who remarried in June 1983 and the benefit ceased. The Government has restored that benefit to people who have remarried since 29 May 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand Senator Macklin's amendment, the position of that constituent would be covered. I feel that it is important for the Government to tell us how many people are involved. I know the Government has put forward the view that 29 May 1984 was the date on which the announcement was made and therefore that would be the date from which the benefit would be restored. That does not seem logical to me. It is certainly not logical to the people who are affected. I would have thought that if the Government were going to make a date it would make it the date of the election in 1983. I have been searching around for an appropriate date, and that date would cover the constituent for whom I am concerned, but it may not cover some other people. The logic of it should be that if the principle is that a person who is receiving a veterans' allowance does not lose it on remarriage after 29 May 84, why not apply that principle across the board? As Senator Macklin has said, presumably there are not very many persons in that category. I support the proposition that the principle be accepted and applied across the board. In the absence of any detailed information from the Government which would indicate that this would create an intolerable economic burden on the Government, I think it deserves the support of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intent of the amendment is to pick up the situation-I think they are few-of a war widow having remarried. Of course, under the previous legislation she would then lose her pension. Under this legislation it will be restored. Of course, the widow who has previously lost her pension upon her remarriage, and her second husband dies or they are divorced, is left totally out in the cold. It seems to me to be a rather extraordinary situation. Someone who could very well have suffered the death of two husbands ought to be treated, under my amendment, as a person who is entitled to the pension. The Government, in its own amendments, has shown that it accepts the principle that that person should not be deprived of support. But by inserting a cut-off date-I realise that there must obviously be some type of cut-off date-of 29 May, that circumstance arises. My amendment, of course, seeks to avoid that and to provide the benefit to any widow who finds herself in that situation subsequent to the passage of this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was waiting for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) to respond to Senator Harradine and Senator Macklin. I say simply that from the Liberal and National parties point of view, we recognise that these are policy decisions of the Government. We cannot impose our policies, or what we believe the Government ought to be doing, on the decisions that the Government has decided to make. As I said previously, having made its bed, it must lie in it. In regard to retrospectivity in relation to clause 24, the only thing I want to add is that the proposal is that people would have been treated differently if they had been born earlier. The Government is taking away a prospective benefit. That, in my view, does not fall within my definition of retrospectivity. Indeed, it happens every time, for example, that the Government changes the tax laws, when the Government perhaps takes away a prospective benefit. So I do not believe it falls within my definition of retrospectivity, although I understand that it falls within the definition adopted by Senator Macklin.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the requests for amendments and amendments (Senator Macklin's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise one outstanding matter on the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Amendments) Amendment Bill 1986 with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). This relates to a suggestion, made originally by Rear-Admiral Griffiths, which I put to the Minister last year, about the need for a monitoring committee. Having served on the Joint Committee on Electoral Reform, I have noticed how useful it is to look back over massive changes to legislation in the light of experience. I believe that a monitoring committee should be set up comprising representatives of the ex-service community, that it should report to the Minister after the operation for 12 months of this Act and that the Minister should undertake that that report will be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Government should then respond to that report as to what types of changes, if any, are needed in legislation and what changes the Government will be willing to accept. If the Department of Veterans' Affairs can provide this committee with all necessary administrative assistance, particularly the statistical data on how each of the changes and the rules affect veterans, we will see much greater support-and probably unanimous support-from the veteran community for the operation of the Act, provided those people know what is happening and how it is happening. I believe that that is the best way in which this matter could be handled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his speech Senator Macklin referred to the need to establish a committee to report on the first 12 months' operation of the veterans' entitlements legislation and in particular on any aspects of that operation which are of concern to the ex-service community. I am happy to give such an undertaking. I will set up such a committee. Membership will include representatives from the ex-service community and the committee will report to the Parliament in the Budget sittings of 1987. The Government will respond to that report as soon as possible thereafter. I also indicate that the Department of Veterans' Affairs will provide administrative support to the committee in its work, including access to statistical information concerning the determining system, and will bring forward briefing papers on any relevant matters arising out of the passage of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments and requests; report adopted.
Sitting suspended from 12.48 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) left Australia yesterday for official duties in the United States of America and Europe. He will return to Australia on 28 April. During his absence the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, will be Acting Prime Minister.

—I ask the Minister for Finance: Is it a fact that the reversal of the decision to quarantine farm losses is the most costly single item in the Government's rural package? Does the Minister recall telling the Senate on 19 March that reversal of either or both the quarantining and capital gains tax decisions `would make absolutely no contribution to easing the present fiscal problems in the agricultural sector'? Did he also in the same answer say that the removal of neither the capital gains tax nor the quarantining of farm losses, which is now such an important part of its rural package, will have any effect on farm sector profitability? In the light of those expressed opinions of a few weeks ago, does the Minister agree with the Leader of the Opposition who has described the package as a disappointing hoax and the President of the National Farmers Federation who has said that it amounts to a total non-recognition of farmers' problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to McLachlan, if he thinks it is worth nothing and wants to make an offer to the Government that the Government should take it back again, it will make our Budget problems a lot easier. It is worth a great deal to the Government and me, in putting together the Budget, whether McLachlan thinks it is worth anything or not. It has not been a reversal. Firstly, Senator Chaney should get his facts straight. The decision has not been reversed. It has been announced that the Murrumbateman hobby farmers, for whom Senator Lewis speaks in this place, will be addressed in a different way, and there will be some other changes relating to valuation of stud stock and so on. As a point of fact it is quite wrong to say that there has been a reversal. Therefore, the figures that have been used of $65m and $45m are also incorrect.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to forestry, I have conceded right from the beginning-although I have never been asked a question about it in the Senate-that in my view there always was a problem with forestry investments, and that constitutes about 10 or 11 per cent of the $65m. In regard to there being no contribution to farm sector profitability, I stand by that statement and I am quite willing to let what will happen be the judge of me on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that the March trade figures show that a large proportion of the drop in our imports is due to Australia importing less fuel? In view of the rapid expected rundown in Bass Strait oil reserves by 1993, would it not make sense to buy oil while prices are low and conserve our own oil to sell when prices are higher and to use when oil is scarce, or are we so caught up in the balance of payments problems that we cannot afford to take advantage of cheaper prices for oil and are using our own reserves at an increasing rate? Will the Minister take steps to stop the oil multinationals ripping off the Australian community, rather than providing them with a $125m subsidy at the taxpayers' expense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ignore the invective in the last part of the question. We will have ample opportunity to debate the merits of the Government's currently proposed legislation in this place later, without too much of a populist, shark feeding frenzy from that corner of the chamber, if we can help it. As to the basic question, fuel import figures are subject to some volatility, particularly in the light of the current situation, in crude oil markets and through stock adjustments. To the extent that the dollar value of fuel imports shows a marked reduction in March as compared with January and February, a great deal of that simply reflects the massive cut in oil prices over that period and does not necessarily reflect a drop in volume at all. There is simply no evidence to suggest any trend towards domestic production of petroleum replacing petroleum imports in the Australian market. In fact, domestic production has declined markedly in recent months from an average of 555,000 barrels per day all through 1985 to below 472,000 barrels per day in March this year. Most of this fall is due to reduced exports of crude oil from the Bass Strait.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not government policy to intervene in the production decisions of Australian petroleum producers in the manner suggested by Senator Vigor. It is apparent that the current low oil prices are resulting in reduced production from Australian oil fields and considerable volatility, as I have said, in supply decisions of refiners and distributors. It is the case that current low oil prices are creating difficulties for the Australian oil industry. Any action to further reduce domestic production in the way that has been suggested would undoubtedly exacerbate this problem and further discourage exploration and development at a time when it is extremely important for our long term oil supply situation that such activity should continue to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Health seen the report in today's Age which states that the company which contracted to deliver the Government's anti-drug booklet had instructed its staff not to deliver to boxes which request no advertising matter or junk mail? What action will the Government take to ensure that all householders will receive this material?

—I am afraid that I have not seen the article in the Age to which Senator Zakharov referred. I would certainly be concerned if the anti-drug booklets were not delivered in the manner promised. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Health. I will find out why I have not got an answer already and will get the answer to Senator Zakharov as soon as possible.

—I bring to the attention of honourable senators the presence in the Presidential Gallery of a delegation from the House of Representatives of the Federal Parliament of Malaysia. The delegation is led by the Honourable Aw How Cheong, the Parliamentary Secretary of the Ministry of Energy, Tele- communications and Post. On behalf of all honourable senators I extend to the delegation a warm and friendly welcome to Australia and to the Senate.

—I refer the Minister for Finance to the growing rental accommodation crisis as a result of the Government's decisions on negatively geared investments and capital gains taxation. Is the Minister aware of a joint study by the Real Estate Institute of Australia and the Western Australian Government's housing body, Homewest, which showed that more than 85 per cent of property owners had no intention of acquiring new properties because of the tax changes? Is he aware also of a 25 per cent increase in home rentals over the past year, as revealed by a Master Builders Association survey? Now that the Government has belatedly decided to drop its farm loss quarantining proposal, because of the damage that would cause to primary producers, will it review its decisions on negative gearing and the related capital gains tax?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. In the light of the Federal Government's drug offensive and the Prime Minister's support and pledge on law enforcement, has the Minister's attention been drawn to a television program broadcast by Channel TVO Brisbane on 17 March 1986? During the course of this program it was alleged that a number of offences had been committed through the use of Telecom equipment in Brisbane. Channel TVO claims to have in its possession tapes that outline the misuse of telephones in the Telecom system. This misuse included money changing hands for placing taps on phones, claims that telephones are being used for industrial espionage and sabotage, transfer of inside betting information on horse racing, de-activating burglar alarms and systems, rigging of telephone accounts, and overseas phone calls to arrange international drug shipments. In respect of the drug offensive, what action, if any, is being taken to investigate these claims by the Federal Police or any other authority? If action has been taken, have there been any arrests, transfers or continuing investigation, or any investigation into the matters raised by Channel TVO in its program on 17 March 1986 or in any subsequent programs?

—It appears that I have no brief on this question. Something seems to have gone genuinely wrong, Mr President. It is a question without notice that I have received from Senator Jones. I will seek some information on it and give it to him in due course.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of a study by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research predicting a loss of 35,000 car sales this year because of the company car tax, and figures published yesterday which show a 36 per cent drop in fleet and business sales during January and February compared with 12 months ago? Does he concede that with such a severe downturn occurring in the industry, the prospect now is for a much lower revenue result from the car tax, and, on our calculations, a likely net gain of only $49m as against the Treasurer's September prediction of $350m? In the light of its change of mind about quarantining farm losses, will the Government reconsider the fringe benefits tax, which is threatening so many thousands of jobs in the motor industry for a relatively insignificant return in revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For those who are familiar with the recent political history of Western Australia, it should come as no surprise at all that a Western Australian Liberal senator habitually defends the interests of tax evaders and avoiders in this Parliament. Western Australia, in the late 1970s and the early 1980s--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. There is a clear provision in the Standing Orders that the question should not be debated. The Minister, in responding to a question which is quite clear, simple and straight forward, commences by entering into a debate on quite irrelevant matters and in quite abusive terms which we have come to expect. In the interests of the continuation of orderly Question Time, when senators get a chance to ask their questions, I ask that you ask the Minister to simply answer the question that has been put to him.

—Senator Chaney and all honourable senators will know that how a Minister chooses to answer a question is a matter for the Minister himself or herself. In this case, though, I ask Senator Walsh to take heed of standing order 100, which does not allow debate on a question, and to bear in mind standing order 100 when he replies to the question.

—Certainly, Mr President. I certainly had no intention of debating it. I just want to put a few facts on the record. One fact is that Professor Hewson, that well known guru of the Liberal Party, has said that Senator Chaney is not up to leading the Liberal Party. So I can understand why Senator Chaney is eager to change Professor Hewson's mind by raising spurious points of order.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a matter of historical record that Western Australia, particularly the Western Australian Liberal Party, in the late 1970s and the early 1980s, was the refuge, the sanctuary, the home, of the largest tax avoiders and evaders in all of Australia. The majority of the members of the Western Australian Liberal Party finance committee in the late 1970s were in fact subsequently revealed to have been bottom of the harbour tax evaders. That was through the period when Senator Knowles was an office-bearer-a senior vice-president, I think-of the Western Australian Liberal Party. So it should come as no surprise at all to those who are familiar with that history that the Western Australian Liberal Party, and the senators who represent it here, stand up to protect the interest of tax avoiders and tax evaders. I am wondering whether the next question in this puerile sequence will be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to your previous ruling in relation to standing order 100. I suggest that Senator Walsh is not obeying your previous ruling.
—Order! I have given the Minister a fair go and I ask him to answer the question specifically.

—I was about to do that, Mr President. I wonder whether the next question in this puerile sequence will be from a member of the Opposition repeating the false assertions regarding the employment effects of the abolition of the free lunch as stated by an organisation which was known by the acronym BAND.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It has been reported in the Darwin media that the United States has made application to establish a military base in that city. Could the Minister confirm that such an approach has been made, and if so, the Government's reaction to it?
—I think that is more of a defence question. I am afraid I do not have a detailed briefing on it. I will check and see whether I can give Senator Robertson an answer before the day is out.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It concerns the decision of the Australian Labor Party Caucus to suspend Senator Georges from further meetings pending a final decision of his membership of the Party. Will this action affect any of Senator Georges's functions in this place, in particular his position as Chairman of the important Joint Committee of Public Accounts?

—The decision to which Senator Kilgariff refers will not affect any of Senator Georges's functions in this place, as Senator Kilgariff describes them, such as the chairmanship of committees and so on. I hope that Senator Georges will continue to exercise his functions as a senator with his normal acumen and diligence.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Now that the Veterans' Entitlements Bill has virtually passed into law, will the Minister respond to criticisms that a group of ex-servicemen who served in Vietnamese waters on the HMAS Sydney, her escorts and the Boonaroo and Jeparit have been consistently denied repatriation benefits? Will the passage of the Bill have any effect on the entitlements of these ex-servicemen?

—Senator Foreman asks me a question with respect to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill and the transitional provisions and consequential amendments Bills associated with it. It is true that the Senate this morning dealt with that Bill and made certain decisions relating to the legislation. The Bill, however, has not yet passed into law. It requires further consideration by the House of Representatives, and it will come back to the Senate, I hope, some time tomorrow. However, I think that we can say that the legislation is as near to being passed as it can be. Arising out of that, the Government's commitment to those who served in the circumstances described by Senator Foreman will enable them to participate in the areas of responsibility under the Department of Veterans' Affairs. My colleague the Minister for Defence has the responsibility of classifying persons who were involved in the Vietnam conflict on special duty. He has indicated that those who served on the HMAS Sydney, her escort vessels and the Boonaroo and Jeparit will come under that classification and will qualify under the legislation which, we trust, will be passed some time tomorrow. In those circumstances those eligible persons will be able to apply for disability pensions for service-related incapacities or death, in the case of their widows, and for service pensions for repatriation treatment entitlements. Many of them will be able to participate in the defence service homes loan scheme. However, I would point out, having regard to a number of representations that have been made to me, that this will not be retrospective for the purpose of taking over existing housing loans.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: FOREIGN EXCHANGE COVER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I remind the Minister of evidence given yesterday before the Senate Estimates Committee C that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation required an extra allocation of $12.8m this year to cover extra costs of imported television programs, capital and other items resulting from the devaluation of the Australian dollar and that this huge extra allocation of Australian taxpayers' money arose because of the refusal of the Department of Finance to accede to the ABC's strong request of May last year to be allowed to take out forward cover on its foreign exchange commitment, eventually allowing it in January 1986 after this huge loss had been suffered. Since then no further losses have been incurred. I ask: How many other instances are there of government authorities such as the ABC which are supposed to adopt proper commercial practices being prevented by his Department from taking protective foreign exchange cover, as the ABC had requested? What has been the cost of such action by his Department over the last two years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental ignorance displayed in that question perhaps helps to explain why Patrick Partners became insolvent years ago when Senator Michael Baume was helping to run it and defaulted on the money which had been left in its care by all the widows and orphans.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order.
—Order! The Minister should withdraw that last remark contained in his answer.
—That bit about the widows and orphans? I withdraw that because I am not really sure who lost money on it.
—Order! I ask the Minister to answer Senator Baume's question specifically.

—I am, Mr President. The losses referred to of $12.8m are in fact the difference between the ultimate cost of programs and equipment estimated just over 12 months ago at the exchange rate that prevailed 12 months ago and the final cost; that is, an estimate at a particular exchange rate and the final cost.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume assumes that the difference between those two figures, which he said was $12.8m-that roughly accords with my recollection of it-was something that was lost because the ABC was not allowed to take out forward cover. He is making that assertion without either knowing or making any allowance for the cost to the ABC of taking out the forward cover. Nobody knows what the cost would have been of taking out the forward cover for the particular dates on which the delivery of the equipment and programs was due. It may well have been more than $12.8m, in which case there would have been a saving. Senator Baume continues to display in the Senate the profound ignorance of this issue which he displayed at the Estimates committee meeting yesterday afternoon in spite of the attempts by the relevant ABC official to enlighten him on the subject.

On the broader question of forward exchange cover insurance and so on, the general policy of the Government and, so far as I know, all previous governments is that the Commonwealth is its own insurer in matters of foreign exchange exposure and insurance in general.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Wheat Board?

—I am about to come to that. The Commonwealth's policy is that the Commonwealth is its own insurer on matters of foreign exchange risk exposure and of general mercantile insurance. Some agencies-the Wheat Board is one; I thank Senator Baume for his prompting-have been allowed to borrow overseas in the past. As I recall the evidence yesterday of Mr Le Gallant, an ABC officer at the Committee, he had first casually mentioned the question of allowing the ABC, given that, although it is a Budget funded authority, it is not an agency of the Commonwealth in the way that a department of State is, to take out some forward exchange cover in the way in which I understand the Wheat Board does. That was a casual mention in about December 1984. More serious discussions took place in about April or May of 1985. I am not sure when the approval came through, but I think it was some time before the end of 1985.
—January 1986.

—Okay, that is a month's difference. If other bodies which exist under Commonwealth statute wish to make applications to the Government, they will be considered on a one to one basis. The assumptions which Senator Baume has made and which he spelt out then are quite false. Likewise, of course, his assumptions about those outstanding contracts for the delivery of capital equipment and programs which the ABC still has. Whether the ABC will reduce the cost or increase the cost ultimately through taking out forward exchange cover is an empirical question which can only be answered empirically and not in the way in which Senator Baume seeks to answer it.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, a major reason for the ABC's being permitted to operate in a more commercial way, if one likes to use that term, is that it is one of those agencies which is given a budget within which it is expected to live. Not necessarily as a matter of reducing the final outcome cost, the ABC has chosen to operate in this way-that is, to use hedging-because its outcomes are more predictable in that way. The final costs may be higher or lower but they are more predictable. For that reason the management decision was taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Mr President, recognising your admonition yesterday about supplementary questions, I simply want to draw the Minister's attention to the fact that I specifically asked him whether there are any other instances of requests from government authorities for permission to seek forward cover being held up or rejected by his Department and what is the cost of such hold-ups or rejections?

—There are none that I know of which are presently under consideration or which have been rejected. I will check that. I can only assume from the part of the supplementary question as to what is the cost that Senator Michael Baume is ineducable.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: Following the events of yesterday in Libya, what is known about the situation of Australians presently living in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following yesterday's events the Department of Foreign Affairs has been in contact with our embassies in Bonn and Rome, which are the communication points into Libya for us, and a number of private companies employing Australians in Libya to establish the welfare and whereabouts of Australians in that country. The Department has also been receiving inquiries from next of kin and friends in Australia. There are approximately 25 to 30 Australians known to be in Libya at present and about 10 or 12 others whom the Department understands also are in Libya. However, this latter information cannot yet be confirmed until next of kin or employers can be contacted.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Embassy in Bonn has reported that the Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany in Tripoli, which, as I have indicated, represents Australian consular interests in Libya, has received calls from a number of Australians in Libya advising that they are safe and well. Details of their names and next of kin are not yet available. The Embassy has also said that it has received no reports of any Australian being injured. The Department of Foreign Affairs will continue to monitor the situation closely and keep next of kin informed. I should mention also that consistent with usual practice in these matters, the Department of Foreign Affairs yesterday issued a travel warning advising Australians contemplating travel to Libya to consider doing so only if it is essential. There are some other points that can usefully be made in respect of that travel warning practice and I will be happy to do so at the conclusion of Question Time in answer to Senator Hill's foray into this subject yesterday.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Education. I refer the Minister to the much publicised booklet entitled the Drug Offensive and in particular to the paragraph headed `Boys on Girls on Drugs'. I remind the Minister of direct quotations from young men, namely:

QUESTION.PARA: `When girls lose control they look cheap, real pushovers.'
`You expect girls to be different. It's kind of expected when guys throw up or flake out. But when girls do the same thing it's bad. It's wrong. You just don't want to know them.'
`I can't stand it when girls lose control . . . it's hard to explain but they sort of lose all their dignity . . .'
I further refer the Minister to the editorial text, presumably approved by the Government, which includes such gems as:
Boys just don't respect girls who allow themselves to lose control.
If only girls really knew what boys think of girls who are on drugs . . .
How does the Minister reconcile the use of these archaic sexist stereotype references in Government material when she so strongly disapproves of it in educational and other material?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone is probably aware that the booklet she referred to was produced by the Commonwealth Department of Health and I think it has gone out under its aegis, so I do not have ministerial responsibility for it. I did read some of the extracts that Senator Vanstone referred to and I was surprised by them. But my interpretation of them was that they attempted to reflect existing attitudes in the community, attitudes which I surely agree with Senator Vanstone ought to be changed, but attitudes which exist nonetheless. I imagine that the writers of that booklet were merely trying to put the most unattractive representation on drug taking possible so as to dissuade young people from that course of action.
