ANSWER.PARA: I do not think the writers were, in that particular publication, trying to deal with sex stereotyping-there are many other publications of the Government which try to deal with that-but rather to reflect, in a way that is very accessible to those groups of young people who are most susceptible to drugs, a very unattractive picture of the drug taker, similar to some of the images in smoking campaigns which are also extremely unattractive but which are used as a sort of aversion therapy, I suppose, with the hope of dissuading, in this case, young girls from drug taking. I do not really think there is a conflict between that aim and the general equal opportunity aims of our Government. I agree with the implication that it is unfortunate that stereotyped attitudes prevail but I hope that in this particular case the use of them may have some beneficial effects for young girls who might otherwise be vulnerable to drug taking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Do I understand from the Minister's answer that she is telling the Senate that the end in this case-to put girls off taking drugs-justifies the means, namely in this case the use of sexist phrases, and if she is saying as a matter of principle that the end does justify the means, would she justify that approach in her Department?
—I am saying that the end in view of this booklet, which is to dissuade young people, in particular young girls, from drug taking, is an end that I hope will be achieved.

—My question is to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer him to his response of 9 April to a question from Senator Maguire regarding reports that Colonel Gaddafi could bulldoze Australian and Commonwealth war graves in Libya. The Minister responded that the story was a beat-up and without substance. Does the Minister still believe that the sanctity of our war graves in Libya is assured? If not, can he indicate from where he believes that the major threat to their sanctity emanates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that Senator Maguire asked me a question about a beat-up story a week ago which suggested that Colonel Gaddafi was somehow threatening Commonwealth war graves, including Australian war graves, in Libya. I indicated that there was absolutely no justification or substance in the exaggerated responses given by Opposition spokesmen, as well as some other people. That is a matter of some regret because people were unnecessarily alarmed by statements that the Colonel was involved in the possible bulldozing of the 8,000 Allied war graves in Libya. In point of fact, of course, the war graves are under no threat at all from a domestic point of view in Libya.

ANSWER.PARA: The war graves are located in Tripoli and at the time at which I responded to Senator Maguire, I completely deprecated any suggestion that they were under threat. However, since that date there has been an escalation of tensions in the region as a result of the death and destruction that has flowed from the bombing which has taken place. The Government has urged both sides to mediate and to resolve their differences rather than to engage in hostilities. I think all of us would agree that that is a very important objective. However, having said that, and bearing in mind that the Commonwealth war graves are the responsibility of the United Kingdom, I would imagine that Mrs Thatcher's involvement in the bombing of Libya would probably place the Commonwealth war graves under some form of retaliation or jeopardy if, of course, Colonel Gaddafi were to retaliate.

Whilst the Government is concerned about the living, as indeed I am in my capacity as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, I am concerned about the sanctity and the protection of the war graves in Tripoli. I would hope that the actions that are taking place in that region will not put the war graves under any form of threat because already I am beginning to receive letters expressing concern about the statements that were made 10 days ago from relatives of those who lost their lives in Libya during World War II. Undoubtedly, of course, the situation has changed dramatically since then because there was no substance in that story at all. I do not know how well precision bombing takes place, but I would imagine that there is now a greater threat to the sanctity of the war graves in the post-bombing period than there was previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Over the last week we have seen $2.5 billion invested in share market deals between Elders and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that has not increased the productive capacity of either company one iota. I put it to the Minister that this is a symptom of a much larger malaise, and I ask: Is the Government concerned that, while productive investment in plant and machinery actually fell from $13.75 billion in 1983-84 to $13.5 billion in 1984-85, the cash involved in successful takeovers jumped from $1.9 billion in 1984 to $4.2 billion in 1985, and stock market indices jumped 40 per cent between January 1984 and January 1986? Does the Government consider that these figures are signs that investment is being seriously misdirected in this country and will it move to introduce measures to prevent the misdirection and the increasing concentration of the ownership of Australian industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matters raised by Senator Siddons are serious matters and are matters of concern. I personally have expressed concern, certainly when takeovers of this size took place in the non-trade exposed area of the economy a year or so ago. There have been a number of inputs from various sources to the debate about investment decisions in Australia. Apart from saying that I think the questions are worthy of continuing examination I just want to make one or two comments about the particular matters which Senator Siddons has raised. In the last part of the question Senator Siddons suggested-it was perhaps not intended in the way that I heard it-that increasing concentration of ownership in Australian industry was, in itself, a bad thing. I think it may be in itself a bad thing in the circumstances which were illustrated by Senator Siddons in the earlier part of his question. I am not sure that it is a bad thing in other sections of Australian industry if it means that there is less fragmentation of industry and a greater concentration of productive capacity than there has been in the past. I just wanted to make that qualification quite clear.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to add two or three other comments. First of all, some of the elements of the Government's tax package will reduce the incentive for investors to engage in non-productive activities. The paper being prepared by the Treasury on the question of negative gearing may well be relevant to that issue and that will require close examination by the Govenment and others. But with regard to the taxation proposals which the Government is in the process of implementing, just let me make the point that it is the Government's belief that it will encourage investment in much more productive activity than has been the case in the past. I refer to the Australian Financial Review editorial commenting on the tax package on 24 September last year. It made this point:

It is by now apparent that the imputation elements of Mr Keating's tax package have the ability to bring enormous changes to Australian share markets. The whole balance between the ability to draw tax-free dividends and the old principle of seeking tax-free capital gains has been altered.

The change has reinstated, at one stroke, the share markets as the main raisers of capital in the country. It has spectacularly altered the traditional notion that capital gains must be the main source of profits.
It goes on:
It will encourage investment in shares that seem to have the quality of paying consistently reasonable dividends.

Quite apart from that, I think it is important in looking at this issue that one cannot necessarily draw valid conclusions from the big figures which Senator Siddons quoted and, indeed, from the aggregate figures which he referred to in drawing a comparison between investment in plant and equipment and investment in takeovers, to short circuit a longer description. I think it is important to recognise that former shareholders of companies which have been the subject of takeovers will, in theory at least, use the proceeds of those share sales by investing, hopefully in the light of a new tax package, in productive activities or, alternatively, by conserving and, in that sense, assisting production in Australia or overseas. It is not immediately obvious that these funds would have otherwise been forthcoming in the course of freeing up the market or investment in more productive activities. There are other benefits from the changes which have taken place and will continue to take place. One cannot quantify the benefits, but I am sure it will be a benefit in the fact that it may provide a welcome infusion of new blood on the boards of companies which, to say the least, may need it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of strong criticism of the extension of phone tapping powers to State governments in special circumstances? What role will the Federal Government have to prevent abuse of these powers, particularly in States like Queensland where the Council for Civil Liberties believes these powers may lead to further harassment of citizens with opinions contrary to the National Party minority Government? Can the Minister guarantee that the proposed phone tapping powers will not legitimise illegal interference with telephone lines like that discovered at the Brisbane fertility control clinics late last year after the Government had harassed women at those clinics?

—Senator Archer asked me a question yesterday covering some of this territory which I will be in a position to respond to after Question Time. But the Attorney-General has advised me in response to the sorts of issues that Senator Reynolds has raised that he is aware that there has been some criticism of the Government's proposal to extend telecommunications interception powers to the police forces of certain States and Territories. The proposals arise out of agreements reached during the Special Premiers Conference on the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse held in Canberra last year. Under the proposals, interception powers would be available only to the police force of a State or Territory where the State or Territory requested such powers and where it had laws providing adequate safeguards against abuse. The safeguards would be at least as stringent as those which presently apply to members of the Australian Federal Police under the present Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. Participating States and Territories will be required to maintain and comply with those safeguards at all times. The powers will be exercisable only pursuant to a judicial warrant in cases involving drug trafficking offences. The proposals will, in no way, legitimise illegal interference with telephone lines.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen reports of a visit last week to Mount Magnet in Western Australia by the head of the gold tax inquiry, Mr Gutman, which alleges that everybody who spoke to Mr Gutman decided he had already made up his mind to recommend the implementation of a corporate tax on gold mining and that the residents of Mount Magnet were so incensed by his attitude that they proceeded to organise a very large successful rally? Is the Government aware that Mr Gutman has made up his mind on this question, or has it any reason to believe that he may have done so? Will the Government assure the Senate that Mr Gutman was not selected by the Government in the expectation that he would give a report favouring a tax on gold? Will the Government seek assurances from Mr Gutman that he has not in fact made up his mind on the subject of the inquiry and that it is worth while for all those opposed to the tax to persevere with their representations to him?

—I did see reports of a meeting at Mount Magnet. I frankly do not know whether Mr Gutman has made up his mind or not. I would not expect that he has, but I frankly do not know. However, what I do know is that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, has made up his mind. I am afraid I cannot cite the precise date. I think I can deliver to the honourable senator, within half an hour if he wishes it, a cutting from the West Australian newspaper of about April last year in which Mr Howard says: `Yes, well of course gold should be taxed'. I do not know whether Mr Gutman has made up his mind or not, but I do know that Mr Howard has, and he is for applying taxation to gold.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN RUGBY PLAYERS: POSSIBLE VISIT TO SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the Minister to reports that Australian rugby players will again be invited to participate in South Africa. Can the Minister indicate the Australian Government's attitude to any such players going over there?

—The Government is aware of the reports to which Senator Bolkus refers. Even if the players concerned were to be invited as individuals and play in a non-representative capacity, such a visit would clearly be inconsistent with the spirit, if not the letter, of the Gleneagles declaration. The Government would regard itself as bound by the terms of that declaration to discourage any players from accepting such invitations. Any players considering such invitations should realise that to accept would weaken international efforts to bring pressure on South Africa to abandon apartheid through the mechanism of the sporting boycott. The boycott has achieved considerable success in the past and the continuing unrest should serve to convince Australian sportsmen of the need for the pressure to be maintained to assist the process of change in South Africa. The experiences of the rebel Australian cricketers should also serve as a warning to Australian sportsmen that the South African Government will use any sporting visit to that country for its own political ends.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I remind the Minister of the difficulties which faced a former Deputy Prime Minister of this country when he admitted that he had signed a letter which he had not read. I refer the Minister to evidence given yesterday at an Estimates committee meeting and to the admission by the Department of Health that the Minister had signed a letter--
—The first letter was right and the second one was wrong.
—I thank Senator Elstob. The Minister had signed a letter which said, inter alia:

QUESTION.PARA: Indeed, a causal link between smoking and mortality has not been established scientifically.
I remind the Minister that Dr Blewett subsequently wrote another letter, in which he said:
I wish to advise that this letter was sent in error and that neither I nor my Department has any doubt about the clearly established causal association between smoking and lung cancer.

Besides asking the Minister which version is correct, I ask whether Dr Blewett reads his letters before he signs them. Did he read the first letter before he signed it, and, if so, why did he sign it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second version of the letter was the correct version. With the exception of Senator Elstob, Government senators accept that there is a scientifically proved causal relationship between cigarette smoking and increased mortality. I do not know whether my colleague Dr Blewett reads in detail every letter he signs. I should imagine that he reads almost every letter he signs. If he gets anything like the mail some of us get, he may actually delegate to some of his trusted staff the job of checking such letters. He may actually trust some members of his staff to sign those letters. I suppose that what happened in this case, if that is what happened, is that a silly mistake like that got through.

ANSWER.PARA: I remember that as Minister for Social Security I used to receive many thousands of letters a week. I used to have to send out replies to thousands of letters. I actually trusted some members of my staff to check those letters. I was willing, under those circumstances, to sign those letters. They were routine letters. I make no bones about this. I would be surprised if there were not Ministers in previous governments who were in that position. What happened was simply that a letter containing incorrect facts was sent out. That error was detected and a correction was sent out. I would be very surprised if Dr Blewett is the first Minister to whom that has ever happened; I would be very surprised if he is the last Minister to whom that will happen. To compare those circumstances with the circumstances in which a letter was allegedly signed by a previous Deputy Prime Minister is absolute nonsense. It is drawing a very long bow and it shows how desperate Senator Baume is to find decent questions to ask in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. Has the Government moved to establish an Asian studies council, as recommended in the Association of South East Asian Nations report? What functions are envisaged for the council? Will it serve to encourage economics and business students to attain appropriate expertise in Asian languages and culture? Will the Minister consider using bicentennial funds to promote awareness of business opportunities in the ASEAN region-for example, by setting up information stalls-as part of the celebrations in 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform Senator Elstob that the Government is almost at the completion of the process of establishing an Asian studies council. On receipt a couple of months ago of the report of the committee that was set up to review Asian studies in Australia, we very quickly set about adopting one of its major recommendations, which is the development of an Asian studies council. In co-operation with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, I am now working on proposed terms of reference for that council. We are seeking a suitable eminent Australian or a person from an Asian background to chair that council. We are looking for someone who will have the confidence of the Australian and Asian communities.

ANSWER.PARA: We hope that this council will not be just another body full of goodwill but having little outcome. We hope, rather, that it will assist in the development of Asian studies not only at school level but also at tertiary education level, which again, while serving the traditional function that Asian studies have in Australia-that is, exposing young Australians to the cultural, literary and historical development of our Asian neighbours, will go beyond that and will assist tertiary institutions and schools to develop courses which bear a relationship to the economic developments and the trade prospects in the area. One of the findings of the Asian Studies Review Council was that there has been a drop in the number of students undertaking Asian studies in recent years, at school level and at tertiary level. It appeared that one of the reasons for the decline in interest by students was that many of the courses, although of intrinsic interest, did not provide any sort of vocational qualification for young people wanting to work in areas that related to the region.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other problem is the weighting against the teaching of Asian languages.

—Mr President, Senator Hill is interjecting but I cannot hear what he is saying. I know that there is great interest on both sides of the chamber in this matter. Senator Elstob's question has come a little early in the sense that we are on the verge of making a major announcement about the council. When we do, and when we have the wide-ranging terms of reference and the appropriate membership of the council, I will be very happy to put down a statement in this place, so that all senators who are interested, such as Senator Hill, can make a contribution. This ought to be a bipartisan matter. I think we all agree that our relationships in the region must be developed further. Yesterday's greeting of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew was an example of the kind of improved relations that we have with the region. But we all recognise that there are further opportunities for improved economic and other relationships. The education system, via appropriately developed Asian studies, has a really crucial contribution to make. I will conclude my answer at this point. However, I promise the Senate that an opportunity will be given to debate this matter when we have finalised our decisions.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Will the Minister inform the Senate as to the progress of a matter referred to the Inter-State Commission in August last year-namely, the review of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme? Is it not a fact that later matters have received priority while Tasmanian businesses suffer?

—From time to time I am asked a number of questions relating to the freight equalisation scheme in Tasmania. For some reason the Minister for Transport has not kept me fully briefed with respect to the question asked by Senator Newman. I apologise to her. There is absolutely nothing in my brief that indicates that I can advance any answer other than what I have given Senator Watson and other senators in the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education in her capacity as Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Does the Government's rural package make any specific provision for women in rural areas of Australia? Has any money been allocated to address the needs of rural women? Are any special steps being taken under the National Women's Consultative Council consultations to provide for rural women to have their voice heard as part of the national agenda for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is certainly the case that an important element of the rural package that we announced yesterday will deal directly with the needs of rural women and with an improvement in services for rural women. Our decision to include that element in the package has come about because of the very active and effective representations made to govenrment by rural women about their needs. One of the developments in the women's movement that has been quite remarkable in recent years has been the capacity of rural women, disadvantaged as they are by the distance and sometimes by isolation, to get together and organise effective submissions and effective consultations with government. For example, we have recently funded the Country Women's Association to undertake a very widespread survey of the needs of rural women. We look forward very much to the results of that survey because we are confident that it will provide us with a very good database and some very good directions on further development of policies for rural women.

ANSWER.PARA: It is certainly the case that rural women suffer from information problems. Even where there are a range of services of benefit to women in country areas, the women who could benefit from those services are often not well informed about them because of distance and other factors. So part of the program which we announced yesterday will be the granting of $100,000 for projects aimed at improving access by rural women to services.
Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all very well for members of the coalition parties opposite, whose parties have been in government federally for many more years than Labor and who have failed utterly to deliver anything for the needs of rural women, to boo and moan and carry on. Despite the fact that rural women have had many more years of government federally by coalition governments than by Labor governments, they have precious little to show for it. I have had the experience many times in country areas throughout Australia where I have been undertaking consultations with rural women of having rural women saying to me, a Labor Minister in a Labor Government: `This is the first time we have had the opportunity to speak directly to a Minister in government about the needs of rural women'. The $100,000 project money will go to rural women's organisations for projects which they will design and which will give women in their areas better access to information, better access to services and more opportunity to participate in policy-making and the benefits of the policies of our Government which, I conclude, have been already, in three years, more beneficial to women living in country areas of Australia than anything that our conservative predecessors ever managed to achieve.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time on 10 April, Senator Watson asked me a question which was illustrated by some vivid-or livid in his case-figures about spare parts being brought into Australia from overseas and delays in Customs clearances. I undertook to give the honourable senator some further information, and that is as follows. The procedures for clearing goods through Customs were extensively revised during 1985 and by last December were in place in all ports throughout Australia. These provide as a standard that the bulk of goods will be cleared by Customs within four hours of documents being delivered to the Customs houses. However, goods selected for random check and for special audit are cleared within two to three days if no impediments are disclosed during Customs checks.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no distinction amongst goods eligible for these arrangements; that is, there are random checks. However, any importer can represent to senior Customs officials critical problems which he may have, such as maintaining production or meeting maintenance requirements, and special arrangements can be applied to facilitate urgent clearance, if necessary. During 1985 some public servants took industrial action which delayed the clearance of goods through Customs. In addition there were disruptions to computer services, principally at Melbourne Airport, which added to the delays. These were exceptional and were resolved by the end of December. Since that time goods have been clearing within the standards specified.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED RESORT IN THE BLUE MOUNTAINS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I undertook to get an answer to a question from Senator Haines. While I think I gave her a very adequate answer, her appetite for facts is insatiable. I said that I would provide further information in relation to a question which she asked me about a holiday resort in the Blue Mountains.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I expect those sorts of interjections, especially from Senator Boswell after his performance in attempting to interject during a previous answer. Let me say in brief-I can give a more detailed answer in writing-that there have been several environmental inquiries into this proposed development conducted under New South Wales legislation, including a challenge mounted in the State Land and Environment Court. Special legislation was enacted within the State Parliament and assented to on 15 May 1985, with the intent of enabling the development to take place. There has been no inquiry under the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. A legal opinion was sought by the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment from the Attorney-General's Department. There is no legal impediment to the Australian Industry Development Corporation funding this project arising out of Commonwealth legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Haines also asked me, I suppose in my own ministerial capacity, whether there was use of foreign capital by the AIDC in funding this project. The answer to that part of the question is that the AIDC will not be undertaking specific foreign borrowings to finance this project. The general overseas borrowings of the AIDC are detailed in its current annual report. I should repeat the point made in my earlier answer that the decision of the AIDC to fund this project was taken on commercial grounds. The AIDC is not subject to government direction in respect of its decisions.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES MILITARY BASE IN DARWIN

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time today Senator Robertson asked me a question about the status of media reports on the possible use of Darwin as a United States military base. I am able to respond now on behalf of the Minister for Defence as follows: The Minister for Defence understands that the report in question in the United States was a congressional study which was prepared for a committee of the United States Congress. There is no evidence whatever that it reflects the views or policies of the United States Administration. The Government cannot speculate on the options which the United States might consider in the very hypothetical possibility that the Philippines Government might not renew the leases on the United States bases in 1991. I can say, however, on behalf of the Government that the Australian Government does not allow permanent basing or the establishment of foreign military bases on Australian soil in time of peace. There has been no approach from the United States Government on this suggestion.

—As I also foreshadowed, I have an answer to a question put to me yesterday by Senator Archer in my capacity as the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, relating to possible increased powers for the National Crime Authority. The answer is as follows: Yes, the Government will empower the National Crime Authority to intercept telephone conversations under similar controls as those which apply to the Australian Federal Police. Following consultations with the States, the Commonwealth is also now finalising legislation to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to extend intercept powers to State police as well as the National Crime Authority, subject to the conditions which I mentioned earlier today in my answer to Senator Reynolds on behalf of the Attorney-General. Both the National Crime Authority and the AFP are presently empowered under general search warrant provisions to open mail suspected of carrying illicit drugs. Nonetheless, the Government proposes to strengthen this area by creating a new offence of sending illicit drugs through the mail, with the AFP, NCA and State police being empowered to examine suspect mail.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to a question put to me yesterday by Senator Hill in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, relating to travel warnings to Australian citizens. I undertook to seek further information from the Department as to the usual practice in relation to the issuing of such warnings. I am able to advise as follows--
—Sensitive diplomatic decisions.

—As I said yesterday, there are a number of sensitive diplomatic considerations as well as practical ones governing the issue of travel warnings. For fairly obvious reasons the Government cannot put itself in the position of officially predicting major civil disorder or military action in a particular country before it actually occurs. The Government is not in any event in a position to direct Australians to travel or not to travel overseas. The issue of a travel warning is made only when it is evident that the safety of Australians in the country concerned would be in serious jeopardy.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in response to Senator Aulich's question following yesterday's events in Libya, the Department of Foreign Affairs issued a news release later that day, which stated that, as a result of the current situation in Libya, Australian citizens contemplating travel to that country are advised to consider doing so only if it is essential. In situations such as this the Department affords appropriate assistance to all Australians who might be involved in any manner. Again, as I said earlier in Question Time, the Department has been in close contact with the Federal Republic of Germany, which represents Australia in Libya, and has not received any reports of Australians who have been injured in the attack. There has been no confirmed report about the movement of expatriate employees to military camps. I believe the Department's action in emergency situations overseas is effective and that it is known and appreciated by those who have received advice and assistance.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The crisis facing Australia's sick and injured in need of hospital care.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a crisis facing Australia's sick and injured in relation to the availability of hospital care. It is a crisis which did not exist three years ago and it is, among other things, one product of Medicare and the Medicare system. When I am ill, when members of my family are ill, when my children were young, if they were ill, we wanted care to be available for ourselves and for them when it was needed. When they needed hospital care, I wanted hospital care to be available, and it was available then. When hospital care is needed to deal with an emergency, to correct some painful or debilitating condition, to determine a diagnosis, to institute treatment, to begin the rehabilitation of some disability-whatever the need-we want hospitals to be available when the need is there and when we are in need. That is a reasonable request for any citizen of this country. Every Australian wants to know that he or she can look to care when it is needed. Today they cannot do that. Today they cannot be secure. They cannot be certain.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not worried today in this discussion about ideology or about the funding mechanisms for health care. We are concerned about whether we can get access to care and to service today. This is not available in Australia today. Politicians use the word `crisis' too freely. Sometimes it is justified; sometimes it is not. I think the events in Libya yesterday deserve the word `crisis'. But I also believe, sadly, that the situation facing our hospitals today is a crisis for all Australians. The crisis is due to increased rights of access to the public hospitals which were granted by the Medicare system.

We were all promised that we would have a right of access to a bed in a public hospital once we paid our Medicare levy. The crisis is due also to a vastly reduced capacity of that same hospital system to respond not only to the increased need which Medicare has given, but also the existing need. The crisis is due in part to large scale closures of hospital beds. The crisis is due in part to large and unprecedented resignations of the staffs of public hospitals which cannot stomach any more and are getting out. The crisis is due in part to new and artificial limitations on the services which hospitals have omitted to offer. I refer to things such as the restriction of operating lists, the refusal to let people schedule operations or tests even though members of the community require them. The crisis is due in part, even in our repatriation hospitals, to the closures of beds and to the turning away of repatriation beneficiaries who are entitled to care. The crisis is due, finally, to a refusal by State governments to allow the proper development of alternative hospitals, private hospitals, to take up the need unmet by the public hospital system.

All of this has happened under a Federal Labor Government which has introduced Medicare and, in so doing, promised to every Australian a right of entry to a standard bed at no cost above the levy, as part of their entitlement under the Medicare scheme. It has occurred under a Labor Government which has failed to provide the enormous extra resources which are essential to make that Medicare promise a reality. It has happened while we have had Labor governments in the States which cover about 80 per cent of Australians-the four mainland States under Labor care.

Available figures confirm the truth of what I am saying: Hospital care for Australians is no longer available in adequate amounts. Figures released monthly show ever increasing waiting lists for admission to public hospitals in Victoria. In Victoria, in which the Labor Government is now in its second term, recent figures show that 27,900 people were on public hospital waiting lists at the beginning of January. The situation is worse now that we have reached the month of April. So 27,900 people may have been waiting for an operation on a prostrate, the replacement of a hip or the removal of a cataract. Each of those conditions is disabling and each of them is fixable and curable. But those people have to wait. The waiting lists are worse now than they were in January. In my State of New South Wales we know that more than 30,000 people are awaiting admission for the same kinds of conditions, and an examination of the situation in other States will show that exactly the same thing is occurring. Let me say here that the people do not seek admission to hospital for fun. It is not something to do if one has a spare day. People do so because they are in need. They do so because they are in danger, at risk, in pain or because they are disabled. Those are the reasons that people need and seek hospital care. The expectation of Australians is that they will be able to redeem the promises made so freely by Labor governments when they introduced Medicare. Those promises clearly cannot now be delivered.

Many people wonder why the waiting lists have increased. Previously our public hospitals served a particular population of people-many of them elderly, many of them pensioners-who were able to be admitted to hospitals fairly quickly. They now have to share the number of available beds in the public hospitals with many others who have gained new rights to those beds since Medicare was introduced. They find that they have less of everything-less beds, less resources, less operating time and less staff. It is the elderly client, the pensioners, those who are dependent upon the public hospital system, who now find that they are infinitely worse off, and it is they who make up a large part of the waiting lists.

In the past three years we have seen several things. First, we have seen a mass exodus of trained nurses from the hospitals in which they trained and the profession which they love. The governments which are responsible for hospital care, and the hospitals themselves, have proved quite incapable of attracting the nurses back. So we have hospitals with fewer nurses than they have ever had, at a time when the need for their skills is greater than it has ever been. The nurses are saying that they are unwilling to be part of the system. They are unwilling to be part of the second rate system of delivery which has been imposed upon them. They are unwilling to be part of a system for which they were trained and to which they have devoted their lives. I did not think I would ever see this happen. It is not an ideological matter on the part of the nurses of Australia. It is not that they are abandoning the hospitals because they do not vote Labor or because they do vote Labor. It represents despair and disillusionment on the part of the nurses. It is so deep and bitter that they are leaving the profession. They are leaving the hospitals which they served in crisis at a time of crisis because they cannot stomach any more. That is the first big factor.

The second factor that has led to a great rundown in our hospitals has been a divisive, destructive and unnecessary confrontation with the doctors who provide the professional services in the hospital system. That was so bitter that the doctors did something unprecedented-they withdrew their services. They placed their own careers in jeopardy. They acted to withdraw from the professional activities that are their lives because they knew that Australians were being cheated, that the system was disintegrating and that Australians were getting and would get less care. I will demonstrate this with examples in a little while. They acted because the crisis was so great that they felt they could do nothing else. It is a matter of history now that many of the doctors' main demands were met by the Government, which finally had to listen and give in.

The third factor which is affecting our hospital system is the situation in public hospitals-the hospitals to which we wish to go to exercise our rights under Medicare, rights which were promised to us. These hospitals should be increasing their resources, increasing beds and increasing access to them in order to make good the redemption of Labor's promise of Medicare beds for all. These hospitals should be delivering on the promise of Medicare. But the public hospitals of Australia are under the tightest budgetary control ever, with diminished budgets in real terms, real reductions in their operating budgets when they should be increasing them, and real reduction in the services which they can deliver when they should be increasing those. They are cutting operating lists and operating times when more Australians than ever before are waiting for services. The great public hospitals of Australia are closing beds at a time when more beds are needed.

Let me give an example. There is a heartbreaking shortage of neo-natal beds in New South Wales-that is, emergency beds for the care of new born children, little infants. In New South Wales the authorities have closed 14 of the State's 51 specialised neo-natal beds-about a quarter of them have been closed. Infants are being airlifted from New South Wales to Victoria for care. Of course Victoria is also experiencing the same squeeze on beds. One great obstetrics hospital in Sydney, King George V Hospital, has turned away as many as 100 referrals of infants in need of care, 100 babies needing emergency or specialised assistance. That is just one example of what is going on in the hospital system at present.

I will give another example. I refer to the great Sydney teaching hospital, the Royal North Shore Hospital, at which the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) and I trained as doctors. It is one of Australia's great hospitals. It had about 965 beds before Medicare was introduced. Those beds provided services for a vast population-perhaps one million people overall. The hospital has been forced to close 100 of those beds as a result of Labor's budget rationalisations. One hundred beds have been taken out of the system at a time when more beds are needed. Another 100 beds have been closed as a result of the shortage of nursing staff because the nurses are voting with their feet and leaving the system. It is true that a few of those beds were regained after Sydney Hospital and the Mater Hospital were closed; but, in fact, the number of beds available for the care of people in my part of Sydney has been diminished in a major way by government fiat and government incompetence.

Let us consider the position in the repatriation system. At the Repatriation General Hospital in Heidelberg there were 504 beds on establishment. Of these, 133 are closed because the Department of Veterans' Affairs cannot get nurses to work for it under the Commonwealth award. Thus, there are 370 beds open; nevertheless, up to 50 veterans a week, including 20 who we are advised would fall into the category of those in severe need or requiring essential rather than elective surgery, are being turned away from Heidelberg Hospital because its beds are not open, it cannot get nurses to enable it to operate and the Government under which it works cannot provide the required resources.

Here in Canberra the Woden Valley Hospital lost 50 beds between June 1985 and March 1986. That represents about 15 per cent of the total number. The Royal Canberra Hospital lost almost 60 beds between last November and March this year. In a four-month period 60 beds out of a total of 438 were taken away. It is clear that the community is worse off. The waiting lists are increasing and the numbers of beds are being reduced. Of course there is a crisis and of course people are worse off.

Let me illustrate the extent of the crisis for individual patients with some real examples of Australians who are disadvantaged. First, let me refer to Dr David Johnson, a contemporary of mine. He is a well-trained staff cardiac surgeon. He is not a money grubber. He has gone public to set out the problems. His patients have been unable to get beds so that he can operate on them. Yet Medicare promised that everyone would be entitled to a bed when one was needed. Dr David Johnson's patients needed surgery, many of them for coronary and artery diseases, and three of his patients have died while they were awaiting surgery. After the decision was taken that they needed an operation and before they could receive it, they died. They probably died unnecessarily, needlessly, pointlessly. I ask honourable senators to imagine that those patients were not just disembodied statistics but were their mothers or fathers, or even themselves, in need of cardiac surgery for coronary or artery disease, waiting for an operation and facing the prospect of dying because they could not get a bed in a public hospital and they did not have the resources to seek a bed elsewhere. The result is that patients are waiting and waiting and waiting, even when their conditions are urgent, disabling or serious.

I refer honourable senators to information that we have had from the Australian Capital Territory. Dr Edward Fleming wrote to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and that letter was provided to me by my colleague Senator Lewis. He describes a number of patients who cannot get beds in Canberra. I will not mention their names; I will use just their initials. Mr S. has an obstructed hernia-and he cannot get a bed! What kind of country is this? Mr A. has a total obstruction of the oesophagus. He cannot swallow anything. But no bed can be found for him inside the hospital system. What kind of country is that? Mrs E. has bilateral cancer of the breast and no bed is available to enable her to be operated on. There are two other patients who have cancer of the breast. It could be my wife or my mother. It is a matter of grave importance that in a country such as Australia we cannot provide resources under the promise of Medicare. There is another patient who has obstructive jaundice and an inflamed gall bladder and three others who have strictures of the oesophagus so that they cannot swallow. These are some practical examples of the restrictions on admission to hospital beds and some of the hardship that this means for Australians.

Not only does the Opposition support a fair go and a fair and good health system for all Australians, not only do we support the provision of hospital facilities to meet all our needs for hospital care, not only do we look to the provision of enough operating and efficient services to redeem Labor's promises made so freely under Medicare; we go further; we demand these things. Because it is clear that the hospital services in Australia are falling apart today, because it is clear that beds are being closed and nurses are leaving the system in droves and will not come back, because governments are reducing the money available to the services, because we see a magnificent hospital system in disarray and despair, we demand that the Labor Government, which gave us Medicare, whether we wanted it or not, should now give us the services that it promised would come with Medicare. Those promises included the right to admission to a standard ward bed whenever a person was sick; none of this business of a person with cancer of the breast or someone with a constricted oesophagus being unable to get a bed. When we need beds we should be able to get them. The Government should provide these things, whether it wishes to avoid doing so or not. The Government should do it because what is happening is unfair to all Australians. It is not good enough and we demand that the Federal and State Labor governments fix the crisis which they, alone and clumsily, have laid upon us all. The only justification for Medicare in the end is if we citizens of Australia get better services and better access to services as a result of the introduction of Medicare. That is what Medicare was supposed to be about. Of course, the situation is worse, not better. There are fewer beds, less resources and less care, and the situation is getting worse still.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we predicted.

—As we predicted. This crisis is real and immediate and one which the Labor Government must fix as a matter of urgency and honour. It is necessary for me to say, sadly, that we have no confidence that it will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been spared that sort of speech from Senator Peter Baume for some time and I had thought that maybe we would be spared it for a while longer, but it looks as though the Opposition, as usual, has run out of things to bring up, so we have had to listen to the emotional nonsense that we have just heard. I remind Senator Lewis and Senator Peter Baume that for the seven years of the previous Government I was the Opposition spokesman on health in this place. For each of those seven years I stood up--
—You made the same speech.

—Every year I made the same speech-Senator Withers is right-because every year we debated legislation introduced into this place, frequently by Senator Peter Baume, to have yet another health scheme in this country. We had seven. Every year I finished my speech with the same words: `We will be back again next year because this will not work'. We were back again next year because none of those schemes worked. People used to say `I feel another health scheme coming on'. None of them worked because the former Government did not know how to make them work, yet Senator Peter Baume has been preaching to us.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disappointed with the last five minutes of Senator Peter Baume's speech, because he said something I have not heard him say before and which I did not expect to hear him say in this place. I can get up and say: `I know two people who died in recent times while waiting for cardiac surgery and waiting for a bed in one of Sydney's leading private hospitals'. Am I entitled to get up and say, therefore, that the private hospital system is crook because that happened to those people, who had conditions from which one may die at any moment? This is absolute nonsense. If I got up and made a statement like that, Senator Peter Baume would laugh at me, but it happens to be true-I do know two people who died while waiting for cardiac surgery, waiting for beds in private hospitals, as people will always wait for beds in public hospitals and private hospitals. Dr David Johnson did not say that those people would not have died if those beds were available. He was asked that specific question and he did not say that. He was not a contemporary of Senator Peter Baume at university; he was a contemporary of mine at university-he was in my year at university-so Senator Baume was wrong there. Senator Peter Baume has done what so many Opposition and conservative politicians do in this place. They come in and say that we have problems in our hospital system and in our health system, which we have, and they are all due to the Federal and State Labor governments; that none of the problems existed before the Labor Government came to power three years ago. That is hogwash and Senator Baume knows that it is hogwash.

We have had an increasing shortage of nurses in this country for the past 10 years and we are now suffering from that increasing shortage of nurses. The previous Government, the Fraser Government, did two things to aggravate that shortage of nurses. Firstly, it cut funds to the States for hospitals year after year. The Federal governments, both Labor and Liberal-I remind Senator Baume that nowhere is the shortage of nurses worse than in my State of Tasmania, which has a Liberal Government in its second term of office-cut funds to the States, and the State governments had to cut the available funds to hospitals. Funds were cut in, amongst other areas, nurse training and recruitment, and we are suffering the end result of that.

The second thing from which we are suffering is that for the past 10 years or more there has been a rebellion amongst the nursing community, who have not been willing to continue to accept what they consider to be second-class conditions; conditions of pay and work which are not comparable with those of their peers in the community. Therefore, they leave the nursing profession and get other work. It is ludicrous, as I have said in this place and other places, that nurses working in highly stressful situations, for instance, in intensive care or post-cardiac surgery care, receive lower wages and worse conditions than someone such as a legal secretary. No wonder nurses leave, are burnt out and do not continue in that profession.

This Government decided to do something about that situation by, firstly, talking to the nurses about the training they receive. They claimed, reports claimed and we claimed that one of the ways to overcome this difficulty is to provide nurses with adequate college-based training which nurses receive in most countries, and we are doing that. We are trying to assist nurses, as we have in the Australian Capital Territory, by improving their conditions, but we cannot reverse a process which has been going on as long as this one has. This bleeding from the hospitals of qualified nurses into other professions and areas has been occurring for the past seven to 10 years. It is not a phenomenon which has arisen just since the onset of Medicare.

The problem is that as long as we in this country treat medicine and medical care in the health system in the way in which Senator Baume has treated it, by saying in this debate `You are in government, all the fault is yours; we are not in government, none of the fault can be ours' we will never get anywhere. I have said that before in this place when I was in opposition, and I say it again now that I am in the Government. There are lots of multifaceted problems in the health system and we should have a debate about those problems.

Senator Baume's first statement was that the basic problem in our hospitals is due to `the increased rights of access to public hospitals by the Medicare scheme'. Senator Baume said that that has resulted in people deserting the private hospital system and flooding the public hospitals. Therefore, in the words of Senator Lewis by interjection, we have apparently ruined the private hospital system and overloaded the public hosptial system. That is not so and Senator Baume knows that it is not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—The honourable senator should read what he said. I quote the exact words of Senator Baume when he said that the reason for the breakdown in the hospital system was `the increased rights of access to public hospitals by the Medicare scheme'. Senator Lewis backed that up by saying that we had provoked the collapse of the private hospital system.

SPEECH.PARA: The continued claim that Medicare is responsible for the long waiting lists in public hospitals is made to justify the attempted undermining of Medicare by Opposition members, but it is not a claim which is made by any State government department, nor even by the conservative State Ministers for Health. In fact, at the recent meeting of State Health Ministers, not one Minister made the claim that Medicare was responsible for the waiting lists in their systems. Several of them placed on the record that Medicare was not responsible. Victoria and some other States, including my own State of Tasmania, have analysed why the waiting lists are as long as they are and what the problem is. As Senator Peter Baume has correctly said, the main reason for the increase in waiting lists is not because of increased demand but because of a very real decrease in productivity in hospitals, by bed closures, and in particular by staff and nursing shortages to which Senator Baume rightly pointed. But those nursing shortages have been developing for many years.

Some States, such as Victoria, have developed a comprehensive plan to overcome this problem. They look at the whole problem and say: `We cannot solve this problem just by throwing money at it. We look, first of all, at nursing shortages, and we introduce constructive strategies to overcome the very real dissatisfaction of nurses with the system, to overcome the very real difficulties as nurses see them. We develop clinically acceptable, and what might be called socially acceptable, waiting times, in consultation with the profession'. I can remember as a member of the medical profession more than 12 years ago that we had waiting lists for people wanting varicose vein surgery of well over a year, sometimes up to two years. We had waiting lists for tonsillectomies, for those who were unwise enough to want them, of a couple of years. We had waiting lists for all sorts of elective surgery of that period back in the 1960s. In fact, that was one of the reasons why a previous Liberal Prime Minister, Mr Gorton, looked to start an inquiry into the health and health insurance system.

We must move to get long stay patients out of some of the public hospital beds which they occupy. We can do that by two methods. The first is by making sure that those in nursing homes, which is my area of responsibility, are in fact people who are really in need of nursing home care, therefore making way for long stay people in acute beds. In Victoria some long stay patients have been moved to private hospitals. We can increase domiciliary care to enable the convalescence of people at home-which has been done in so many countries overseas-thus avoiding the unnecessarily long stay in hospitals for people who have non-urgent surgery. We can increase day surgery, which is more appropriate, cheaper and quicker, and which will remove pressure from in-patient facilities. We can look at and attempt to do all those things. I believe, and the Commonwealth believes, that this is a professional and constructive approach to the problems which everybody recognises. The Commonwealth also recognises that the primary responsibility for hospitals, particularly the day-to-day administration of hospitals, is, in fact, a State government responsibility.

Of course the Commonwealth has a clear financial commitment, and we have upheld that commitment. We have increased funding of the States for public hospitals by twice as much as we had under the Fraser Government. But the problems will not be solved by just pouring money in in this way. The Royal Australian Nursing Federation has also publicly expressed the view that the waiting lists are not, in fact, due to the Medicare system. It has consistently stated that and pointed that out. At its recent annual conference it made further mention of this and again pointed out that the problems went far beyond just the problems of Medicare.

Senator Lewis should know-Senator Peter Baume does know-that the evidence does not support the view that people moving from the private hospital sector to the public hospital sector for treatment is the cause of our hospital waiting lists and our bed shortages. In 1983 the private hospitals in this country had an overall occupancy rate of about 60.9 per cent. In 1985 the occupancy rate had increased to 61.2 per cent. How there can be an increase in private hospital bed occupancy and somehow at the same time, as Senator Lewis claims, have a bleeding of people away from the private hospitals into the public hospitals is beyond me. Currently there are many applications on hand for additional private hospital beds. Since the introduction of Medicare there have been applications for 28 new private hospitals and extensions to 46 hospitals involving over 3,500 beds-hardly a picture of an industry in decline. The private hospitals are currently selling for $150,000 per bed-a record price. It is not a picture of an industry in decline. Recently a public company was floated to purchase private hospitals and the share issue was over-subscribed in the few minutes after being floated by about $40m-hardly a picture of an industry in decline, of an industry being bled by people moving from private hospitals into public hospitals. It is the repetition of that sort of nonsense, that sort of ideological claptrap, that Senator Lewis goes on with in this place, which clouds the debate in this place. In fact, there has been no mass exodus from private hospitals to public hospitals as a result of Medicare. We have a mixed system, public and private, and we will continue to have a mixed system.

Senator Peter Baume attempts, in an unfortunate way, to paint those doctors who conducted a dispute in New South Wales in the last couple of years as martyrs, as a group of people who were in fact struggling to maintain our public hospital system and who resigned only as a result of their frustrations with the system. Most of the people who resigned and who stayed out belong to one group of surgeons in particular-the orthopaedic surgeons. They were the leaders in this dispute. I suppose that they exemplify one of the problems we face in this community in that in some areas of medicine, in the technological areas such as orthopaedic surgery, but particularly cardiac surgery, in recent times there has been great development in new techniques, for the benefit of us all-including me-in the capacity of the profession to perform surgery which was impossible in years past, and in its capacity to expand in this area at a rate that no one would have predicted even 10 years ago. That applies particularly in orthopaedics.

In orthopaedics we have also had the biggest closed shop that exists in any profession in this country-the most restrictive closed shop anywhere. The people who are the political leaders of the orthopaedic profession, the wealthiest members of the orthopaedic profession, are also the people who control the training of orthopaedic surgeons in this country, who limit the training and who vigorously limit entries to that profession, despite expanding opportunities recently, and who particularly, I might add for Senator Giles and Senator Haines, limit the entry of females into that profession. I do not believe that they can continue to do so. I do not believe that any government can allow them to continue to do so. I do not think we can allow them to hold this country and the patients of this country, particularly the patients in New South Wales, to ransom in the way that they did last year.

There are many other contributory factors to the difficulties that Senator Peter Baume pointed out. I am not running away from the fact that there are those difficulties. There has been the extraordinary expansion of technological methods of diagnosis and investigation-everything from computerised axial tomogram scanners and their successors, to new nuclear medicine techniques, to new bio-chemical techniques. Instead of having those techniques introduced in a sensible and planned way, on a basis of need, the previous Government allowed the untrammelled introduction of, for instance CAT scanners, to be used and abused under the previous health care system-not under the Medicare system-so that, in fact, we had the ludicrous situation at one stage of a group of general practitioners in Sydney having a CAT scanner for the pure purpose of raising money, not for any benefit of their patients. That sort of untrammelled use of new technology is being questioned and restricted closely in the United States of America, the home of free enterprise. It is something which is violently resisted by the medical entrepreneurs in this country; but it is also something about which, I must admit, I have heard Senator Peter Baume express concern in this place at other times.

In the short time that is available to us to debate this matter we cannot get up here and give long expositions on some of the things we think are important in the health profession. I think some honourable senators who will follow me will mention some of the things that should be mentioned. One thing which Senator Peter Baume did not mention and which I am sure following speakers will mention is the fact that good health and the efficient use of health resources in this country rely on not only the provision of medicines but also the introduction of good public health measures, which is a particular concern of Senator Crowley, and good industrial health measures, which is a particular concern of both Senator Crowley and Senator Giles, and also on the general preventive health care, which I understand is of considerable interest to Senator Haines.

In the one minute I have left in which to speak I cannot talk of these matters or of the necessity for any other mechanisms of this type. All I wish to say finally is this: We have difficulties with the delivery of health care in this country, and we have always had them. We have had them since the late 1950s and early 1960s when Sir John Gorton, the then Prime Minister, recognised that. We will not solve them just by blaming members of one political party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the matter of public importance proposed by Senator Peter Baume in regard to the crisis facing Australia's sick and injured in need of hospital care. I do not think that there is a great deal of dispute about the fact that there is a problem reaching crisis proportions in this area. What has caused the crisis and what has caused the problem is, it would appear from the debate today, in dispute. Certainly, how we fix the problem appears to be in dispute. One side of this debate appears to be arguing that the abandonment of Medicare in itself will solve the problems, presumably on grounds that the introduction of Medicare alone has caused problems. That argument seems to overlook the fact that waiting lists are not new in this country as far as the public hospital sector is concerned. Certainly they existed under the previous Liberal Government. Indeed, looking back over newspaper reports about the problems facing the sick and injured who do not have access to a hospital bed it is interesting to see the change in attitude along the way.

SPEECH.PARA: If we go back a few years to 1978-79 and look at what happened in Victoria-by the way, it is Victoria now which has one of the highest waiting lists-we can see that Victoria had one of the highest waiting lists then. When the then shadow Minister for Health in that State was complaining about this-the man who, after the accession of the Cain Government, became the Minister for Health for a while-he was arguing that it was a problem for these people and that the then Liberal Government in Victoria ought to do something about the more than 8,000 Victorians who were then waiting for admission to public hospitals for operations. What did the Opposition's spokesperson at that time say? He said some rather extraordinary things. In fact, Mr Houghton rejected the claims made by Mr Roper that the present waiting list of about 8,000 pointed to what he had previously called a deplorable lack of proper hospital facilities. He argued that the waiting list was no cause for concern at all. In fact, he asked what was significant about it and then went on to make this rather extraordinary statement:
If we had no waiting list there would be a glut of hospital beds and people would be paying $140 to $150 a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good grief, there is a hell of a difference between 8,000 and 28,000 on a waiting list.
—Is Senator Lewis agreeing then that 8,000 is acceptable, but more than that, not counting population increases and so on, is a real problem?
—There has to be some moderate waiting list but you say that 28,000 people and over 12 months is reasonable.

—I did not say that any waiting list in Victoria or anywhere else was reasonable. The point I was making is that it seems to be a political attitude that is affecting some honourable senators in this chamber with regard to that.
—Why do you always attack us?

—I ask Senator Lewis to give me a moment to explain what is causing these problems. They are not entirely political. Had Senator Lewis waited for 30 seconds before going off his head he would have heard me say that there is no doubt at all that the extension of public hospital treatment to people other than those traditional recipients of it-that is, pensioners, beneficiaries and people who are in need of major surgical intervention-who want it and are prepared to take it under Medicare is a major problem. It is probably one of the major problems causing the long waiting lists. I am not going to argue about that. In fact, I recall pointing it out in letters to pensioner organisations which were writing to me in 1983 saying: `Keep your fingers off Medicare because it is going to be beneficial to the country'. When I said to them that their waiting lists would extend and that they would run into problems, they dismissed that as a figment of an overfanciful imagination.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us make no mistake, there is no doubt that the introduction of Medicare in that regard has caused problems relating to waiting lists. It will continue to do so until some action is taken in regard to things such as gap insurance which will encourage people to take out additional insurance and to make use of the increasing number of private hospital beds which not only are available but also are in use.

In addition to those problems are the sorts of staff shortages already mentioned. I mentioned also the problems of bed, and, for that matter, whole ward closures, resignations, which Senator Baume mentioned, and, of course, the particular problem facing the nursing profession in an increasing number in this country over the last few years. I for one do not blame them for taking the sorts of actions that they have. For decades nurses have been the recipients of low salaries, massive responsibilities, extraordinarily long working hours and a very low status in comparison to other medical profession colleagues. This is an undeservedly low status. In fact, in many ways they have been treated as lackies and not given the due salary and esteem, in other than the eyes of patients, that they have deserved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad to hear Senator Lewis say `Hear, hear!' because it is a problem which should have been corrected many years ago and which has not been helped by a recent court decision that rejected the whole concept of the value of the work done by nurses as far as salaries are concerned. People such as nurses and speech therapists in largely female dominated professions have faced these sorts of problems for far too long. As I said, I for one do not blame them at all. Of course, an additional problem that was raised by Senator Grimes relates to the inappropriate use of beds by people who should be better placed in nursing homes or hostels or given some sort of community care which, up to date, has not been available.

SPEECH.PARA: However, just as important as an issue and one which can be attended to without vast amounts of money and one, which if remedied, would in fact save the country money, is the increase in waiting lists in the last decade or so caused by the increasing number of people occupying public hospital beds because of various forms of anti-social and highly preventable behaviour, the sort of behaviour that has caused massive diseases and injuries which are preventable, which are costly to repair or cure and which society seems to accept with a complacency that is staggering.

An increasing percentage of the health care dollar in Australia is going towards mending problems which are preventable and which could and should have been prevented. Many skin cancers, lung cancers, respiratory tract diseases, broken bones and eye injuries due to car crashes and the victim being flung through the windscreen and so on should never have occurred in the first place. The statistics with regard to people who are occupying public hospital beds with those sorts of preventable diseases and injuries are quite extraordinary.

Australian society, and I presume Western society generally, is far too prepared to take the attitude that if people come down with this sort of problem, somebody will fix it up for them and, furthermore, that somebody else will pay for it to be done. Whether it is getting skin cancers from ignoring the advice of the medical profession, pharmacists and others with regard to the amount of exposure one gives to one's skin by lying out in the sun, whether it is alcohol-related accidents, whether it is lung cancer and respiratory diseases caused by smoking, whether it is work accident-related injuries that stem from unsafe working conditions or whether it is heart attacks, various forms of drug dependancy, alcoholism and stress caused by pressures that are applied to people in ordinary life, it does not matter. Those diseases are preventable and they ought to be prevented. Governments at both State and Federal level ought to be doing something to encourage people to take far greater care of themselves and their offspring, for that matter, than they are currently doing. Yet we have a Government which in its most recent drug campaign, while it paid some attention to the problems of legal drugs, has certainly not emphasised that particular problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mostly illegal drugs.
—Right. The emphasis is on illegal drugs. Nobody is arguing that that is not a problem.
—Not in South Australia, Senator. You ought to know better; it's your State.
—Illegal drugs; not a problem in South Australia!
—They are a problem, but they are not a preoccupation.

—They are a problem everywhere; but, if Senator Crowley wants to expand on that when her moment of glory comes, she can go right ahead. Illegal drugs are a problem but the damage done to the human body by the use of legal drugs of one sort or another is massive and the cost to the community is horrendous and is increasing. Yet we have a South Australian Government which is quite happily allowing a grand prix to be sponsored by a brewing company. The juncture of those two things-car racing and alcohol consumption-strikes me as one of the most extraordinary things for any government to allow.
—They pay sales tax on the grog.

—They may well pay sales tax on the grog, as Senator Sheil so eloquently put it, but I suggest that it is hardly enough to make up for the damage to health that the consumption or inhalation of those two particular drugs-alcohol and tobacco-cause.
—It works on a community rating.
—I beg your pardon, Senator.
—Order! Senator Haines, it would assist if you would direct your remarks through the Chair.

—It would assist us if the honourable senator behind me refrained from inane comments. Of course nobody is going to shoot people who get sick. The point is to encourage people not to require the treatment, not to do the things that abuse their bodies and which require the treatment in the first place. There is no doubt that health care in Australia is in an unsatisfactory state for a large number of reasons and one of them is that the emphasis in this country, as in many other Western countries, is on cure rather than prevention. Prevention is a whole lot cheaper to put into effect than curing a problem once it has arisen.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only does society get given the good housekeeping seal of approval for abusing itself through advertisements, even members of the medical profession are not particularly geared, because of the sort of education they receive at the moment, to treating problems before they become serious ones. Stress related illnesses are still beyond the coping of large numbers of ordinary general practitioners because they simply have not-it is no fault of their own-been given the sorts of lectures and counselling when going through university that would enable them to recognise and deal with those sorts of problems in ways other than allowing the problem to continue until we finish up with a heart attack or some other result of stress related illnesses. Killer diseases are causing this country an excessive amount of health care expenditure and are at least as much a problem as far as causing waiting lists as the introduction of Medicare, nursing problems and resignations in the medical profession or even the rather unconscionable behaviour of certain doctors in New South Wales last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to remind the Senate that we are not discussing lecturing people about how to avoid illnesses, we are talking about the crisis facing Australia's sick and injured who are in need of hospital care. This matter of public importance was moved by Senator Baume today and, along with other people like myself who supported it, it is now being discussed by the Senate. I think it is something that is of importance to this country. I think any government has to realise that there are two things that worry a person most. First of all, is their hip pocket nerve. We all know that at election time one can quite often lose an election if one does not appeal to people's hip pocket nerves. The other thing that worries them is their health when they are well. When people get ill, they worry about their ills and their health more than anything else, and they do not want those ills attended to in six months time or 12 months time, they want to get into hospital and have them treated in a reasonable amount of time. That is not possible in this country at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: They certainly do not want their treatment delayed because the hospital system of this country just cannot accommodate them. That is becoming increasingly the case, as I will point out in a moment, in this country. Any doctor would know that it is never wise to put off the treatment of any medical case. Rarely does any condition that requires surgery get better with the elapse of time. Mostly it gets worse and, as has already been said, many of the cases of people who are being kept out of hospitals are disabling and in many cases the total health and life of the person concerned is at risk.
