A few years ago this Government decided, in its usual socialist way, to bring in a medical scheme which it said would be all things to all people. A bed when needed was promised. Apart from eating up more and more of the taxpayers' dollars, there seems to be a real concern amongst those doctors whom I come in contact with of the ability-I should say the inability-of the public hospitals to cope with the system that we now have. We have tens of thousands of people needing treatment who are waiting for public hospital beds and at the same time thousands of nurses are leaving their profession due to the bad working conditions that they have to put up with. It is obvious that if thousands of people are waiting for hospital treatment, some of them will be dying prematurely because of the grim queues that are outside the hospital waiting areas. Maybe if people physically had to queue up outside the hospitals we would see just how enormous this crisis is. The word `crisis', as used by Senator Peter Baume earlier, is certainly the word that should be used to describe the situation in this country at the moment.

What has been said in some of the papers around Australia and by some of the medical people within this country? One article I have here is the Australian Health Review, volume 8, No. 4 of 1985. Under the heading `Nursing in the Mid-Eighties-Condition Critical', I will read the abstract because I think it described fairly well the conditions we have in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with every word of it.

—Senator Giles can have a go in a moment, if she would like. I think she really should read some of these things because she obviously does not know as much about them as she professes to, judging from the noise coming from that area. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Nursing in the mid-1980s is in a chronic state of crisis. Inadequate wages, poor working conditions, lack of career opportunity, low morale, disillusionment, and high levels of stress have each contributed to the inability to recruit and retain nurses in the health care system. In the next twelve months decision makers must come to terms with the chronic problems affecting the industry, and speedily introduce radical changes if a major breakdown in the health care system is to be averted.

Those are not my words; this is out of the Australian Health Review. There is an article in the Age of 13 March last year, entitled: `AMA calls for $300m boost to ``save'' teaching hospitals'. It states in relation to all teaching hospitals:
Steady deterioration of equipment and facilities, and a gradual decline of elective surgery in the face of growing patient numbers.
The exasperation of specialist surgeons with `resource constraints' in teaching hospitals `and their subsequent movement to specialist private hospitals'.
That is just part of the article which I think was on page 3 of 13 March. Again, that was a year ago. What happened in that year? Absolutely nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has got worse.
—It certainly has got worse. Later in that year, in September 1985, there was an article in the Sydney Morning Herald headed: `A cool billion needed'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Errol Pickering, the executive director, said there had been chronic under-funding of hospitals in the past 10 years.
Most of the underfunding has been during the Labor Government's period in office. The article continues:
These included large metropolitan teaching hospitals and smaller country hospitals.
The lack of funding had meant that buildings and capital works had been ignored in favour of more pressing clinical needs.
Dr Pickering said:
Patients are often accommodated in hospital wards not much changed since the turn of the century . . .

What is the Government doing about the health situation? As I said a moment ago, not very much. An article in the Australian of 6 January this year is entitled: `Waiting list for surgery tops 50,000 nationwide'. Earlier Senator Grimes said that we were being emotive. If he were one of the 50,000 who wanted to have something taken off his bald head or an artery changed somewhere in his body, would he want to be one of the 50,000 who has to wait, sometimes for months, to get treatment? That is the kind of situation that is now hitting this country. On 19 February there was an article in the Age entitled: `Tight hospital finances mean longer waiting lists, says lobby group'. That is six weeks after the previous article which stated that there are 50,000 waiting nationwide. The Sydney Morning Herald in February carried the heading: `Hospital association warns that staff may not get paid'. Then in the Australian of March this year there was an article entitled: `Baby care in hospitals ``critical'' '. It states:
A crisis point--
the very word used by Senator Peter Baume-
has been reached in NSW and Victorian hospitals because of the severe shortage of neo-natal emergency facilities caused by a lack of skilled nursing staff in public hospitals.

From those few articles-I have many more here-I point out too that the problem is not new and it is getting worse. It is very well described by a doctor in a letter to Dr Blewett on 10 March this year. I will not read all of the letter, but in the last sentence he describes people who could not get into hospital for periods of up to five weeks. He states:

May I submit with respect that the public hospital system in Canberra in particular and Australia in general, so espoused by you, is in disarray, that there is a monumental refusal by you to either acknowledge the fact or attempt to remedy it, and that the system is now so open to corruption that it no longer matters what disease you have to gain admission or treatment-the main requirements are who you are and who is your doctor.

That is a pretty sad state for a health scheme of this country to come down to. I am sure a doctor would not have written a letter of that kind had he not been pretty fed up with the problems we have in this country. We have a sad record of damage to the health scheme that this Government has to own up to, the scheme that it forced upon Australians. We have all heard too of the industrial turmoil of the doctors resigning and putting their jobs at risk. Nurses and others are completely fed up with the system. Public hospital facilities and services are continuing to deteriorate as hospital resources become strained beyond their limits by the increased demands that Medicare has forced upon them. Of course, there has been no increase in funding to compensate for those increased demands. Beds have been closed off due to staff shortages despite the growing list of over 50,000 people waiting for surgery.

Increasing medical benefit costs with incentives such as bulk billing does lead to some overservicing and to overutilisation at an enormous cost to the taxpayers of this country, on top of the very high Medicare levy that they have to pay. So we have side effects to these problems. The medical training of new doctors is at risk because hospitals are unable to provide an appropriate mix of patients because the not-quite-so-urgent patients are shunted to the rear of the queue. Some will never get the surgery that they want. This was said about the hospitals in England. I hoped that it would never be like this in Australia, but it is. It is time that this Government and in fact any government realised that it is now a very serious situation and something has to be done about it. We have also seen the Government increasing the cost of prescription drugs, so it is quite a financial strain on those who are chronically ill to pay for the medicine that they need to take. I have an interest in that matter. I have always proposed that people on long term medication should be able to get sufficient drugs to last them for a long time, the same as somebody who just takes them for a short time.

I could go on, but surely from what we all know, from what we have all read and from what we have all heard said by both sides of the House today, we know that there is a crisis. It was admitted by Senator Grimes. I believe that the situation in this country is a scandal; it is a disgrace. The people of Australia deserve better health care and, as Senator Peter Baume said earlier, they demand better service. People should be able to opt out of Medicare and return to the private sector to take pressure off the public hospitals. They should be able to opt for a private scheme if that is what they want.

I finish as I started by reminding the Government that people worry about their health above all else. When they are ill their families worry about it. Any Government that cannot set up a suitable system I believe places itself at risk. The system we have obviously needs to be changed. Unless it happens the health of the people of Australia will continue to decline and the Government will rightly suffer at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess to a little confusion about the matter of public importance that we are debating today, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The crisis facing Australia's sick and injured in need of hospital care.

What we have heard so far from the Opposition in propounding this particular opinion is not a careful analysis of the needs of Australia's sick and injured or their need for hospital care per se but what seems to be a concerted attack on the public hospital system-full stop. I believe this completely ignores a whole wide range of issues which should be canvassed if we are to have an intelligent discussion upon this very important matter. However, it seems to me that the whole thread of the Opposition's case is not so much a concern about Australia's sick and injured but, in fact, the crisis in its own ranks about its proposition, or range of propositions, which will take the place of Medicare in the future if it regains government and fulfils its promise to dismantle Medicare.

This confusion seems to be evidenced by the fact that two points of view have been placed before us, one from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), which is that Medicare will go, and the other one from the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), who wants, as do some senators who have spoken this afternoon, to allow people to opt out of Medicare. I can understand their confusion. They had all those years in which to try an amazing range of permutations and combinations in relation to health insurance. What did they finish up with? They finished up with a complete and utter mess. And what have we? The present Government introduced a universal medical scheme which, in the very years in which we have had to put it into position, has become the most popular medical scheme that Australia has ever seen. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in answering a question in the House of Representatives, said:
For instance, by getting rid of Medicare he will have left a private health contribution rate for a family of between $25 and $30 a week . . .
Is it any wonder that the majority of Australians say that the system we have now is a good one? The Minister continued:

. . . a 61 per cent satisfaction rate, is the most popular health scheme in the last 10 years. All those opposite have behind them is those five schemes-one scheme every two years. The surveys show that 90 per cent of the Australian people value the service delivered to them through the Medicare offices. So we welcome both the idiotic calculations and the decision to fight the next election on Medicare.

The Minister was assuming that wiser counsel would not prevail in the meantime. We are in obvious agreement on one matter. I would have been happy if it had been the subject of a separate debate. Maybe we could look towards that. I refer to the question of the shortage of nurses, the question of beds being closed as a result of that shortage and the question of what should be done about it. In the seven years of conservative government in this country we saw very little in the way of initiatives to resolve the difficulties of what obviously was going to be a severe shortage of nurses in the 1980s. There was a cutback in nurse training in most States and we could see at the time that this would lead to disaster. However, the powers in those days were obviously not prepared to look ahead to the day when we would be desperate for trained nurses. The responsibilities of the previous Government in that regard should not be forgotten. I refer especially to its rejection of the notion of transferring nurse training to tertiary education and to upgrading nurses' status.

What about the responsibility of governments and private employers for the conditions under which nurses would be encouraged to come back into the work force and to stay in the job which many of them love to do and would leave only regretfully? Of course, we cannot look at this subject by just focusing on the strains that are being put on public hospitals at this stage because we have within our system a consider- able reliance upon beds for private patients in public hospitals as well as the use of private hospitals. Of course, the question of nurse shortage goes to the staffing positions in what can be described as the three tiers involved in the care of patients.

This Government has had the opportunity over the last few months of becoming involved in a really sensible discussion about the conditions under which nurses work. That happened in the Australian Capital Territory towards the end of last year, when the stress on nurses employed by the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority had become absolutely intolerable, and, as a result of some rather painful but ultimately successful negotiations, a package was put together. That package included obvious but unusual conditions of employment for nurses in Australia, such as child care for the children of nurses who wanted to work but who had nowhere else to leave their children at odd hours. It included the capacity for nurses to be employed part time and to work the hours with which they could cope in view of their other responsibilities-bearing in mind that the vast majority of nurses are mature women with households to run.

Perhaps the most progressive of the conditions that were included in this package was an agreement that nurses would be consulted about such things as admission policies, which in the past have resided almost solely in the first instance with administration but which, once again, frequently have been overridden by either visiting or resident medical staff, who in many cases tend to overbook and to completely disregard the capacity of their trained nurses to cope with the work load. In that way strains have been put on nurses, and that has led to the sorts of industrial disruptions that we saw in the Australian Capital Territory last year.

I believe that this package could serve as a model for the rest of Australia. I would like to commend it to State governments and the administrators of private hospitals. They should actually consult their nursing staffs about what conditions would make it easy for them to remain within the work force, and would lead to the sort of work satisfaction that would attract and keep nurses, what would help reduce the tension and stress that have become part and parcel of the nursing profession over the years.

On the question of nurses' wages, to which Senator Haines briefly adverted, a comparable work case was placed before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission just a few weeks ago. That case was thoroughly opposed by the employers, who were completely unprepared to acknowledge the fact that the rates at which nurses were being paid nowhere near reflected the responsibilities, the level of training and the circumstances under which they had to work. I hasten to ensure employers that the comparable work concept is not dead. I hope that it gets a great deal more support when it is raised again.

I would like to refer to another element-a very important element-in the stress that is placed on hospitals. Senator Haines referred to the sorts of illnesses and injuries that are engendered by behavioural factors. The behaviour of our medical profession is not always the most rational. Prevention, of course, is a golden rule. It is one which more and more medical practitioners are learning. However, in the meantime, excessive elective surgery-in many cases this is what is clogging up the system-is something that medical practitioners have not yet learned to monitor, and which the system has not yet learned to deal with.

This is not a problem that is peculiar to Australia. In the United States of America, for example, many health insurance funds have instituted mandatory second opinion requirements for elective surgery, so that if I go to a doctor in the United States who recommends that my appendix be removed or that my child's tonsils be removed, and this is not a lifesaving operation but is something in the opinion of the doctor that could be done at some time in the future, I am then required to consult a second doctor to find out whether in fact the operation is necessary.

We know perfectly well that as medical insurance data becomes more sophisticated and the collection of morbidity statistics becomes more comprehensive, it is possible to detect trends in elective surgery in Australia which in many cases are completely without medical explanation. For example, I refer to a recent study of caesarian sections. Details of the study have recently been published. It was carried out at a large Sydney teaching hospital on 120 women aged 18 to 44 who gave birth for the first time-primipara. Among them, the caesarian section rate was 23 per cent. The survey report makes reference to a study carried out in Dublin in 1980 on 1,000 patients, showing a caesarian section rate of around 5 per cent.

Looking for medical reasons why in 1986 Australian women-young, healthy Australian women-are being delivered by caesarian section is really a task for a detective. Why on earth is this the case? Is it dystocia? Is it disproportion? Are all those women in their late 30s? Are they all tiny Vietnamese women who are married to enormous Australian men and who are having babies that are too large to deliver vaginally? It is absolutely amazing. The stress on the system of caesarian sections as against vaginal deliveries which, in most cases, one suspects might well have come to a successful conclusion is absolutely unexplainable. There is certainly nothing in the figures that would demonstrate a greatly improved infant survival rate-perinatal survival rate-nor is there anything to prove that the maternal survival rate has changed as a result of this greatly escalating rate of caesarian section in Australia today. That point also applies to not all but very many colocecostomies, appendicectomies and tonsilectomies.

I appreciate the fact that thorough studies have not been carried out in Australia to work out which of these operations are essential and which are not, but there is a very strong suspicion that, if the medical profession were to set its mind on co-operating and making certain that the hospital system worked efficiently, we would have nothing like the crisis that the Opposition seems to feel is at this moment, as the Oppo- sition describes it, unprecedented in Australia. In fact, a great deal has been done in the last three years to ensure that in the future the hospital system will be able to cope a great deal better. We hope that the behaviour of the medical professionals and those who are responsible for their working conditions will also greatly improve in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most startling revelation to come out of this debate is the fact that the Government does not seem to think it has a health care crisis on its hands at all. It does not even recognise that there is a problem. I think it is eminently clear from the debate today that we do have a crisis on our hands. Almost the first speech I made in this Parliament was made to a joint sitting of the Houses of Parliament when the Whitlam Government rammed through the Medibank legislation. That was really the starting point of the crisis that exists today. All that has happened has been predicted and was eminently predictable. I could even go back and quote from my speech then. The problems that would be caused to the hospitals, the doctors, the patients and the pharmaceutical industry were all mentioned back in those days.
—Was it bad then, Senator?

—The storm was gathering, but fortunately the Whitlam Government went out of office and the Fraser Government got in. Instead of getting rid of Medibank, as it was then, with the broad sword, the Fraser Government put band-aids all over it and it took a few years to get rid of it. The Fraser Government had only just got rid of Medibank when it lost an election, the Hawke Government came in and Medicare came in. That was bigger and worse than Medibank ever was.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to reiterate for a start that the promise of free health care at the point of delivery is a promise that is incapable of implementation because it creates an unlimited demand for which there is only a limited budget. As the demand goes up and the budget gets spent, the two move away from each other. So we get dissatisfaction amongst patients, hospitals and their staffs, doctors and the pharmaceutical industry-the whole business. It is indicative that if a problem is taken to the Government it will pretty soon convert that problem to a crisis. Government does not hold the solution; government is the problem in these areas. The fact that the Government does not admit that there is a crisis and therefore will not be taking any remedial action to fix up the situation as it exists today is an even more serious aspect of the health care crisis that we have on our hands at the moment.

If we look at the situation at the moment, it is in a shambles because the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has isolated himself from the various sectors of the health industry. He has alienated the public hospitals. They will not talk to him. The private hospitals are in the same boat, as are the doctors. When Mr Hayden was bringing in the Medibank legislation he alienated the doctors to such an extent that he thought if he ever got sick he would have to go to a vet. The current Health Minister is putting himself into the same sort of position. He is isolated now.

I mention waiting lists. The figures that have been quoted today are horrific. Upwards of 70,000 or 100,000 people are on hospital waiting lists. I know there were waiting lists before, but they were much smaller. There will probably always be waiting lists, but the current level of people on waiting lists is horrific and the things that are happening to people who need urgent treatment are horrific too. Some instances have been cited today, with some people on hospital waiting lists actually dying. That is something we were actually trying to avoid in a health care system that, it was said, wanted to be fair, equitable and cheap. I think the operative word is `cheap' because once governments promise unlimited health, they cannot deliver and they start restricting it.

The Medicare side of the Government's health scheme at the moment has exploded, obviously due to the bulk billing system. Now the Government is trying to put a brake on that. Hospital expenditure has exploded. Now the Government is trying to put a brake on that. What that means, in effect, is that it is restricting the services. In other words, it promises everything, but once it realises it cannot deliver, it has to restrict. Once it starts restricting we get dissatisfaction in all sections of the industry. I would say that there is a mounting groundswell of discontent now, particularly amongst the patients. Only about 10 per cent of the people are sick at any one time, so it would take quite a deal of time for all the people to realise that they are being taken for a ride by the health care system. Once they have had experience of the system in Australia, their discontent becomes evident, and it is mounting at the moment.

With regard to the doctors, I do not think we could ever have dreamt at one time that doctors would be withdrawing their services, resigning en masse and going on strike. These actions were put down by the Minister to the fact that we had a closed shop of orthopaedic surgeons who were money hungry-I suppose he was trying to make that out-and did not want to have any competition, but that was not the case at all. The New South Wales doctors' strike was a dreadful occurrence. The Government caved in in the end and had to pay an enormous amount of compensation just to get things back on an even keel in the case of the equipment in the hospitals and teaching facilities, and it had to catch up with the losses that occurred during the dispute.

The pharmaceutical industry is in the same boat. The prices of drugs were kept down to such a low level over many years that the research and development sector of the drug industry in Australia virtually left our shores. It has hardly even come back now. Right at this very moment-it was mentioned in the Senate today-dilantin has lost its government subsidy because the Government is still arguing with the manufacturer over its price. It is an essential drug for many epileptics.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hundred thousand people.

—Three hundred thousand; I thank Senator Baume for that figure. It is an enormously important drug for people but the Government is arguing with the manufacturing firm about its price. Many of the people who are epileptics, of course, are unable to work full time, so they are in an even worse position. Patients have found that with the Government trying to restrict the services to them they and their doctors have been subject to investigations and inquiries-the midnight knock at the door. There has been great disquiet amongst people because of the fishing expeditions that have been conducted to find out whether doctors have been over-servicing; in other words whether they have been costing the system more. Heaven knows, I think it has probably cost the Government more to search than to carry out an ordinary computer analysis. The Government is controlling everything. It has announced that it will tell doctors what pills they will prescribe for what diseases, how many should be prescribed, how many repeats should be issued, under what conditions one can be admitted to hospital and for how long one can stay in hospital. The controls on the whole system are getting more and more intolerable.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disappointed today to hear of the extent of the degradation of the nursing profession, a once noble profession. Everyone loved, respected and looked up to nurses. I can remember stories of the nurses who had to walk through the gardens at Woolloomooloo in Sydney, through all the places where the gangsters used to hang out. No nurse was ever molested. In fact, if anything, the gangsters looked after the nurses better than the police could have done. I am sure that if anyone had touched a nurse, the gangsters would have made sure that the case was taken care of properly. We have a shortage of nurses. There is a shortage in the intake of nurses. Nurses are not completing their training. They are resigning from the system. They are attending mass meetings to complain about stress, their low wages and long hours. It has got out of hand. The shortage of nurses, if considered together with the shortage of beds and the reduction in operating times, adds up to a health care crisis.

Even in Canberra the Government cannot run away from that problem. The Federal Government is entirely responsible for the health care system in Canberra. It pays for it. This afternoon reference has been made to the horrific matter of people on waiting lists who die before they reach the top of the list, and people's inability to have operations. I read recently in the Hansard that serious eye operations for children and adults are not being performed. Heaven knows how many beds in New South Wales have been shut down. I think the figure is over 1,000. In that State there is now a new health plan to organise its health administration into regional areas. I looked at what is proposed and it is almost exactly the same as the group area establishment committees that were set up in Great Britain to help run the national health scheme. They were a remarkable flop. In fact, national health schemes similar to the one that we have in Australia have been tried in countries that are similar to ours, such as Canada, which has Medicare, the United States, which has Medicaid, the veterans' administration, Scandinavia, West Germany and Great Britain. They all have one thing in common: They are all failures. I do not know why we must keep going down that same road. But the group area establishment committees, as I would call them, in New South Wales, will not fix the ingrained problems in that State.

The current budget for health in Australia is $17,000m a year. It is hard to comprehend that sort of a figure. But there is a shortfall of $800m. That is a crisis. Somebody somewhere must go short because of that. The Medicare levy covers about one-fifth of that amount. The future, of course, is even bleaker, especially in the public hospitals in Victoria and New South Wales, because they have recently announced their funding, which is at a level lower than the current consumer price index. But hospital expenditure increases by a far greater amount than the CPI, largely because any equipment which must be bought is purchased overseas and there has been an enormous devaluation of our dollar.

Despite all that has been said this afternoon, the private hospitals are in a bad situation which will become worse, particularly because of the disincentives for people to take out private medical insurance. When one adds to that the sudden and ruthless introduction of categorisation and accreditation that has been applied to private hospitals, they have more or less had their heads put on the chopping block. These are the very hospitals that several Ministers of this current Government have chosen to go to for important treatment. They have bypassed their own public hospitals. I think that shows that they feel they might get a better deal in the private hospitals than at the public hospitals. I hope all of their problems are solved in these private hospitals before they wreck them too. Some have already been forced to close, but others have been forced to pull in their horns, restrict the updating of equipment, services, facilities, and staffing. The Government's previous policy of promising free health care caused a flow of patients from their homes to hostels, to nursing homes, to hospitals. Now there has been a complete reversal and upheaval. The Government wants them to go from the hospitals to the hostels, to the nursing homes and back to their homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the one good thing about my being able to speak is that I am the last speaker and I will not have to listen to any more of the remarkable piffle sponsored by the Opposition. Such is the topic of this matter of public importance that Senator Peter Baume has hedged all his bets and talked about a crisis facing Australia's sick and injured in need of hospital care. Unfortunately, I was not able to be present when Senator Baume spoke, so I did not hear him spell it out. But I was advised by my colleague, the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), that he had nothing special or new to say. There is no doubt that the matter listed, in terms of Australians who are sick or injured and in need of hospital care, is a matter for serious consideration. Any number of ministerial meetings, documents, publicity and so on, indicate that this is a problem of which the Government is aware. But I do not think that by any criteria it could be called a crisis. Certainly I do not believe we should be fooled by the Opposition's claim that it is new. Indeed, Senator Sheil was busy telling us, by way of some kind of a defence, that when he first came here, and I do not know when that was, but it was a long time ago-when was that?
—It was in 1974.

—The crisis was alive and well then. Although we know that the Whitlam Government was extraordinary, I believe that even Senator Sheil must acknowledge that it did not create that problem in just two years. It was something that had been growing.
—It did.

—I am delighted to hear Senator Withers say anything because it proves he is not dead. It did not achieve all of that in two years. In fact, it was not able to get through the Medibank proposal in two years because, after all, we know what the Opposition, as an obstructionist Senate, did in those years. It did not allow the introduction of Medibank so it cannot be held responsible for the disaster. The Government was trying to address the serious problem of providing adequate hospital care for those who needed it in this country. If honourable senators opposite thought it was so terrible, why did they stuff around in the seven years-seven years, good and true-during which they were in government? They introduced five different health systems, not one of which shortened the waiting lists.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give the Senate some hard data, some figures, particularly for the edification of Senator Sheil. In the early 1960s-it was a reality even before he came here-we had waiting lists in public hospitals. It is not a recent phenomenon. In the early 1960s people had to wait 15 months for a varicose vein operation and up to two years for a tonsillectomy, neither of which would have been too major or too urgent, and quite clearly the sort of thing one would expect could be placed on a longer waiting list, rather than be seen as an urgent matter. Senator Townley managed to skate right over anything like a definition of `a reasonable waiting period' and, without having heard him, I presume that Senator Peter Baume would acknowledge that there is a difference between urgent surgery and the needs of patients who must be treated urgently in hospital and those who have a problem that can be treated in a more gentle way or those who seek elective surgery to deal with problems.

This word `crisis' is a grab bag which has given Senator Peter Baume an opportunity to kick the Government. Well, we do not mind, Senator Baume; we will head it off with a pass and send it right back. Essentially he wants to kick the Government about hospitals because of all the things he has tried to attack the Government about, the only thing that seems to get any recognition, in his view-and he is wrong again-is Medicare. So he has gone back to a tired old record of giving the Government a serve on Medicare. I suggest he look at this again and he might see why it is a very silly thing to do. The Opposition has nothing to put in place of Medicare. Opposition members and senators say that Medicare is bad so anything else would have to be better. As I have already said, they had seven years in government with five different schemes, none of which was any better. In fact, none of them enjoyed the support which public polling now shows Medicare enjoys. In fact, Medicare is favoured and supported by 61 per cent of the Australian population and it is the most favoured health care scheme that we have had in 10 years. The Opposition wants to attack Medicare because it has nothing else to put in its place. So it says `If it is health, let us whack Medicare'. This shows how wide of the mark members of the Opposition are because the matter of hospital waiting lists and the crisis-if one wants to call it that; I would rather call it a problem-over hospital care is obviously a State matter. Therefore, the only way in which we can really discuss this in the Senate is by having a whack at Medicare.

There are any number of State Ministers of Health, both Labor and Liberal, who say that Medicare is not responsible for problems in public hospitals and with hospital waiting lists. The Royal Australian Nursing Federation has also made statements to the effect that Medicare is not responsible for waiting list problems in public and private hospitals. In fact, the RANF alludes to the sorts of problems that Senator Peter Baume would have been much better off speaking about instead of giving us a grand old serve in the same old boring way. I am surprised that he even dares to do it because there is a lot of evidence that the Opposition has nothing to put in place of Medicare. Even more than that, the Opposition is divided. For example, take the statements of the shadow Minister for Health. I was delighted to hear Senator Giles say that she could not even recall his name. That is not difficult; he is just a shadow. I think his name is Mr Porter and he comes from South Australia. He was very, very busy rabbiting away in the Estimates Committee last night, feeding questions to Senator Baume so that we could all be enormously edified by his potential for knowledge. Mr Porter goes around the country saying that when he is the Minister for Health the Opposition will allow people to opt out of Medicare. It is just as well he does not run into the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, because Mr Howard is running around the country saying that he will do away with Medicare, that the Opposition will have nothing to do with it.

I do not know why the Opposition continues to put up debate about Medicare when quite clearly it has no policy and it is divided. The Opposition is not even appreciative of the fact that the Australian people appreciate Medicare and the general provision of health services in this country. Perhaps Mr Howard, who said by implication on television recently that he would do away with Medicare altogether and thus save $3.7 billion, is innumerate as well as being a discredited former Treasurer. Perhaps it has never dawned on the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, that the reason Mr Howard was discredited is that he is not very good at numbers, let alone policy. Apparently he does not appreciate that the polling for Mr Howard and his popularity suggests that if Medicare is an issue on which he is running, it is not doing him any good. According to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) in the House of Representatives, if Mr Howard intends to save $3.7 billion by doing away with Medicare, he is wildly wrong. He could not do it. The $3.7 billion includes $1.3 billion raised by the levy. If he does away with Medicare he will do away with $1.3 billion, so he will not get his $3.7 billion that way. Further, he would have to acknowledge that of the $2.4 billion left from Medicare costs, $1 billion goes to medical benefits for pensioners and the disadvantaged. Mr Howard is on record as saying this:

I think the provision of essential welfare is necessary . . . obviously there are some items of welfare that can't be cut, and I have never argued and no sensible person would argue that you should take benefits away from persons who really need them.

That is a quote from Mr Howard. If he really believes that he is not going to take welfare away from those who need it, I presume that he will not take $1 billion from medical benefits for pensioners and the disadvantaged. So he is now down to $1.4 billion out of his potential $3.7 billion that he thought he could save. Also, he has forgotten that he would have to subsidise private insurance. Once Medicare goes we will be back on the previous system and even if one took the figures from 1981 under the Fraser Government and subsidised 30c in every dollar for private health contributions, one would find that Mr Howard had just lost the rest of the money that he intended to save. He would not make any gains at all and he would certainly not win any votes on the platform of kicking Medicare or trying to abolish it.

That is why I am very surprised that Senator Peter Baume is so ill-advised or ignorant that he should take this opportunity to have a whack at the Government about Medicare yet again. It does the Opposition and his Party absolutely no good at all. The public has said that and the public understands it. The public also appreciates something that the Opposition does not-the public is not stupid. It knows that the difficulties about waiting lists in public and private hospitals are complex. It knows that the points raised by speakers on this side-by Senator Grimes and Senator Giles, and to some extent by Senator Haines-are right; that the problem is to do with hospital administration, bed closures and staff shortages.

Senator Haines raised the problem of illnesses caused by lifestyle. I would go further than she did and try to include not only those illnesses or injuries due to personal lifestyle, but also those matters which involve occupational health and safety; in other words, matters outside the individual's responsibility which contribute to ill health. Senator Giles also raised the point that elective surgery increases waiting lists. Also, we have no idea of whether those numbers on waiting lists which people were quoting in this chamber include those cases where people have their names on the lists of more than one hospital. Senator Giles and I both know from the inquiry into private hospitals and nursing homes that many patients in the community put their names on a number of waiting lists for both nursing homes and private hospitals. I would be surprised if that kind of behaviour was not sometimes carried into the waiting lists for elective surgery.

I think we have had quite a number of explanations here showing that the reason for extensive waiting lists in hospitals is not a matter of Medicare difficulty. Surprisingly, in as much as it is a matter for Medicare, it has to do with the small part of Medicare which funds the provision of hospital services through the public system. In the time left to me I would like to draw the Opposition's attention to another piece of monumental illogic. Opposition members keep arguing for the abolition of Medicare so that people can be given a choice. We have had Medicare; we have experienced it and the people in this country like it. When people exercise the choice, under the Medicare provisions, to seek their medical attention and care in public hospitals, suddenly the Opposition says that they cannot do that because it is increasing the waiting lists; they should go into private hospitals. Thus the Opposition argues that people in the community can have a choice as long as they agree with it. That is an insufficient understanding of what choice is really about.

I wish to take this opportunity to comment on a point I made as an interjection in Senator Haines's speech. Apparently I left her with the impression that I was suggesting that so-called illegal or hard drugs were not a problem in South Australia. If that was the impression I gave, I hasten to correct it. I thought that she was alluding to the South Australian Government's response to the drug education program. The emphasis in South Australia has been as much on the lifestyle drugs of alcohol and cigarettes as on the hard drugs. Further to that, we need to look at those drugs which are normally provided by prescription, the so-called standard medical drugs, such as aspirin, Bex and valium, which also contribute to the drug problem in this country. This is particularly so in terms of the cost that is picked up in the hospital system when such people overuse those drugs, after being prescribed them or choosing to use them themselves, and find themselves yet again in a hospital bed. Thus they contribute to the demand on hospital beds that Senator Peter Baume raised today in his matter of public importance.

One other point on which I would like to comment is Senator Townley's extraordinary claim. I would not dare even try to contemplate answering Senator Sheil's claims. He claimed the lot and then negated it all with the next set of claims, so it is beyond me to understand where he stands on anything, except that it was all happening before he got here in 1974, and with that, I must admit, I do not have too much dispute.

The Minister for Health today released the preliminary estimates of health expenditure for 1982-83, 1983-84 and 1984-85. Those estimates, prepared by the new Australian Institute of Health, were based largely on the statistics gathered by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The figures indicate a slowing in the rate of growth of health expenditure during the first full year of Medicare. This goes to the point raised by Senator Townley: The cost of health is growing and growing, blowing out through the roof and impossible to contain, and that is what happens if it is given to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Those humbugs want the cost of compensation to continue to blow out because they are trying to sabotage the Government legislation to contain it.

—Thank you, Senator Walsh. I am not quite sure where that fits into my contribution, but if it means that the Opposition is foolish, I am entirely in concurrence with that view. The Minister for Health said that it was significant to look at those figures because there has been an enormous series of complaints and charges against Medicare in that it does not contain costs. The figures to this point show that it is successful in containing the expenditure on health at a constant between 7.5 and 7.6 per cent of gross domestic product for six years.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a ministerial statement on economic and rural policy and to incorporate the statement in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Previous Liberal-Country Party governments have responded to successive rural recessions with measures of a largely ad hoc nature. Some of these responses have been of assistance to the sector and have become part of the fabric of farm policy. Others have been ineffective for any purpose other than as a placebo or an ideological fix. They have not seriously addressed the problems; they have quickly disappeared as the crisis has passed-as did the beef incentive payment scheme, for example.

The Hawke Government's approach is different. We have analysed the nature of current rural problems very carefully. We have not restricted ourselves to farm policy. We have also looked at economic and industry policies and at policies directed toward non-farm, rural and provincial Australia. My speech today is a summary of the comprehensive analysis of farm and rural policies as set out in the accompanying Government statement on economic and rural policy. We have found cases where our policies should be changed. But the broad thrust of our policies has emerged intact.

Many of us in this House have had experience of previous farm crises. My own experience on a farm goes back to the 1950s and 1960s. Most of us can recall the late 1950s drought, wheat quotas, the wool crisis, the dairy crisis and beef crisis of the 1960s and 1970s and, of course, the 1982-83 drought. In times of crisis in rural and provincial Australia reaction by farmers is at first slow; institutions and governments also are slow to act. But once the seriousness of the situation is realised, and because personal stress brings out basic political attitudes, it is usual for there to be dissent, unrest and exploitation of these attitudes by the opportunists.

Farmers are not whingers; they are gamblers. Farmers are realists; they rarely make extreme demands. Farmers feel they are victimised because they work in some isolation, in a setting where they cannot control the weather, the middlemen, the markets, the unions and the governments.

We now have a situation, quite apart from political attitudes and exploitation, which is termed a so-called rural revolt. However, at the end of the day once the emotion has been expended, once the simple-minded simple solutions have been disproved, once the demagogues have been dismissed, I have always found that it has been necessary to analyse calmly what the problems are, and what can be done, in terms of overall economic and social policy. This statement is about reality, analysis and directions.
The Place of Primary Production in Australian Society

The first reality I want to identify clearly is the place of primary producers in particular, and country dwellers in general, in Australian society and the Australian economy. Some 36 per cent of Australians live and work outside our major capital cities. Some 7 per cent directly depend on the primary industries of agriculture, forestry and fishing for their livelihood. Thirty per cent of all Australia's small businesses are in primary production. Of course, farms and other small businesses are not in the same situation. Farmers compete on world markets, while most other small businesses complete against each other.

Taking into account multiplier relationships, perhaps some 20 per cent of Australians owe their livelihood to primary production either directly or indirectly. With primary production providing some 37 per cent of Australia's exports, the standard of living of all Australians is affected by primary production.

Rural Australia is an integral part of our history, our culture and our environment. No government can ignore this contribution of the rural sector to our society and our economy. This Government does not. What the Hawke Government does-and this is different from our political opponents-is to recognise the true nature of this contribution. The only policies that work are those that contribute to the long term health of the sector in its market environment. Individuals in need are helped effectively only by measures that are properly targeted on those individuals.

Not all country dwellers are farmers, nor do all country dwellers depend on primary production. But all country dwellers do have common problems of access to the range of public and other services that are taken for granted in the cities. It is for this reason that this Government does not confine its rural policies to farmers alone-we are in the business of addressing the problems of all Australians.
Nature of the Current Rural Problem

There can be no doubting the very substantial economic successes that the Hawke Labor Government has achieved. Australia's economic growth is the most rapid in the Western world. Our job creation record has greatly exceeded our targets. Only last week it was recorded that we have now created almost 620,000 new jobs. This outstanding record has reflected a number of factors, not the least being our successes in the areas of wages and fiscal and monetary policy. The fundamental problem is that, by and large, the rural sector has not shared in this economic success.

According to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the real net value of rural production-that is, the Bureau's key indicator of farm income movements-is projected to fall by 21 per cent in 1985-86, with a further 21 per cent fall projected for 1986-87. Average farm cash operating surplus is projected to fall by 25 per cent in 1985-86 to $19,600, after fluctuating from $19,500 in 1982-83, the lowest in recent times, to $27,500 in 1983-84, the highest in recent times. Average farm incomes on family farms-which allows for depreciation-is projected to fall by 66 per cent. This does not, however, include imputed or off-farm income. Rural land prices are falling in some areas in an inevitable response to present lower returns and unrealistically high prices in the past.

The proportion of farms assessed by the BAE as being `at risk', that is, having a negative cash margin and less than 70 per cent equity, is up from 5 per cent in 1984-85 to 7 per cent in 1985-86-12,000 farms. Employment growth in non-metropolitan areas was very close to that recorded in metropolitan areas. However, country areas generally have not experienced the same dramatic falls in unemployment as have the cities. I emphasise that there has still been a fall in the non-metropolitan unemployment rate. The major causes of the poorer country labour market performance have been more rapid population growth and stronger growth in female labour force participation. The gap between country and city female labour force participation rates has narrowed as country women have increasingly sought to take their rightful place in the community.

The broad statistics on farm incomes I have cited so far need to be qualified in two major respects. The first is that there is substantial diversity across commodities, regions and individuals. It is both unreasonable and dishonest to infer that all farmers are in trouble. For example, the projected change in average farm cash operating surplus in 1985-86 ranges from a fall of 52 per cent for wheat and other crops to an increase of 10 per cent for beef farms. Of course, international price movements, seasonal conditions and overseas policies can always confound such estimates. Estimates are estimates.

It is a simple fact that the current and prospective income problems are concentrated in certain commodities, such as wheat, sugar, dairy, rice and horticulture, and in certain areas, such as the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia and the Mallee districts of Victoria and South Australia. As a result, the falls in rural land prices have been by no means universal. Similarly, there has been a great deal of talk of farm debt problems, and this is undoubtedly the heart of the problem for many individuals. Nevertheless, according to BAE estimates for June 1985, some 28 per cent of farmers had no debt and a further 18 per cent of farmers had less than $20,000 debt. This is in contrast to the 12 per cent of farmers, including 25 per cent of wheat farmers, who had more than $150,000 in debt. This diversity shows that no grand fix-it solution can work. The problem needs to be addressed on an individual basis.

The second qualification is that it is entirely wrong to compare the BAE's farm income estimates with estimates of average weekly earnings and so suggest some comparison with wage earners. The two sets of statistics are totally incompatible, as the BAE's farm income statistics make no allowance for either off-farm or imputed income. Whilst the statistics show that there are declining farm incomes, they do not, of themselves, demonstrate an individual welfare problem. This, too, needs to be addressed on a case-by-case basis. Obviously, if the averages are low, there is a welfare problem at the bottom end. Consequently, proper policy settings cannot be directed at simply supplementing all farm incomes. Rather, they need to be directed at solving the underlying problems of primary production, transport, marketing and adjustment. Any special assistance needs to be carefully targeted on individuals.
Causes of the Problem

It is important for all of us, including both producers and governments, clearly to establish the causes of the current problems. The simple fact is that adverse world market trends are the reason for the failure of the farm sector to share fully in Australia's general economic growth. Average export returns for Australia's primary products have increased by only 5 per cent in the two years to 1985-86, despite a currency depreciation of the order of 25 per cent. This implies that average world prices for our exports have fallen by around 20 per cent. Had world prices not fallen, rural incomes would be over 50 per cent higher than is currently projected. Instead of a fall of over 30 per cent in the real net value of rural production over the past two years, we would be looking at an increase of 6 per cent. There is little prospect of immediate improvement. Projections for 1986-87 suggest little increase in world prices.

It is simply not possible, in the face of these figures, to lay all the blame for the problem at the door of the Australian Government. Our overall economic policies cannot be blamed, as the rest of the economy has been doing very well. Tariff and other industry policy measures cannot be blamed. The direction of movements in protection has been generally downwards for some time, particularly through the measures being implemented by this Government. In any case, Australian agriculture adjusted to our historically high levels of protection decades ago.

World prices are the problem. The Government does recognise that the impact of general economic policies can fall unevenly. At a time of low commodity prices, farmers are less able to withstand high interest rates. The problem is not high rural debt levels-the use of debt finance is less in the rural sector than in other sectors-nor is it high interest rates alone. The problem is the conjunction of high interest rates and low returns, exacerbated in some areas by a series of poor seasons.
The `Grand Solutions'

Rural populists have proposed alleged quick cures to these problems, including massive subsidisation of the farm sector. The rationale for these proposals is often the `tariff compensation' argument-that farmers lose from protection for manufacturing industry and so should be compensated. The logic behind this argument is extremely faulty. I repeat that Australian agriculture adjusted to our high protection levels decades ago, and recent movements in protection have been downwards.

The protection of other industries is not the cause of the current problem. It is true that protection imposes a cost on all Australians, including farmers, and that farmers would particularly gain from a reduction in protection. In recognition of this, the Government is reducing protection levels. For instance, our decisions on the car industry are resulting in reductions in effective assistance of an estimated 10 to 15 per cent per year. Any so-called `compensation' during the time it takes for these measures to have their impact would make no economic sense and, in particular, would make no equity sense. People should be assisted according to need.

The final problem with `tariff compensation' is that no-one has yet worked out a form of assistance that would not make other problems worse. For example, we could simply provide massive price support across all commodities. As European and North American experience shows, this simply does not work. Europe's agricultural subsidies have thrown a million people out of work, while the farm problem in the United States is much worse than in Australia, despite massive subsidisation.

It is government cave-in to farmer demonstrations and revolt overseas that has accentuated the problem. In these countries, subsidies represent most, if not all, of the total level of farm income. Subsidies would provide a windfall gain for current producers, but would do nothing to prevent a recurrence of the problems in future as market fluctuations continued. By encouraging over-production, subsidies exacerbate the problems. By encouraging reliance on governmental support they reduce the dynamism and self-reliance that is the strength of Australian agriculture. The budgetary costs would also be enormous. An equivalent level of support to that provided in Europe and the United States could cost us anything up to $5,000m. We simply cannot afford it. Any attempt to do so would so destabilise the macro-economic environment that it could make farm sector problems worse. Finally, and most importantly, it would totally fail to target assistance on those most in need. Twenty-five per cent of Australia's farmers produce 60 per cent of the output, so it is obvious that this 25 per cent would get 60 per cent of the benefits of such an approach.

Another popular but irrational form of assistance would be to provide massive general subsidies on farm interest rates. This, of course, would be even worse, as it would subsidise only one input-debt finance. It would distort the pattern of assistance across commodities, regions and individuals. To the extent that debt is not correlated with need, there would be perverse distributional consequences.

Interestingly, the sector's total interest bill is less than the amount of `tariff compensation' that is often claimed. The Balderstone report in 1982 suggested that interest subsidies could be delivered through a loading on the tax deductibility of interest rates. This would be even more inequitable, giving greatest assistance to those with the highest incomes. The conservative parties' policy favourite of tax deductibility has never done a thing for farmers with low, or nil, taxable income.

Another set of `grand solutions' relates to the current privatisation fad. The Government is reviewing the regulation that exists, implementing deregulatory measures where appropriate, and acting to improve the efficiency of public sector operations. This includes our reforms of statutory marketing authorities, the dairy industry and sugar industry restructuring. What counts is not necessarily ownership, but the quality of management and the incentives provided by the regulatory environment. These issues were ignored by previous governments for too long.

We all know what would happen with wholesale privatisation. In the case of Telecom Australia, for example, the $490m provided in 1984-85 in cross-subsidisation of non-metropolitan rentals and local calls would be lost. I note that the dries in the Liberal Party have yet to direct their attention to the primary industry statutory marketing authorities. In short, the grand solutions provide no solution.
The Government's Approach

What the Government is doing is implementing those measures that do three things-strengthen the sector's long term competitiveness, assist those most in need, and complement our general social and economic policy approach. It is true that we have changed the worst examples of the National Party's legacy, but we have also improved those special programs that specifically benefit primary producers. I particularly refer to tax averaging, the diesel excise rebate and the various commodity underwriting arrangements. No other sector receives these benefits. Our policies need to be set against a background of understanding the market environment of the sector. Despite all the rhetoric, there often does not seem to be much understanding of the nature of markets or of the free enterprise system. Primary production is a form of business activity and therefore should be treated as a business activity. All markets involve risks, and all market participants should know the risks. Accordingly, farm policies need to be consistent with other economic and industry policies.

However, the Government is prepared to give specific assistance to a single commodity where required, and the sugar industry is a good example. Last September, Cabinet took a decision to provide up to $150m in assistance to the sugar industry provided that the Queensland and New South Wales governments matched $1 for $2 price support, up to an agreed level, and that the industry agreed to a beneficial level of deregulation. While the New South Wales Government and industry agreed to the proposal, the recalcitrance of the Queensland Government, which legislatively controls the industry, has resulted in drawn out, inconclusive discussions, rather than effective negotiations on price support and deregulation. The Commonwealth Government has now decided that it will support sugar prices up to a maximum of $230, $225 and $220 per tonne for each of the years 1985, 1986 and 1987 as long as the cost of this support does not exceed $54m in Queensland. This offer is on the basis that the Queensland Government accepts that its offer of $27m interest cost on early season advances and Sugar Board stockholdings represents price support for the industry, thus meeting the Commonwealth's stipulation that State Government contribution for price support is provided on the basis of $1 for each $2 from the Commonwealth. The Government will also participate in the development of measures for farm and mill adjustment on the basis of discussions between the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries and myself on 14 March this year. It is proposed that a consultative body be established for the planning and implementation of regionally based industry adjustment, giving priority attention to the area affected by Cyclone Winifred, which includes Babinda mill.

The decision by the Commonwealth to provide a $100m package for the sugar industry indicates its preparedness to assist specific industries in times of need so long as they are prepared to adjust to changing market and technological circumstances.

The measures I shall announce are not some major change from the policy approach we have been following for the past three years. Rather, they are the natural development of that approach-an approach that recognises the central role of macro-economic policy; an approach that addresses the much needed and long awaited reforms of marketing institutions and systems; an approach that addresses all legitimate cost difficulties and the need to secure the long-term resource base of the sector; and, most importantly, an approach that recognises the importance of all country dwellers, not just primary producers.
Macro-economic Policy

It is becoming increasingly recognised that the most important issues facing the rural sector relate to general economic policy. Specific commodity policy, while important, pales by comparison. We need to recognise, however, that primary production represents less than 10 per cent of economic activity in Australia, so there is no way we are going to redesign our entire economic policy for the sole benefit of that, or any other, sector. No sector, group or interest in our federal, pluralist, private enterprise society ever gets all it wants. Nevertheless, general economic and labour market success implies, by definition, the implementation of appropriate policies for the rural sector. Success means minimal inflation, strong economic growth, and international competitiveness. These are precisely the prerequisites for a healthy rural sector. We have had substantial success on all of these fronts. The BAE's projections are for rates of farm cost inflation of 8 per cent in 1985-86, reflecting the impact of the currency depreciation, and 3 per cent in 1986-87. This compares with the 11 per cent rate we inherited-3 per cent coming up, 11 per cent when we came to government. If the 11 per cent inflation rate had continued, the net value of rural production would have been some $1.5 billion lower by now. Instead of a fall of 30 per cent over the last two years, we would be looking at a fall of around 60 per cent.

Our record of strong economic growth has brought benefits to all country dwellers through improved job opportunities and to primary producers through stronger domestic demand for their output. The floating of the currency has lifted our international competitiveness to record levels. Due to its export exposure, the farm sector is a major beneficiary of this. The BAE estimates that if the currency depreciation had not happened, the farm sector would have been around $1,000m worse off. If our predecessor's policy of maintaining an overvalued dollar had continued, the fall in the real net value of rural production would have been around 40 per cent in 1985-86, not 20 per cent. The Government's general economy policy stance is, of course, subject to continuing review. It has also been reviewed in the context of this statement.
Monetary Policy

Interest rates are the main cost concern of the rural sector at present. As I have pointed out, they are not of concern to all farmers, as many have little or no debt. They are of very great concern to many individuals. The story has been put around the bush that interest rates are high solely because we are artificially propping up the Australian dollar, and that a different policy stance could simply and quickly result in Australian interest rates falling to equal overseas rates with an equivalent depreciation of the currency. I can assure honourable members that things are not that simple. The fact is that the recent stance of monetary policy has been necessary to moderate domestic demand and restrain growth in the monetary aggregates, as well as provide some stability to the dollar. The cleanliness of our float is shown by the size of the depreciation we have been prepared to allow.

While policy has been important, the increase in interest rates late last year was also due to other factors. These primarily related to lags in the operation of policy and the unexpected strength of domestic demand. At the same time, the balance of payments deficit was increasing and the impact of reduced public sector borrowing had not yet been felt. Many of these factors are turning around. Tight monetary policy has achieved its objectives, and the Government is now allowing market induced falls in interest rates to take their course. At the same time, the effects of the currency depreciation and reduced public sector borrowing are being felt. As a consequence, interest rates have already started to fall. For example, 90-day bill rates have fallen from 19.75 per cent to around 15 per cent, while 10-year bond rates are at the lowest level since 1980. The scene appears to be set for further falls. The rural sector wants interest rate reductions. It is getting them-not through an irresponsible monetary policy, but because of the success of our responsible but unpopular policy stance-a stance that was necessary to ensure that primary producers, and all Australians, reap the benefit of the currency depreciation.

In the meantime, the Government recognises the difficulties that high interest rates are causing for a number of primary producers. While we cannot accept an across the board subsidy, we do support appropriate measures targeted to those most in need which have the effect of strengthening the sector in the long term. These are precisely the objectives of the revised rural adjustment scheme, which is an accepted form of assistance with a successfully functioning administrative operation. The Government will constantly liaise with the States' rural adjustment authorities to ensure there is as much flexibility as possible in administration.

In order to enhance the ability of this scheme to achieve its objectives, the Government has decided to increase funding under part A of the scheme by $20m in 1986-87. This will channel additional funds of about $220m into the sector and represents a tenfold increase in loans supported under the scheme since 1982-83. We have also decided to conduct a program to ensure that primary producers are aware of the provisions of the scheme as it may affect them. In addition, the Government has reviewed the foreign investment guidelines relating to rural land. In the current economic climate, the restriction could be acting to exacerbate the declines in land prices that are occurring in some areas. We have decided, therefore, to lift the threshold above which foreign investment proposals are subject to approval from $1m to $3m. This effectively exempt the majority of rural properties, without allowing massive purchases to go unchecked.
Fiscal Policy

Agro-political spokesmen have, for some years, been very fond of calling for reduced public spending and borrowing. This is based on the links between spending, borrowing, taxation, interest rates, inflation and the exchange rate. There has always been an excessively ideological aspect to this position, but the Government recognises that these links do exist. As a result, the Government has committed itself to the trilogy, whereby the Budget deficit, Commonwealth spending and the burden of taxation should not increase as a share of gross domestic product over the life of the current Parliament. This is the most severe self-discipline ever imposed on any Australian government.

A shift in the mix of economic policy, with fiscal policy playing a larger role to reduce the burden of monetary policy, is an important objective this year. This represents a necessary tightening of fiscal policy at a time of rising capital market demands, as such it will not exert a depressing influence on economic activity, but will leave room for private sector expansion. The rural sector will benefit, mainly because of the further easing of financial market and interest rate pressures to which such restraint contributes. This stance does imply, however, the closest scrutiny of all outlay items. No portfolio can be exempt from this, least of all my Department, relating as it does to a constituency that has always supported reduced expenditure. Nevertheless, in addition to the cost of the decisions I am announcing today, and because of the problems facing the rural sector, the Government has decided to give high priority to retaining those expenditure programs which affect the farm sector in the 1986-87 Budget. The benefits to primary producers could be much greater, and come on top of the benefits of the recent fuel price decisions.

On the taxation side, the Government has announced a number of measures to improve the operation of the taxation system in terms of its impact on both economic activity and equity across individuals. This has centred on a crackdown on tax avoidance and evasion opportunities-the $3,000m leakage allowed by our opponents in the past. Because of the substantial reductions in tax rates that are at the heart of this package, the farm sector will be a major beneficiary. Some of the decisions embodied in the tax package have been subject to criticism from rural spokesmen. By and large, I reject this criticism. The capital gains tax is necessary for the proper taxation of all forms of income. It has been designed carefully so as to effectively exempt the farm sector without creating a tax shelter. The great majority of rural properties will not be subject to the tax for generations, if ever. Similarly, the fringe benefits tax will bring in to account forms of income currently untaxed.

The major criticism has focused on the proposal to quarantine farm income for taxation purposes. The Government has reviewed this matter and, in the light of some potential inequities, has decided not to proceed with this measure but to pursue an alternative approach. This represents a cost to revenue of $65m. The problem of tax abuse in the primary production area will now be addressed with more closely targeted remedies. As a first step, we have decided that breeding costs by registered stud breeders up to the time of birth of progeny are to be taken into account in the trading stock valuation for income tax purposes.

The Government's motivation regarding quarantining was correct. Many of us will agree with the phrase `we are living beyond our means'. I would be happier with the phrase if it were not being uttered by the `haves' instead of the `have nots'. There is no reason why the community should allow tax shelters so that those with high incomes can make massive capital gains and push up the price of farm land in the process. If the claims of some of the critics of quarantining could be believed, we could expect a substantial recovery in land prices to result from this decision. Unfortunately, I do not expect this to be the case-the fundamental cause of the weakness in rural land prices is the low level of farm incomes.
Wages Policy

The central tenet of much rural criticism of the Government's economic policy relates to our wages policy. I want clearly to state here and now that, given the demonstrable success of the Government's wages policy, we are not about to change our basic direction. Our current centralised wages system is working, with wage inflation having fallen dramatically while still allowing real incomes to be maintained. As a result, the previous imbalance in factor shares has been corrected. This development has played a large part in the achievement of strong economic and employment growth.

Critics of the system need to demonstrate that an alternative system could deliver more in terms of wage restraint and reduced industrial disputation. The facts of history are against them. The catchcry of many critics is the need for `flexibility' in wage setting. In most cases, they do not know what they are talking about. The accord has, for the first time, introduced macro-economic flexibility into wage setting in the form of wage restraint at a time of strong economic growth. Unlike our opponents, we do not need to resort to severe deflationary policies and consequent spiralling unemployment. This capacity for macro wage flexibility through the accord has already been demonstrated by the agreement to discount the current national wage case for the effects of the currency depreciation.

The basis for much rural criticism of centralised wage fixation is a desire for capacity to `pay' on an industry basis to be the central issue in wage determination. What the critics are saying is that people in similar occupations should receive different remuneration. Why should this concept apply to employees and not any other input? I wonder whether it is also being suggested that equipment suppliers, banks, local stores and everyone else who supplies farmers should also charge farmers less than their other customers. How is the workforce to be so browbeaten that it would accept such an inequity? Farm leaders appear to believe that their preferred system will result in depressed industries paying less in wages than they do now. Unfortunately for them, the lessons of history are different-`capacity to pay' would mean that the more profitable industries would pay more, with all other industries quickly experiencing a flow-on.

Just look at the disastrous effects on the economy of the 1981-82 experiment with deregu- lation. Where is the economic logic in that? One could only imagine the effect on economic growth, on the incentive for entrepreneurial dynamism, of a system where by every time a firm improved its productivity it was hit by a wage increase. How would an industry subject to wide fluctuations in its fortunes-such as the farm based industries-guarantee that it could reverse wage increases granted in upswings? The proposals are recipes for both an industrial relations and an economic disaster.

This is not to say, however, that there would not be some advantages in achieving increased relative wage flexibility, but only insofar as it did not endanger the macro wage outcome. Achieving this balance will be a difficult and challenging task, but one which the Government will continue to pursue. Flexibility is available under the current system, as it is always open to an industry to argue its incapacity to pay national wage cases. The National Farmers Federation has taken advantage of this in the past. The Government has indicated that flexibility will also be available in the implementation of the superannuation reforms that are proposed to be paid from the current national productivity case.

As previously announced by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), rural workers must expect that they will receive the benefits of the new arrangements towards the end of the two-year phasing-in period.
