Naturally, this will not preclude discussions being undertaken beforehand to settle the detailed implementation of the schemes.
Income Side Measures

The rural debate in this country has become excessively focused on narrow-minded discussions of particular cost issues. As I shall outline in a moment, the Government's record on these issues is impressive, with substantial further gains in the pipeline. Nevertheless, as the major problem for the rural sector is declining receipts on world markets, this is the area that needs to be addressed first.
Trade Policy

World trade growth has underpinned the health of our rural sector in the post-war period. It is essential, and inevitable, that it do so again. We must make every endeavour to maximise both the growth in trade and our share of it. This requires concerted action on both the demand and supply side of international markets. On the supply side, the Government has been most active in expressing Australia's concerns on the international scene about the subsidisation practices of certain major agricultural producers.

We have changed the abusive tactics used by our predecessors for more calmly reasoned argument, pointing out the adverse effects of these subsidisation practices on world markets, other countries including the Third World, and, indeed, on the subsidising countries themselves.

We have had some successes in this regard. Last year we were able to negotiate the Andriessen Agreement with the European communities which protects our major Asian beef markets from the intrusion of subsidised European beef. This year, the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) was able to achieve an important contribution in winning improvements to the United States Farm Act, as reflected by the United States congressional decision to reduce the size of its export subsidy program; it halved it. There is still a long way to go. Our determination to continue our efforts is demonstrated by the departure of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) later today to further pursue these issues.

The problem of agricultural production and export subsidies is directly related to the ineffectiveness of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade disciplines in respect of agriculture. The Government is giving priority and using every possible avenue to ensure that the problems are effectively addressed in the GATT and the new round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations. We are particularly seeking to strengthen GATT rules so as to phase out direct export subsidies for agriculture and improve our access to markets. Simultaneously, the Government is pressing forward with bilateral trade arrangements. An important aim is to fully secure Australia's position in the growth markets of the Pacific Basin, North Asia, the Middle East and North Africa.

Trade agreements, with appropriate emphasis on agriculture, have been concluded with most countries of the Middle East, while an Agricultural co-operation agreement with China has been signed and an agreement with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is at an advanced stage. A high level group of officials and the rural and exporting communities is being convened to develop a more comprehensive strategy for bilateral agricultural trade policy. The necessity for broad recovery in the world economy is also important in rejuvenating demand for agricultural imports in world trade. The Government is involved in discussions in a number of world fora which seek to promote policies designed to achieve the highest sustainable rate of output and employment growth.
Marketing Arrangements

Ever since becoming Minister three years ago, the reform of the various statutory marketing authorities has been one of my top priorities. Our marketing arrangements need to be as flexible and commercially oriented as possible if they are to achieve their objective of maximising returns to producers. I have therefore established a policy for statutory marketing authorities that removes unnecessary bureaucratic controls, and replaces the politically motivated appointments of our predecessors with a procedure that ensures that only the best people for the job are selected.

It is impossible to estimate the gains from this policy. An improvement of even one per cent in our rural export returns still amounts to over $100m. To illustrate the magnitude of the potential benefits, our decision to allow the Australian Wheat Board to borrow overseas, alone, saved Australia's wheatgrowers some $50m in 1984-85. As a further step in improving marketing arrangements, we have decided on a comprehensive reform of marketing for the horticultural industry. Australia has performed poorly in both traditional and newer horticultural markets in recent years. This is partly due to a lack of co-ordination, infrastructure, research, and promotion. The Government has decided, therefore, to establish a Horticultural Marketing Corporation, together with complementary industry selection, policy and research organisations. Commonwealth support of $10m over five years will be made to these organisations. This includes $5.85m for the Corporation, $1.9m for the Policy Council, $1.25m for the Research Fund, and $1m for research on overseas quarantine barriers.

In the 1985-86 Budget, the Government agreed to provide $7m over four years to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to encourage marketing innovation. We have also secured the basis of wool promotion expenditure, with a financial commitment of about $32m this financial year. The newly created Australian Trade Commission-AUSTRADE-will enhance Australia's export performance, while its export, finance and insurance arm is providing extensive insurance support for Australia's rural exports.

There is no question that agriculture needs greater sophistication in producing for market requirements and developing better marketing systems. In order to encourage change in these areas, the Government has agreed to the establishment of a special fund of $25m over five years for innovation in agricultural product development and marketing. No marketing measures are worthwhile if the incentives to producers, processors and exporters are all wrong. Such a situation currently prevails in the dairy industry through the export pooling arrangements. These arrangements encourage unprofitable exports at the expense of both producers and domestic consumers. Our recently announced reforms to the dairy marketing arrangements will correct this situation.
Cost Side Measures

As I pointed out earlier, our success in restraining inflation and hence farm cost increases has been of substantial benefit to rural producers, as well as to the economy as a whole. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics projects that the index of prices paid by farmers will increase by only 3 per cent in 1986-87, compared with 8 per cent in 1985-86 and the 11 per cent rate we inherited. This reflects generally lower inflation and, in particular, lower fuel prices and interest rates. Today's decisions will further reduce the rate of cost increases. This is a substantial achievement, one that deserves recognition by all those associated with rural communities.
Fuel Prices

Fuel prices to primary producers have fallen significantly recently as a direct result of our decision in last year's Budget to fully rebate the excise for diesel off-road use by primary producers. This is in addition to the benefit to primary producers, like all users, from the recent petrol price reductions. These decisions are saving farmers over $300m per year. Primary producers are the only users in receipt of this full rebate. It has been suggested that we should extend the rebate to include petrol excise. This raises a number of difficulties with respect to cost, equity and administration. The Industries Assistance Commission is considering the fuel excise system. In considering its report, the Government does not envisage a reduction in the benefits to primary producers represented by the current diesel exemption.
Fertilisers

The Government currently provides assistance to fertiliser consumption through subsidies costing some $55m annually. We have also provided a $10m subsidy so as to exempt farmers from the effects of anti-dumping action on certain fertiliser imports. Both these measures are currently subject to review. As recognised by the National Farmers Federation, fertiliser subsidisation is less than an ideal method of delivering assistance to primary producers. Nevertheless, in the light of current rural sector problems, the Government has decided that the overall cost of fertilisers to farmers will not increase as a result of any decisions which may flow from these reviews.
Tariffs and Industry Policy

There has been increasing recognition by primary producers in recent years of the costs to them of tariffs and other forms of industry protection. As a result, farmers have come to realise that they have effectively been sold out over the years by political representatives who supported `protection all round'-that is, members of the National Party of Australia. There has, however, been a great deal of confusion about which forms of protection have been imposing these costs. Some believe that tariffs on farm inputs are the major cause of these costs. Others tend to ignore the costs arising from protection for some agricultural commodities. The fact is that anyone who is not receiving protection is paying for all forms of protection, either through higher prices for particular inputs or through a higher exchange rate and a higher overall domestic cost structure.

The present Government is the first government in Australia's history to adopt a program of protection reductions on a long term sustainable basis. Our approach is to consider each industry's situation and difficulties, and implement a package of measures that reduce unwarranted assistance while strengthening the industry's long term competitive position and prospects. Such packages have been implemented for the steel and car industries in particular, along with some smaller industries. Rural industries cannot expect to be exempted. Our decisions on the dairy, tobacco and dried vine fruits industries include aspects that reduce the high levels of assistance these industries receive. In a number of cases, the forms of regulation and assistance provided to rural industries are perverse in their operation. Nowhere is this more obvious than in the sugar industry, where the regulatory framework redistributes income within the industry resulting in higher costs to the industry as a whole.

The Government will be continuing with its present approach when considering the reports of the Industries Assistance Commission on industries currently under inquiry. These include textiles, clothing and footwear, pulp and paper, and the chemical and plastics industries. This will result in all major highly protected industries having been reviewed since we came to office. As a result, over time, decisions on these industries will further reduce reliance on high levels of protection and promote internationally competitive activities.

The Government is confident that the continued application and extension of its policies towards manufacturing, with competing interests properly balanced and in full co-operation with affected parties, will progressively reduce the costs of protection imposed on the farm sector. The Government also carefully considers the forms of assistance, in order to minimise the impact on users. Accordingly, it was decided in last year's Budget to replace the tariff on grain harvesters with a bounty, so reducing farm costs by some $14m per year.

The Government has now decided to take further action to reduce tariff-induced farm input costs. The tariffs on agricultural and horticultural machinery for soil preparation and cultivation will be replaced with a bounty providing equivalent assistance. The IAC will be requested to advise on the appropriate bounty level and arrangements. These will apply from today, cover existing stocks, and will cost an estimated $39m in the first year. In last year's Budget Speech, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated that the Government was disposed to replace tariffs on agricultural chemicals with bounties when considering the IAC Report on the chemicals industry. A final decision will be made in the context of the IAC's final report. However, the Government is committed to reducing the price of these chemicals for farmers, either by bounties or the reduction of tariffs or a combination of the two. In the meantime, we have decided to remove immediately the 2 per cent revenue duty where it now applies to agricultural chemicals, at a cost to revenue of $0.4m in a full year.
Bovine and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign

The bovine brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign-BTEC-is on target to meet its objective of national disease-free status by 1992, with the BTEC trust fund currently in a healthy state. As a result, the Government has decided to reduce the BTEC component of the livestock slaughter levy by $1, at a saving to the industry of its own money of about $6m next year. We have also decided to amend section 36AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act to permit profit from the sale or destruction of animals for BTEC purposes to be offset on a head per herd basis and to be assessed as income over 10 years.
Off-Farm Costs

The area of downstream costs has become increasingly contentious in recent years. The Government has already achieved substantial successes in restraining these costs. Our SMA reforms are improving the value for money primary producers receive from their marketing institutions. After many years, progress is finally being made in creating a single national inspection service. This, along with other measures, has resulted in substantial cost savings, estimated at some $16.8m per annum. I might point out that, had the National Party allowed changes in the Victorian Parliament, there would have been another $2.3m saving. A review of relevant legislation has identified some export controls on wheat products, timber and some livestock which can no longer be justified. Through the Business Regulation Review Unit in the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, a wide range of regulations are being reviewed. One of the priority areas of particular relevance to primary producers relates to food laws. Of course, the most important aspect of restraining off-farm cost increases has been our success in reducing overall inflation.

Nevertheless, we recognise that there needs to be eternal vigilance in this area, and further measures are required. To this end, the Government has decided to offer to the States the establishment of a joint inquiry into the costs and efficiency of wheat transport and handling. The inquiry will take the form of a Commonwealth-State royal commission, to report within 12 months. The terms of reference will be developed between Commonwealth and State Ministers.

In its consideration of the two task force reports on liner shipping and shore-based shipping costs, the Government will seek measures which continue to enable exporters to negotiate further commercial improvements in shipping arrangements. The liner shipping report calls for shipping arrangements to promote Australia's overall trading interests and advocates the maintenance of a competitive regime for liner shipping, with shipping lines free to operate commercially either within or outside conference arrangements and with minimal government intervention or regulation.

Some rural lobby groups have suggested to me that they should receive funding from their industries through the Commonwealth's compulsory levy mechanisms. I cannot agree to this request, as I do not believe it is appropriate for the Commonwealth's ability to raise compulsory levies to be used for this purpose. Nevertheless, the Government does recognise that there is a need for improved consultative mechanisms with all those involved in the rural scene. We have decided, therefore, to offer to establish a Rural and Allied Industries Council involving the National Farmers' Federation, industry and trade union representation. The Council, modelled on the successful operation of the manufacturing industry councils, would provide a forum for regular consultation on all issues affecting the rural sector, including the review of conditions in the sector and the identification of major impediments to its development.
Resource Base

A major concern of the Government since taking office has been to secure the resource base of the sector. We have instituted the national soil conservation program, which is receiving $5.2m in Commonwealth funding in 1985-86. We have also broadened the scope of the tax concession available for soil conservation expenditure to include all land degradation expenditure. We have placed rural research funding on a sound long term basis, with a guaranteed Commonwealth matching contribution of up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production of each industry, and reformed the institutional arrangements. I have already announced improved research arrangements for the horticultural industry. With the agreement of the Agricultural Council, the National Drought Consultative Committee was formed in 1984. As a result, we now have a consistent set of drought policy measures. The principal drought measures are concessional finance for carry-on, restocking and restoration, and freight rebates for the transport of livestock, fodder and water.

Our nation's most important resource is, and is increasingly, the talents, skills and dedication of our population. Understanding of advanced technology and of its application to rural industries is becoming essential for future success in primary production. Commercial management skills are also becoming of even greater significance. While many of the advances required of the rural education system are being met in varying degrees by individual educational and training institutions, we have decided to examine further the adequacy of rural educational and training services.

The Government is also concerned at the relatively low level of participation by country youth in senior secondary and tertiary education. The Government has already acted to improve assistance for students and their educational opportunities in country areas. It will also be considering the scope for further action, in conjunction with the States, to increase educational participation. As a first step, the Department of Education has been allocated $388,000 to implement several initiatives to improve the access by rural people to information on Commonwealth education assistance schemes.
Rural and Provincial Affairs

As I acknowledged at the beginning of this statement, agricultural policy needs to be set in the context of the overall perspective of the needs of country dwellers. Not all country dwellers are farmers-in fact, most are not-and not all country dwellers are directly or indirectly dependent on agriculture for their livelihood. But all country dwellers, whether farmers or not, do have special needs and concerns that should be addressed by Government.
Access to Services

The Hawke Labor Government is the first government to take its responsibilities in this area seriously. Our Party platform commits us to ensuring that no disadvantage occurs to country dwellers, and to develop special institutions and programs where necessary. Both myself and my colleagues in relevant areas have been very active in precisely this direction. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris)-Australia's greatest Minister for Transport-has taken many initiatives to improve our transport system. Substantial gains have been made in the areas of improved operation of the Australian National Line and Australian National Railways, the shipping reviews to which I referred to earlier, and securing the funding of roads and road safety.

The Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) has allocated substantial sums of money to airports in rural and provincial centres. The number of airports receiving development and maintenance grants has increased. Coupled with assistance to rural air services, this has meant a substantial improvement in the quality of services in rural Australia.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has presided over a massive expansion in services to rural areas. These include remote commercial television services, AUSSAT, and Telecom's Rural and Remote Areas Program. Incidentally, the last mentioned is still to be endorsed by our political opponents. Through these initiatives, we are now more than ever before one nation, with more equal access to each other.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has ensured that the community employment program is equitable in its treatment of non-metropolitan areas. Under this program, we have so far approved $422m in grants for projects located in non-metropolitan areas providing employment for almost 43,000 long term unemployed persons. The program of Commonwealth general purpose financial assistance for local government is particularly significant for rural councils as it contributes, on average, the equivalent of about one-third of their rate revenue. The level of program funding will be at least maintained in real terms in the coming two years. For the coming year, there will be no change in the basis of distribution of funds between councils. However, in subsequent years there will be a gradual change in favour of the most needy councils, including rural councils.

The labour force participation of country women, including in agriculture, has been increasing for many years. This reflects both a greater equality of roles between the sexes and changed perceptions by rural women of the roles they have always undertaken. This development has gone largely unrecognised by many National Party and agro-politicians, who continue to cling to unrealistic attitudes on the role of women. We have decided to provide $100,000 for a rural Womens' Access Program to fund projects aimed at providing the access of all women in rural areas to services and employment. This is in addition to the national survey on the needs and priorities of rural women that is being undertaken in collaboration with the Country Women's Association.

We have taken the opportunity of our review of rural policy to consider also some of the more general measures in this area. We have decided to establish a working group to advise on the most cost-effective means of providing greater access for rural areas to Commonwealth Government administration, including the delivery of cash payments and to information on the range of Government programs. Studies by the Department of Community Services on the delivery and effectiveness of its programs in remote areas have also been commissioned.

We have decided to expedite negotiations with the States on improved travel arrangements under the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme. We have decided to allocate $0.5m in 1986-87 for fostering strategic plans for country centres and surrounding regions to provide a basis for future development by the private sector and State and local government. We have decided to further integrate rural policy development, particularly through the operation of the Rural and Provincial Affairs Unit in my Department. We have also decided to develop a research proposal on policies to increase the relevance and effectiveness in rural areas of housing policies and programs.
Welfare Measures

In the light of the current income difficulties, the Government has reviewed existing income security measures available to primary producers and has decided to make a number of improvements. Part C of the rural adjustment scheme provides household support for up to three years to producers considering leaving the industry. This has been successful in alleviating on-farm hardship. It has been decided to increase funding under Part C by $1.8m in 1986-87. This is an open-ended commitment, so it is anticipated that all applications for assistance will be met, including an expanded presence in those States currently under-utilising this aspect of the scheme.

Various State and private initiatives already in existence have demonstrated that counselling services, particularly financial counselling services, for primary producers can have beneficial local and national economic effects through the encouragement of appropriate adjustment and to reduce personal and social stresses associated with poor financial circumstances. The Government has therefore decided to establish a rural counselling service, under which the Commonwealth is prepared to provide matching funds to help community groups employ a counsellor. The service is estimated to cost the Commonwealth $900,000 per year.

One industry with special adjustment problems is the fishing industry which, in a number of cases, needs to reduce activity if fisheries are to be managed on a sustainable yield basis. Successful adjustment assistance has already been provided in respect of the northern prawn fisheries. We have decided to extend this assistance to all fisheries that are subject to effective management arrangements.
Conclusion

The cost of the initiatives I have announced is not large when compared with the total value of rural production. It is certainly not large when compared with the benefits to the sector of our rural economic policies. However, these measures do represent all the remaining specific measures that can be taken for the rural sector. Any further expenditure at this time would not be justified either against the need for fiscal constraint or for equity reasons. The solution to the rural sector's problems must come through a recovery in international markets. We will continue to do our utmost in this area. In the meantime, the major rural sector concerns must be on appropriate macro-economic policy management. The Hawke Labor Government has demonstrated its credentials, with further substantial economic gains in prospect.

I know today's statement will not satisfy everyone-nothing ever does. However, in many ways this is an historic statement. No government has ever presented such a comprehensive, wide-ranging policy review from the standpoint of the rural, or any other, sector. No government has ever been as active as we have been in promoting the revenue concerns of Australian agriculture. No government has given more recognition than we have to the needs of all residents of rural and provincial Australia.

In the immediate future there will, of course, be further consideration of fiscal measures in the budgetary context, and continuing reviews of wages and monetary policy. The interests of the rural sector in particular, and country residents in general, will continue to be well to the fore in these deliberations.

For the longer term, the Hawke Labor Government has established a return to strong economic growth in Australia. We all benefit from this, including the rural community. We will continue to frame our policies with this longer term perspective in mind. Those who seek spurious quick fixes will not find us receptive. Those who are interested in policies for the long term benefit of all Australians will find much to support in this statement, much to support in our overall economic and social strategies, much to be thankful for in our record, and much to look forward to in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators I table a paper entitled `Economic and Rural Policy-A Government Policy Statement'. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
`, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Hawke Labor Government has-
(a) failed the sugar industry totally and has watered down the original offer of assistance to such an extent that hundreds could be forced off their farms;
(b) failed to remove Government excise and tariffs from essential input costs to rural industries;
(c) failed to give relief from the interest rates which are an added crippling burden;
(d) while providing $108m, $35m of which will be spread over 5 years, failed to acknowledge the $442m ripped off the farm sector in Labor's Budgets since 1983;
(e) failed to make any attempt to remedy the situation revealed by the Burueau of Agriculatural Economics forecast of a further 21 per cent fall in net farm income in the next financial year; and
(f) failed to address the underlying problem of high costs and low productivity in handling farm produce beyond the farm gate,

and is in total confusion over its policy on the quarantining of farm losses, as indicated by Senator Walsh's comments in Question Time on, 16 April 1986, and the Senate calls on the Hawke Labor Government to recognise that the farm sector-
(g) provides for our domestic requirements;
(h) provides much needed export income at a time of an all-time high current account deficit; and
(j) provides thousands of jobs,
and to treat the farm sector's difficulties, particularly those caused by its policies, more seriously and with more remedial action!

This ministerial statement was brought down in the House of Representatives yesterday by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on behalf of the Hawke Labor Government. I am reminded of a quote of Mark Twain who said:
Few sinners are saved after the first twenty minutes of a sermon.

This sermon, if one can call it that, ran for about 61 minutes, so very few farmers would see any salvation in the sermon as delivered by the Minister for Primary Industry yesterday. Interestingly, there is a paragraph in the foreword of the paper entitled `Economic and Rural Policy-A government Policy Statement' which reads:
There will be some who will want simply to add up the costs of specifically new initiatives developed in this paper.
Too right they will. It continues:
The measures we are taking are too numerous and too diverse for that to provide any realistic indication of our commitment.

That sort of paragraph raises the alarm bells and says `beware'! It is a bit like some of the journalistic jargon, such as `there has been full and frank discussion' which actually means that there has been one heck of a row. The jargon in this paragraph really means: `We are saying a lot but doing little'. So the farmers of Australia should beware. Indeed, I think they are already aware of that. There is a lot of verbiage but very little substance.

The Minister spent a considerable amount of time telling the farmers what their problems are. Do they need it? Does anybody think they need it? Does a farmer who is working from daylight to dark, seven days a week, with his wife and children helping him, who is quite efficient but cannot make a go of it because of costs beyond the farm gate-costs over which he has no control, such as government imposts-need to be told for at least half an hour in a ministerial speech, in which he hoped he would get some relief, what his problems are? Of course he does not. The farming community and individual farmers have been telling for some considerable time this Government particularly and the people of Australia generally what their problems are. I do not think that anybody is under any illusions as to the dire straits in which the farming community now finds itself.

I suppose one thing can be said: At least the Government at last recognises and acknowledges the problem. In other words, now it knows. After all the broken promises, about cheap fuel and no capital gains tax, we should have known, we should have been warned. There has been a build-up in the weeks before the statement was brought down; the farming community was looking forward to it. Then all of a sudden we get a whole lot of verbiage and very little substance. We should have been warned. We had heard the broken promises which have come to nothing. We had heard the build-up for this statement, but again, basically we have got nothing. I suppose it must be acknowledged that there is a philosophical problem for the Hawke Labor Government or any Labor Government in understanding the farming community. This Government still seems to look on it as a milking cow and still seems to look upon the farming community as a bottomless pit from which it can keep taking revenue to prop up its ailing economy. The cow is pretty well dry and there is not much silage left in the pit. Still the bush hangs on, but one sometimes wonders why and how. The people in the bush have always had a certain amount of resilience, and the people are still there. While they are still there they are providing a massive amount of revenue for our export income. Unfortunately there will be many casualties.

On top of all this it must be mentioned that there is a drought throughout most of Australia's primary producing areas. That drought is ticking away like a time bomb which could ultimately be one of the contributing factors towards destroying the Hawke Government. On top of all the problems the rural community is facing, this drought is there. Areas which normally have high rainfalls have had very little. Many parts of eastern Queensland, and the wheat growing areas of New South Wales and Victoria are in dire straits. It does not look as though crops will be planted, let alone be destroyed afterwards by inclement weather. It has to be accepted and realised not only by this Government but also by the people of Australia that they cannot at this stage rely on the bush, the rural sector, to do what they usually do and pull this economy out of the hole into which it is slowly sliding.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) saw himself as the Messiah. He was going to solve all Australia's problems. We can all remember those Messiah-like election campaigns. Unfortunately, most of his policies were all about the redistribution of wealth and nothing about creating wealth. That is a little bit of plagiarism. I can recall Des Keegan saying that after the first Hawke election speech. Nonetheless, there he was, the Messiah, on stage, promising the world that he would do this and that for Australia. It is unfortunate that a sufficient number of other Australian's also saw him in that light. He gave the rural sector hope with many of his speeches; but unfortunately, yesterday was the Hawke Labor Government's day of judgment, and it failed. The farmers are still in bondage, and a lot of it has been brought about by the Hawke Labor Government's policies. Interestingly, with all the hyperbole, with all the verbiage, the farmers are not buying it. Most of the newspapers played it pretty straight, but the spokesmen for the farming community are not buying it at all. No matter what industry we look at, they are awake to the fact that there is very little in it for them. Even while the Minister for Primary Industry was bringing down this infamous statement, Mr Hawke was, significantly, on his way overseas, leaving one of his Ministers to cop the flak.

One of the facts that people are slowly waking up to is that when the bush hurts, everybody hurts. Conversely, when things are prosperous in the bush, the economy bubbles along in a reasonable manner. The Hawke Government has acknowledged this. Not long after it came to power the then drought broke, and the economy picked up-nobody is denying that. As I said, the Hawke Government has acknowledged the fact that when there is prosperity in the bush and the bush is spending money, it provides for a very quick resurgence in our economy, because rural people are the people who spend money and who spend it quickly on machinery, sheds, fencing, and so on. But when the bush hurts, everybody hurts. This time the bush is hurting and it does not look as though it will cease hurting for a long time yet. That does not bode too well for this country's economy.

The National Farmers Federation, some time ago, targeted five issues: First, a full flow-on of import parity pricing so that Australian consumers pay the world price for fuel; secondly, tariffs off all agricultural inputs, with chemicals as a first step; thirdly, a reduction in interest rates by freeing up the money market; fourthly, the cancellation of the next two proposed national wage cases; and fifthly, the scrapping of the proposed capital gains tax and a restructuring of the offsetting of farm losses. In other words, they were basically structural policy changes in areas of farm input costs. None of these areas has been addressed, except the quarantining of farm losses. I guess this Government has translated a `She'll be right, mate' attitude, which is indicative of most Australians to one of `You'll be all right, fellas; we'll look after you, but we won't do much'.

All the farm leaders have been warning of the consequences of what would happen as a result of Government inactivity. Now, after a 61-minute statement by the Minister yesterday, we still have inactivity. The attitude seems to be that a lot of the problems will go away. Significantly, international factors were mentioned-and so they should have been. Every parliamentarian, of whatever political persuasion, would recognise that international factors have an effect. We all recognise that the European Community is dumping subsidised products on our traditional markets. We recognise that we lost out badly on the Japanese meat market. Quite significantly, when that happened very little was done about it by this Government. But one would think that when international situations are such that our rural community is suffering, any government would be trying to free up any domestic situation which was causing difficulties so that it might become more competitive, and that the Government would assist it to compete in those particular situations.

As I indicated, there are few pluses in this document. What pluses there are have been more than covered by the minuses since the Hawke Government came to power. As I have mentioned, the paragraph in the foreword states:
The measures we are taking are too numerous and too diverse for that to provide any realistic indication of our commitment.

That was referring to the fact that the Government has not quantified what the benefits will be. Fortunately, my colleague the Hon. Ralph Hunt in the other place has done so. He puts forward a figure of benefits of about $108m. Included in that, I might add, is $35m which would be phased in over a five-year period. Ralph Hunt also quantifies the extra imposts since this Government came to power on the rural community. They are running at $442m. So in spite of this package, there is a massive deficit, or a shift of financial resources, from the rural sector to the public sector per kind favour of the Hawke Labor Government.

One would have to acknowledge the fact that the sugar industry is in trouble. The proposed help to the sugar industry is a great disappointment. If ever there was an industry that is indicative of what an industry's flow-on effects are through the community, it is certainly the sugar industry in Queensland. We are the most decentralised state, because the sugar industry, right up the coast of Queensland, has provided good, solid provincial towns. Sure, this Government can go on with its bloody-mindedness towards the rural community, and towards the sugar industry in particular; but it has to understand that as well as hurting the farmers, which it seems intent on doing, there are plenty of other people down the line who rely on that sugar industry. Undoubtedly, we shall ultimately see the rationalisation of mills, and many people who are employed in the sugar industry, on the farms, in the processing industry and in the transport industry, will be without jobs. The minimum floor price needed to keep the sugar industry out of trouble is $240 a tonne. The package yesterday offered $230 a tonne.

Other farmers will welcome the few pluses that there are in this document, or the few crumbs from the table. More money has been made available for farm and debt adjustment to assist those farmers with some hope of recovery but who would not be classified as commercially viable by traditional lending institutions. There have been changes in welfare benefits. Some small relief from tariff costs has been announced. The Government laid great store by the quarantining of farm losses. The abandonment of that, albeit before its implementation, is to be welcomed.

I think that one has to acknowledge that there are many other failures. First of all, the Government does not appear to have accepted the forecast of its own body, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, of a 21 per cent fall in net farm income in the next financial year. As I indicated, if the weather is against one of the major producing sections of its economy, if international markets are against it, one would think that the Government would be doing everything in its power to help it. It has failed to address the underlying problem of high costs and low productivity as well as that of handling farm produce beyond the farm date. Therein lies one of the major problems facing the farm community.

One would think that with monthly current account deficit figures which show a disastrous picture, an unprecedented picture-a picture which, to my knowledge has never been seen since Federation-for a sector which is providing 40 to 45 per cent of our exports the Government would be treating it with kid gloves and would be looking after it. However, the opposite is happening because of the philosophical hang-ups which Labor governments have arising from their belief that the rural community is a milking cow.

I mention that, in recognition of the fact that there are peaks and troughs in rural incomes, we introduced tax averaging provisions and income equalisation deposits. That is something which I would consider is probably one of the best things that the Fraser-Anthony Government ever did for the rural community in the long term. However, it was not long before the Hawke Government came to power and got to the tax averaging provisions with a knife. Certainly it gutted the IEDs. Significantly, those IEDS were used in the first instance, and as a continuing method, to help to finance the Primary Industry Bank. Of course, that method of helping the Primary Industry Bank has now gone because the IEDs are such that one must question whether farmers would want to use them anyhow.

As well as all those problems there are also the underlying economic problems facing this country. Those problems are facing the manufacturing industry as well although, of course, they are facing the primary producers to a greater extent. As I indicated, farmers can be as efficient as they like on their farms, they can work harder than any other section of this community, but once the produce gets beyond the farm gate the farmers have no control over costs.

Those people who are working in every sector of transport or processing beyond the farm gate basically are earning more than the person who produced the original product. That is a ridiculous state of affairs. As I said, that industry is providing for our domestic consumption, it is providing thousands of jobs and it is providing much needed export revenue. For this reason one cannot understand why the Government has taken the attitude that it has.

As I said, the farming community would welcome any crumbs from the table that are there. However, as I indicated, I think the farming community has seen through the rural policy statement. It is not fooled by it. If this Government wants to survive, if it wants to pull this nation out of the economic hole in which it is finding itself, it has to do far better than that. The economic situation is such that we are in hock. Any recovery we have had has been a debt-led recovery. This nation is in hock. We have committed our children, their children and their children's children-generations to come-to paying off the profligacy of this Government towards other sectors of the community. The Government has ignored the manufacturing sector and the rural sector, the only sectors that can pull this Government out of the economic hole in which it is finding itself. The Government carries on in that ignorance at its peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Government brought down a significant paper with regard to the rural policy which it is pursuing and which presumably it intends to pursue between now and the next election. I think it is a very important paper. It is indeed a pity that we have not had such papers in this area in the past. In fact, in the six years that I have been here, this is the first comprehensive detailing of a government's forward policy with regard to a very important segment of Australia's economic life. I believe that the treatment which the paper has received has come in many circumstances only from a knee-jerk reaction. Much of that reaction occurred prior to the release of the document. Possibly many of the Press releases which went out were written prior to the document's tabling. That seems to me to be a pity.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a significant area of policy. I would have thought that it was important to debate the items which the Government maintains and to test them to see whether the items the Government is proposing are indeed legitimate, useful devices for promoting the economic life of the rural sector of Australia. Merely to engage in the type of speech we have just heard from Senator Collard does not assist anybody very much. I believe that in future it would be far better if the various proposals-there are some quite significant proposals here-were to be debated on their merits. I suppose that it is a bit much to ask in the political world in which we live. However, it seems to me that it is very useful that this be done. If it were done, I think we would then find that there was a great deal to welcome in the paper brought down by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). I think we would then have a basis for saying where we disagree, where we believe the Government should be heading and what types of additional items the Government could well be addressing itself to.

I would like to go through the items in the Government's paper in light of the statement that I made in the election campaign in 1984 to the Rural Press Club. I would like to use those items as a basis for raising what the Government has sought to do in terms of its paper and saying where I believe there can be significant advances on where the Government currently stands. In more general terms-that is, in terms of factors affecting interest rates and the money supply-it seems to me that the Government simply has reiterated its general economic policy, as one would expect it to do. However, I think there were some significant items which I raised in 1984 and which really ought to be taken into account but which the Government has not made any comments on. These are to do with the foreign banks and whether the Government has a requirement-the Government certainly has not, but I believe it should-for a significant rural finance component in terms of the entry of those foreign banks and whether the relevant Act should be amended to allow for better provision of banking facilities and services to rural areas in terms of the significant development of the banking sector in Australia.

Also, I want to look at the Government's deregulation of interest rates. This is something which the Australian Democrats have not supported but which, of course, the Liberal and National parties have supported. I believe that in that deregulation there are significant problems for small business and for the rural sector. I believe that if the Government is intending to proceed in this way-it would seem to be the settled policy also of any incoming Liberal- National Party government-the Government is then required to take additional measures to make sure that the people, particularly those who have overdrafts under $100,000, have significant interest rate support. The Government has gone some way towards this in terms of actually providing some finance. It seems to me to be very odd, in the first place, to engage in this type of deregulation with regard to small businesses and then to have to prop up the interest rates which people necessarily have to pay because of the deregulation policy the Government has pursued.

There should be a uniform low rate of assistance across all sectors of industry which does not favour any particular industries and which places all sectors on an equivalent competitive footing. I refer here to the Industries Assistance Commission report delivered during the Fraser years, upon which the Fraser Government took no action and upon which very little action has been taken since, in regard to the general reduction of tariffs. I believe it was one of the best reports produced by the IAC. The Fraser Government made no response to that report. It ignored its recommendations entirely. However, if it had adopted the major recommendations when in government, we would now be five years down the ten year track of that general reduction in tariffs across the board. The report's major recommendation was for a ten-year gradual reduction of all tariffs within Australia to a uniform level so that there was no particular sector or any particular industry within Australia which was favoured in competition with any other industry. Hence, industries, in terms of attracting capital and investment, would do so on the basis of their productivity and not on the basis of what type of tariff support they happened to get from some previous government or some previous friend in government. I believe if the Government had put all sectors and industries on that competitive basis over a ten-year period, we would have made probably one of the most significant contributions to the rural sector in Australia. The previous Fraser Government did absolutely nothing. This Government at least has taken some steps, unfortunately very few, but it certainly has not adopted that general recommendation from the IAC.

The Government has made some statements on the rural adjustment scheme. It seems to me that there is still room-there is no mention of this-to rectify the major administrative inefficiencies occurring within that rural adjustment scheme. However, I do welcome the moves the Government has made with regard to that scheme and the additional support it has sought to supply.

I have already referred to the general point with regard to tariffs and bounties. In my 1984 statement, I pointed out that the Australian Democrats would have, as a priority, bounty forms of assistance. I welcome the Government's move in that direction in this statement. I think it is an excellent suggestion and an excellent move. Bounties, of course, do not have the type of significant impact that tariffs have. Bounties have an additional benefit, which is that bounties appear in a Budget somewhere. They are up front, they are on the notice paper and they are in the cheque book. We are paying for them and one of the major objections I have to tariffs is that we never see the cost of them because they are constantly hidden from public scrutiny and public view. Bounties can at least be directed. They are a significantly more flexible instrument to deal with than tariffs, particularly with regard to the rural sector, and I am pleased to see that the Government is now moving in that direction. I hope that it may continue that forward progressive movement.

Likewise, in the 1984 statement I maintained that there should be a removal of the tariff on all grain harvesters and other assistance to be provided by way of bounty. The Government has not taken that step, but it has actually made some steps down that road. I hope it will move further. Likewise, I maintained that there should be an extension of the tariff bounty to bona fide agricultural tractors and the removal of import tariffs on agricultural and veterinary chemicals. The Government has made moves in respect of agricultural and veterinary chemicals and the Australian Democrats welcome those moves to reduce significantly the import tariffs.

The next area I raised was that of income equalisation and taxation measures. On behalf of the Democrats in that campaign I maintained we should have continued tax averaging arrangements to ensure that taxpayers with unstable incomes were not disadvantaged by the progressive taxation arrangements. With a view to implementing that, we maintained that there was a need for the reintroduction of a genuine income tax equalisation deposit scheme so that, firstly, the income equalisation deposits are deductible from taxation income in the year of deposit; secondly, interest rates are linked to a two year bond rate; thirdly, interest was payable on the investment component of the deposit where the investment component is equal to the balance of the deposit if tax were payable in the year of deposit; and, fourthly, safeguards were imposed to avoid IEDs as a tax avoidance measure. I think it is of enormous regret that this chamber assisted this Government in the destruction of the income equalisation deposits.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a pity.
—It indeed was, when the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia voted to assist the Government to destroy those effective deposits. I believe--
—We gave the Government its Budget.
—Senator Boswell voted on a Bill. It was not even in the Budget.
—It was in the Budget. It was a Budget Bill.

—It was not a Budget Bill. I think it is very good that the Liberal and National parties have subsequently seen the error of their ways and are willing to look at those money Bills in a much more rational way.
—Tell us how you voted on the assets test.
—I did not vote for the assets test and Senator MacGibbon knows that.
—Because you hid under your bed. You were not in the chamber. You were not in the Parliament that day.
—Order! The matter before the Chair is a rural debate.

—Senator MacGibbon is very large on words and very little on ideas. Income equalisation deposits, which were destroyed by the Liberal and National parties voting with the Government, I believe need to be reintroduced. Unfortunately, there is no such reintroduction mooted in this particular statement and I think we will find significant problems in time to come without some type of scheme such as that to assist those unstable incomes-incomes where there is high income in one year and low income in another year. Without some method such as an income equalisation deposit I think that rural incomes will be significantly affected by paying higher taxes in the good years and, of course, paying no taxes or very little taxes in the bad years, but that hardly compensates.

SPEECH.PARA: The indexation of progressive tax schedules to offset the effects of inflation, which was one of the progressive measures introduced by the Fraser Government and which it unfortunately took back, is an ideal that we will probably not see attempted again for quite some time. I think that is a pity because we have what I think Mr Fraser referred to in one of the election campaigns as, taxation by stealth by simply those taxation schedules operating in terms of inflation to move people into higher and higher brackets of taxation.

The next point in that campaign was that we believed there should be a complete revision of the stock evaluation sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act to take account of the differing needs and realities of different forms of primary production, including horticulture. I certainly welcome the Government's moves in this regard in this statement. It is an area which, unfortunately, has languished. It is one which, unfortunately, very little attention has been paid to in the past. I must admit that I was quite surprised to see that the Government had, in fact, moved in this area. It is something that I have raised on a number of occasions and I believe it will have some quite significant effects, with regard to that particular area. It is of a more technical concern, I think; nevertheless, a very important step forward and a step in the right direction.

There needs to be, of course, the inclusion of horticulture in the definition of primary production in the Income Tax Assessment Act. Although that is not specifically mentioned in the statement, a reading of the statement does suggest that the Government intends to look in that direction in the Budget session. I hope that we may see that particular advance take place. I also believe there should be an expansion of the zone allowances into some meaningful form based on the part of the tax dollar which is forgone by people who live in rural sectors. An example of that may well be that a very large amount of money is spent in the area of arts and very little is spent in country areas. It seems to me an effective zone allowance should make a distinction for that amount of money. That money should then be returned by way of a zone allowance to the taxpayers in rural areas to enable them to purchase the things which are provided free of charge by government and government departments to the urban population of Australia. Under the rural population section of the statement I made in 1984 there is an essential part of economic planning-provision to encourage people who wish to remain living and working on the land and in rural towns and cities to do so. This would apply specifically to young people and to services such as education, health, dental care, economic and legal services. People must be assisted to keep the jobs they want to do rather than be given unemployment benefits.

I welcome the first major movement in this area that the Government has taken to actually look at the rural communities as such and to look at the types of services which are provided to rural communities. It is a significant point. If one visits the outback towns of Australia one finds a significant number of professional and semi-professional areas. Jobs are available and since employers cannot pay any more than the normal type of wages which are going in the cities, they are unable to attract people to those jobs. Is it any wonder that councils in the west of Queensland find it very difficult to get shire clerks? The amount these councils offer is the same as on the coast, yet there are significant disadvantages in shire clerks taking their families to the western areas, not the least of which relates to education, dental care and health. The added burden on a person taking his family to those areas is such that he finds it better to stay in a job on the coast which is not paid as much, but his total income is actually higher than if he actually took promotion and went inland. Many of the councils are having to find money from other parts of their budget to be able to offer inducements to people to take those jobs. They are having to pay salaries way above those which are paid by other councils, hence to the detriment of the types of services they are able to offer in other areas. I welcome the Government's move in these directions. I think it is a significant move to look at people who are involved in the area. Too often when we talk about rural industries we seem to talk only about the animals or the industries. We welcome the Government's move to actually talk about the people who are involved in those areas.

I turn my attention now to the next section of the statement I have made; that is, fuel, transport, storage and handling. I raised the point that there should be an effective fuel cost equalisation scheme, which we do not have. Although some comments are made about this in the government's statement, there are no significant moves in that regard. The Government announced a rebate for fuel excise for fuel used for off-road purposes and the full flow-on of the gains that were made from the lower international fuel prices. However, I am looking down the track at other excises currently on fuel. I think the removal of those excises would remove a significant impost on the rural sector.

The next point that arose is the development of a national transport development program embracing the requirements of an expanding agricultural sector. Such a strategy needs to take account of the requirement to move produce quickly and economically from the point of production to the point of use. The Fraser Government, in its bicentennial program, which is being carried on by the current government, had that as one of its aims. Hopefully, the continuation of that program will go a long way to assisting in the transportation of goods. However, there are major deficiencies still in the area of the transportation, in particular, of wheat. The Government has made the promise that it will look at the royal commission with regard to the wheat industry, particularly in terms of the handling of wheat. I suppose that has to be taken at its value. Hopefully that royal commission will do its job and will report to the Government as rapidly as possible. I hope, when the Government looks at that matter, it will look at the more general aspect of transportation of products with regard to the wheat industry in particular. Hopefully this will be carried over into other areas.

We also campaigned for a significant reduction of air navigation charges for light aircraft in rural areas. The general aviation sector of the aircraft industry is used out west, as it were, as taxis. Significant imposts and charges which come from those higher costs flow through from the avgas prices. I believe that there should be a removal and a lessening of those costs, but more importantly a significant reduction in the general aviation charges. The general aviation area does not by any stretch of the imagination use the type of star wars technology which is provided at all our major airports for most domestic flights. I believe that the vast bulk of the general aviation usage in rural areas is often between one property and another and on dirt strips or on other types of low grade landing areas that do not require enormous upkeep. Out of fairness to that sector, a substantial reduction in the air navigation charges is warranted. Likewise, as part of the continuing campaign the Australian Democrats proposed the abolition of sales tax on freight. We presented a detailed program to the Fraser Government, which rejected it. We presented the program again to the Hawke Government, which rejected it. I still believe it is an iniquitous operation where sales tax is added on top of tax. I believe that a method has to be used to overcome that problem. Again, there is no mention of that in this particular report.

Under the heading `Weather' I made the point at the Rural Press Club that there needs to be the establishment of a permanent drought and natural disaster scheme as part of a general national disaster fund. The scheme should include insurance against weather and fire damage to crops, pastures, animals and property. Since that time the industry has made steady moves towards establishing an industry-wide insurance scheme. The results I have seen to date look very encouraging. Hopefully that will come to fruition in time. However, I think the Government has a role to play here. The types of genuflections that have been made in this report in that direction are few and far between. It is a very important area. Drought assistance ought to be given when we do not have droughts rather than when we do have droughts. When we do have droughts we have to throw money around simply for survival. Undoubtedly most of the money goes to the farmers who are most inefficient than to the most efficient farmers because the most efficient farmers have spent money on drought-proofing and other types of activities, and they are further down the line when that money is handed out during drought relief. I believe drought relief ought to be done when we do not have a drought. By doing it that way we are supporting the efficient farmer rather than the inefficient farmer.

With regard to research, there is some quite significant pickup. The point I made at that time was that priority be given to upgrading rural research and ensuring real increases in research funding. The Government has done that. I applaud the Government for the significant advances it has made in that particular area in this statement. I also made the point that there should be implementation of a flexible policy in relation to the responsibility for research so that the particular industry decides whether marketing boards are to be responsible for research or separate research boards should be established. A statement was made earlier this year in regard to research boards. The Australian Democrats generally support the thrust of the Government with one major reservation: We believe that the retention of industry-elected representatives on those research boards is absolutely vital for the dissemination of research. Without that I believe that research may very well be done but not sold to the people who have to use it. The best people to sell it are the representatives who are elected to those research boards by the industry bodies themselves.

The Government has made significant contributions in the statement with regard to tech- nology and biology. The Australian Democrats welcome the significant moves that the Government has made in these areas. The points made by the Minister is this respect are almost identical to the ones that I raised in a speech I made in 1984. Due to the shortness of time I do not intend to pursue them now.

In the market development area, the Government has, of course, set down in other statements its policy in regard to flexible marketing boards. The policy that the Australian Democrats have maintained-in fact the Government has had to fall in line with this policy on each occasion it has attempted to deviate-is that there should always be a majority of industry representatives on the marketing boards. After all, the industry pays half the cost of the operation of the boards and they are the people who are most intimately involved. We believe that they are the residential experts in most of these areas. While the Government has moved to replace some of the board members with experts, we are happy to go along with it as long as the experts are also growers, as in most cases they are.

Further, in terms of market development, we maintain that agricultural attaches and marketing intelligence officers should be appointed to serve in key markets, such as the United States of America, Japan and the Middle East, with the specific tasks of assisting with the promotion of Australia's rural produce and the reduction of overseas barriers to Australian rural exports. Quite frankly, in many ways I believe that these people are more important than military attaches. We seem to be able to afford them but not these people. It is a pity. Reference is made to this matter in two different parts of the Minister's long statement, neither of which goes as far as I would like in terms of the development of that policy.

Further, of course, we should be looking at the development of a Pacific economic community with an understanding to increase the negotiating skills of member countries, particularly in the global trade negotiations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade-of course, we are now into a new round of GATT-the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, which is a very important forum for Australia. There needs to be improved communications with European Economic Community consumers. I hope that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his current trip abroad to the United States of America and the EEC has more effect than the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) have had. One can only hope that he will, because no matter how efficient we become in Australia, unfortunately the European Community has a stockpile of most of the goods we wish to sell. It is able to make a profit on whatever it sells them for because it has already paid the going price. We are really in difficulties in that area and there is almost nothing we can do. Hopefully, the Prime Minister will be able to do as much as can be done.

There needs to be a recognition that sectoral assistance to either import competing industries or selective export industries should be paid for by the traditional unassisted exporters. A major element in our export strategy should be to provide a uniform level of assistance to all export and import competing industries. Neither this Government nor the previous Government has given that uniform support. Although it is not mentioned in the Minister's statement, I believe it is an essential element that we must ultimately pursue.

Obviously there needs to be a complete revision of the export inspection charges to ensure that they are imposed only when the inspection is required by the importing country. The rates should be flexible in accordance with the standard of inspection required, and they should be imposed to take account of the export incentives given to our major rivals in export markets which impose charges.

As I say, the Government has raised a number of matters in the statement. Finally, I would like to refer to the move by the Government in regard to farm loss quarantining. I am happy to see that the discussions I have held with the Government over the last four months have paid off in some respect. As a result of the evidence which has become available, I think that the Government ultimately saw that the stance it had taken was misguided and misdirected. I think that many people are relieved that the Government has jettisoned the wide brush approach that it had taken and has looked rather at a specific type of approach to pick up any type of tax rorts that may very well be going on. I have maintained in my discussions with the Government that if it knows where those tax rorts are, it should go out now and prosecute the people involved under existing laws, because undoubtedly what is happening is illegal.

Finally, we welcome the Government's rural policy. It is useful to have the basis on which a debate can take place. Hopefully we will be able to have an informed debate on the Government's policy again in the very near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment moved by Senator Collard, as will all Liberal Party and National Party senators. Unlike the previous speaker, Senator Macklin, I hope that the Parliament does not get any more reports of this nature, because nothing of any benefit at all has been given to rural Australia. I do not find it surprising that the Australian Democrats do not know what to do when they are presented with a statement such as the one made by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). As the quintessential urban dwellers, they have never had any experience, let alone any comprehension or understanding, of what is involved in rural production or the rural industries in Australia. But above all, this report is the saddest of all statements ever presented in this Parliament. It is a dying dirge from a failed Minister. The report is untruthful, it is patronising and it is irrelevant to the needs of rural Australia. Above all, it is an enormously tedious document. It takes 40 pages to say what could well be said in four. As I said earlier, it gives no support or solid comfort to those people who are trying to earn a living off the land in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard this morning a radio broadcast in which it was said that this statement would provide, on average, about $5 a week for every farmer in the country. I do not know whether that figure is accurate. But if it is accurate, it is probably equivalent to giving every pensioner 50c a week.

It is 40 pages of a very crude political propaganda exercise. As I said before, it patronises, and it thereby demeans, those people who work on the land. It narcissistically praises what the author sees as the achievement of the Hawke Government. Mr Kerin was a Minister of considerable promise when he took over his portfolio. He went around. He travelled a lot. He travelled far more than did any other Labor Minister for Primary Industry that I have known. He listened to people. He was well respected and liked in rural Australia. But in the three years he has been in office as Minister, he has shown himself to be incapable of taking any protective action, let alone a constructive action, for the people he has to look after under his portfolio. He has become very much the Barry Jones of the rural world. He is great on words, but one should not look to him for performance.

I would like to look briefly at the 40-page statement. I will not bore the Senate by wading through all of it; I will just pick some of the highlights. We start with the selective use of figures from a Bureau of Agricultural Economics report on the troubles of rural Australia. The Minister lists a projected fall of 21 per cent in 1985-86 with a further 21 per cent fall in 1986-87. He conveniently neglects to say that under his stewardship there was a 13 per cent decline last year. So we are really in an enormously steep downturn. According to the Minister, average farm income will fall by 66 per cent. Which senator sitting on the other side of the chamber will take a 66 per cent cut in his income this year? How many members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions will pad up to the Prime Minister's office and say: `Please, Prime Minister, I want only 66 per cent of my wages as is given to my brothers in the rural world'? The Minister passes that over quite blithely as just a statistic of no account.

The Minister then talks about what is going wrong or which branches of rural Australia are going to be concerned in the decline of incomes-the grain producers and the sheep producers. He then makes the statement that at least the income of beef producers will be 10 per cent more this year. Does he not open his eyes when he is driving in his air-conditioned LTD from Canberra Airport to Parliament House? We are in the early stages of a drought which grips the whole eastern half of Australia. That has as much an impact on the beef producers of this country as it has on the grain growers and the sheep producers. The Minister has only to open the newspapers and look at the cattle sales to realise that graziers are liquidating stock. They are selling stock that are only half finished to get money for them before they die on their hands as a result of the coming drought.

I turn to page 7 of the Minister's statement and note the sophistry involved there under the delightful heading `causes of the problem'. Like a bad workman, the Minister blames his tools; the fault is everyone else's but the Labor Government's. He blames principally the lack of overseas markets or the fall in prices in overseas markets. It is true that they have some part in it, but many of the problems for rural Australia come from the inability of this Government to control the costs that rural Australia bears. It is for the Minister to dominate the difficulties, not to be dominated by them, as he is so obviously in this document. He blames everyone but himself and his Government for the sins that have been foisted upon us in rural Australia.

The handicaps that one faces on the land really come from the actions of the trade union movement, because 80 per cent of all the costs on a farm come from off-farm sources. They are not generated by the way a property is managed and run; they come from goods and services that the farmer or grazier has to have to operate. Forty per cent of the cost of all those goods and services come from freight costs. The nonsense of a couple of weeks ago when the Transport Workers Union went on strike over no issue at all and held up the airlines resulted in an on-cost to the rural producer.

We look in vain for any realistic economic assessment of what is going on from the statement from Minister Kerin. All we get is some very muddled thinking about overseas markets and tariffs. We find in it the typical approach of the Labor Party of putting up all its sacred cows, such as the over-valued dollar. It is not so very long ago that, under the Fraser Government, $US1.25 equalled the Australian dollar. Today, it is floating around the 70c mark. It is not correct for the Minister to claim that the Government, with its economic genius, has arrived at a true value for the dollar, not an over-valued figure. The figure of 70c has been set because that is all the money people overseas think our dollar is worth. They think it is worth nearly half what they thought the Fraser dollar was worth. The Minister went on with some statements about how it was a good float. The actual fact of the matter is that even at the 70c figure it is propped up through the Reserve Bank and is very much a dirty float.

I turn to page 20 of the Minister's statement and the removal of the proposal to quarantine farm losses, something which has had an enormous impact on the rural community. It was an iniquitous move of the Government to think it could ever bring that proposal in and isolate one section of Australia's commerce. It does not matter what other field of commercial activity one is engaged in, such as running a brickworks or a pie shop, one can transfer losses from one business venture to another. There is something about rural activities that led the Government to move against their sacred cow and say it was bad. Fortunately, it now seems to have backed off, but it has backed off in a very ambivalent way. I quote from page 20 of the Minister's statement:
The Government has reviewed the matter, and in the light of some potential inequities, has decided not to proceed with this measure but to pursue an alternative approach.

This Parliament has never been told what that alternative approach will be, but I think the presumption can be made that the Government will use some smart lawyer trick to try to get to the same objective by slightly different means.

I turn to the selling Australia's rural products. There was some praise on page 24 for what I presume was the last trip overseas of the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins. Let me just put this matter in perspective. I lived in Europe for a long while and I saw generations of Australian politicians and public servants trying to sell agricultural produce in that milieu before the Common Market came into being. They came as raw boys from the bush. They did not sell very much at all. I think there has been an improvement in the approach of Australian authorities to Europe, but when Mr Dawkins came along we had a total relapse back to the worst of the wild colonial boy days.

Mr Dawkins was in Europe shouting and screaming, saying to the Europeans: `Why don't you dismantle the common agricultural policy? Why won't you buy our produce?' I do not think a product can be sold with rudeness. I do not think products can be sold in a rush. If people such as Mr Dawkins are chosen as the agents of this Government to represent Australia abroad, we will simply lose the markets we have at present, let alone develop new ones.
