One cannot operate in the way Mr Dawkins operated on his last trip to Europe.

This is a symptom of a larger issue involving this Government. As Senator Collard said, we get nearly 40 per cent of our export earnings from primary production and the maintenance and development of those markets is crucially important to us. We have competitors and those competitors are the European Common Market and the United States. It is a fair comment to say that this Government does not understand what it is up against. It does not understand what is involved in the common agricultural policy in Europe. It does not understand what is involved in the United States Farm Bill. We have to be efficient to compete with those subsidising nations overseas, because they are going to go on producing. There is nothing we can do to stop them. So what we have to do is cut back the union demands which I was talking about before and which amount to 80 per cent of the costs that a farmer has to meet in producing his product. We have to get the cost of production as competitive as we can.

For the information of the Senate, I wish to put a couple of points about the common agricultural policy and the United States Farm Bill. This year alone Britain is spending #2.2 billion on its farm bill-that is $4.4 billion in price support for its farmers. That is almost twice the farmers' own income. That is reflected right across the board of the common agricultural policy. That policy is directed to producing in quantity, not in quality. Farmers do not try to improve the grades of anything they produce; they just go for bulk numbers because they are being paid per unit of production, whatever that is. The Common Market does not look at things that it is short of. It has chronic shortages of products such as timber. If it is going to subsidise agriculture it should be looking at developing a timber industry to overcome some of its importing needs.

It also does a whole lot of illogical things, such as paying a great deal of money to produce milk and then spending even more money on buying electricity to boil the water out of the milk and create a mountain of even more highly expensive skim milk. The illogicalities really do not matter because the cost per average citizen in the Common Market is very low. I think the figure-I could be wrong-is about $35 a year. What it costs the average person under the common agricultural policy is peanuts. However illogical, however unfair and however unreasonable it may be, it is just a fact of the market-place, and we have to get in there and compete against it. What do we do? We send someone such as Mr Dawkins to carry on like a spoiled child who has lost his teddy.

The United States Farm Bill is another matter of very great significance to us. It was passed in the latter part of last year and signed into law by the President in December 1985. It will run for five years, but in its first three years $US52 billion will be provided to rural producers in the United States. That is almost as much in handouts over three years as our entire Federal Budget for one year. In private conversations I had with senior people in the Department of Agriculture in Washington this year the view of public servants at a senior level is that the realistic figure will not be $US52 billion but will amount to at least $US74 billion or $US75 billion over those three years.

What has the Australian Government done? It has sent the Prime Minister away this week to try to negotiate our way out of the position of conflict with the United States agricultural juggernaut that we are facing. That is too little, and it is too late. The United States State Department representatives both in Canberra and in the consulates around Australia were telling people in Australia who were prepared to listen quite publicly that this Bill would be introduced through last year. It was introduced to help the US farmers as a counter to the subsidies coming from the common agricultural policy. There was no secrecy, least of all there was no ambush, in what the United States was going to do. It told everyone what it intended to do. But this Government, which is responsible for our management and welfare, did not do a damn thing about it. It took no notice. It did not perhaps understand that what was being said to it was a matter of vital importance to us, as 40 per cent of our exports are now at risk because of the inability and incompetence of the Hawke Labor Government.

When the Bill was signed into law by the President in December there was a great flurry of activity in the embassy in Washington. Agricultural people from the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs talked to the Americans. There was a general running around. But it has now reached the level at which one cannot do a thing through the normal diplomatic channels. It has reached such a level that only the Prime Minister can cope with it. However what the President can do now that the Bill has been signed into law is very limited. He simply has no flexibility in this matter. The Prime Minister should have been talking directly to the President before the Bill hit Congress and when the Bill hit Congress. Now he goes there as a stained Prime Minister who yesterday wanted to have two bob each way, and who would not support the Americans in their foreign policy. What sort of hearing will he get when he goes to Washington?

TALK.START.PARA: —Very short.

—Very short. That is quite right. In conclusion, this statement is a cynical exercise by the Government. The Government just does not care about rural Australia. It has done its sums and it knows very well that it cannot win one more seat in the country areas. It is a simple mercenary exercise. This is very sad because, as I said earlier, 40 per cent of our export earnings are involved in rural production. The Government has put us in a debt position that has never before been equalled in the history of this country. Our capacity to service that debt is diminishing day by day. As I think of Mr Kerin and Mr Hawke, the words of Lawson come back to me. They fit very well in the case of both Kerin and Hawke. Lawson wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: You'd better stick to Sydney and make merry with the push. For the bush will never suit you and you'll never suit the bush.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment that has been moved by my colleague the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Senator Collard. I say to the Senate that, since the Australian Labor Party came to office barely three years ago, it has ripped $442m from the primary industries of Australia. In a pathetic attempt to win back some lost ground, the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, produced a 43-page document full of Labor Party rhetoric, telling the farmers what was the cause of the problem. I can tell Mr Kerin that everyone involved in primary industry knows the cause of the problem. The Labor Party has been the cause of the problem for three years, during which time it has removed $442m from the pockets of the farmers of Australia. The farmers of Australia are reacting. Honourable senators will have seen their reaction. They will march tomorrow. They were marching last week, and they will go all out throughout Australia. Senator Grimes laughs about the plight of the rural industry. He sits there and laughs about the farmers who are going broke. We are not laughing about them. We are concerned about the farmers. Since the May mini-budget in 1983, 43 benefits have been removed. Four pages of benefits have been taken from the farmers that have cost $442m. We have seen so many broken promises. I refer to the broken promises on capital gains, fringe benefits and water. The list goes on and on. Probably the worst broken promise of all is the one that I want to talk about tonight-the broken promise to the sugar industry of Australia. Three years ago, in 1983, the Labor Party promised a price support scheme. In 1984 the Prime Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I undertake on behalf of the Federal Government, to you and to the industry, that we will undertake the financial commitment to assist you on the basis that the review-which is accelerated as a result of co-operation with the State Government-move towards drawing up an overall package which is going to result in a strong and viable industry.

That is typical Hawke doublespeak. The rural package is a sell-out to the sugar industry. Farmers have been waiting for three years to get some measure of help from this Federal Government. What have they seen? Let us examine this package that has been presented. Over the past three years the Federal Government has put in a lousy $15m. All we have heard from the Labor Party is that the Queensland Government will not co-operate, or that the Premier will not co-operate. But let us find out what the Premier and the Queensland Government have done. The Queensland Government has put in $72m compared with the Federal Government's lousy $15m. It should be noted that the Federal Labor Government receives $60m in excise from the rum industry alone. So it could well afford to support the sugar industry.

If we examine the sugar package, it is the greatest doublecross since Judas Iscariot took his 30 pieces of silver. In the latest package, this package which has been presented, $54m is allocated to the sugar industry to support a price scheme of $230, $225 and $220 a tonne for the years 1985, 1986 and 1987. Today the price of sugar on the London market was approximately $223 a tonne and rising. Under the package that was brought down yesterday the Government will have to outlay only $17m of the $54m to support the 1985 price of $230 a tonne. So let us look at the situation now. The Government's promise of $150m to the sugar industry has been reduced in the package to $100m. We then see that price support now is reduced to $63m which is made up of $17m price support and $46m rural adjustment. It is a commitment of $63m over a three-year period. The Government is getting $60m a year from excise on rum. If that is not a sell-out to the sugar industry, I do not know what is. It is a Clayton's offer and once again proves that Labor Party promises to rural Australia are not worth the paper they are written on. Mr Kerin has no integrity and Mr Hawke is a trickster.

All sections of the Queensland industry are in agreement with the Queensland Government proposal on sugar. The sugar industry on 6 March this year moved a motion stating that price support was a Federal government responsibility. All sections of the industry-millers and growers-agreed with the Queensland Government's proposal. They know that Queensland has the runs on the board. It has already put in $72m compared with $15m of Federal funds. It has promised another $170m over the next three years, including $50m in direct grants. What has the Federal Government put in? It has put in $63m over three years. The sugarcane farmers of Queensland will rise up and wipe the Labor Party out of north Queensland. The Bjelke- Petersen Government has given a total commitment to the sugarcane growers of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let him put his money where his mouth is.

—He has put his money where his mouth is. The Federal Government's mouth is open to the tune of $15m at the moment, and his Government has put in $72m. Government senators may laugh about it, but they will not be laughing too hard when the Australian Labor Party is wiped out of Leichhardt and Herbert and loses all its State seats in northern Queensland. Let us see how they laugh then because the sugar cane farmers are not so susceptible that they will fall for this nonsense. I predict now that the ALP will lose the north Queensland seat of Leichhardt. Mr Gayler, the member, has not fought for the Queensland industry or, if he has, he is a lightweight and he has been ignored. He can pack his bags because he is gone. The member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, has not been worth two bob to north Queensland and he will go too. Senator Reynolds will be the lone Federal Labor voice in north Queensland after the next election. I suggest that since she has been in the Federal Parliament she has been so busy attacking the Queensland Government that she has not been performing her duties. She has not ensured that the people of north Queensland have received the appropriate slice of the Federal Government cake. I suggest that Senator Reynolds refer this disastrous sugar package to the Human Rights Commission for a report on broken promises, seeing that she is so ready to refer everything that happens in Queensland to the Human Rights Commission. She should put this matter before the Commission, together with a number of other broken promises that the Labor Government has made to the rural industries of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In making this response to the Federal Government's economic and rural policy which was unveiled yesterday by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), I wish to address briefly its impact on the Northern Territory. As my colleagues have pointed out throughout this debate, the crisis in the rural sector is having an impact all over Australia. Not only are the people on the land contending with soaring interest rates-and as we know, in many cases these are more than 20 per cent-the loss of international markets and high wage costs, but they are also now facing an increasingly severe drought. When the present Government came to power much was made of the fact that its election coincided with the breaking of the last drought. It was light-heartedly suggested by some commentators that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, himself was somehow responsible for the end of the drought.
—What do you mean by `somehow'?

—As Senator Grimes has indicated, I believe that there are some people within the Australian Labor Party who took this claim seriously. As one who did not subscribe to that theory, I am not in any position to hold the Prime Minister responsible for the present drought. I accept that this is a natural phenomenon over which none of us has any control.

SPEECH.PARA: However, even if the drought is beyond the control of the Prime Minister or his Government, it is within the capacity of that Government to do something to help those whose livelihoods are threatened by this disaster, as well as by the other factors which are having such a detrimental effect on the rural sector. Unfortunately, the package unveiled yesterday has failed to provide that much hoped for assistance. Reference has already been made to the reaction of the National Farmers Federation to the package. The NFF has bucketed the proposals as not providing any real relief and surely it is the organisation to judge. The disappointment with the rural package expressed by the NFF reflects the feeling of people on the land, and those who make their livelihood on the land in the Northern Territory are no exception. I speak particularly of the area in outback Australia.

Central Australia is again in the grip of drought with, at last count, 51 properties being declared as drought-affected. Two of these properties are in the Victoria River region, 11 in the Barkly Tablelands and 38 in the Alice Springs region. In 1984-85 the cattle turn-off in the Alice Springs pastoral district alone was some 117,046, close to a third of the total cattle population. Drought assistance is being provided by the Northern Territory Government and many more applications for assistance are being assessed.

The Northern Territory branch of the Cattlemen's Association has been fighting very hard for recognition of the drought-affected areas around Alice Springs, the centre of Australia. The Northern Territory Government has recently extended the same provisions to Alice Springs as previously applied to the rest of the Territory. There has been a recognition of the seriousness of the problem in the Territory. Yet, if yesterday's package is anything to go by, the Federal Government is not equally prepared to recognise the facts. I have been out in the drought areas during the past two weeks and some of those areas have not received rain for some two years and four months. That is a very serious situation.

The only benefit to the graziers of the Northern Territory contained in the package is that the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign component of the livestock slaughter levy will be reduced by $1 from $4 to $3. This will represent a saving to the industry of about $6m per annum. While the cattlemen would welcome that, even the Minister acknowledges that this is only returning to the industry its own money. It is also important to bear in mind that the BTEC scheme has been quite successful and it would be expected anyhow that it would begin to wind down shortly, thus less money would be needed to fund the scheme in any case. That is not much of a sacrifice for the Federal Government and the Treasury. Yet the Minister is patting himself on the back for coming up with this `generous' arrangement.

The other potentially beneficial aspect of the package is the amendment of section 36aaa of the Tax Assessment Act which will permit profit from the sale or destruction of animals for BTEC purposes to be offset on a herd for herd basis and to be assessed as income over 10 years. The present situation requires that restocking be undertaken within five years. With the exception of these two matters, there is little in the package for the graziers in outback Australia. Tariff concessions apply only to agriculturalists, such as wheat producers, and good luck to them too. It does not extend to the pastoralists or graziers in the outback. The big impact upon farm profitability which the Government claims this package will have will just not occur. The package will have little impact.

If the Government is serious about assisting the men and women who are presently struggling to stay on the land and produce the products that are so vital to Australia's economy, I respectfully suggest that it might start by abandoning its proposed capital gains tax. As a next step, in view of the economic difficulties presently faced by pastoralists who, as a result of the drought, are being forced to sell off large amounts of stock-and we have had some discussion on this matter this evening-the Government should move to reinstate all the provisions of the income equalisation scheme which used to operate to reduce the impact of this sort of situation. We have heard tonight that this used to be in being but it has been withdrawn. Pastoralists who are forced to sell off this stock naturally generate uncharacteristically high incomes in those years when they actually sell. We have seen this over the past two years. Under the old income equalisation scheme the pastoralist was able to set the money from the sale of stock aside and draw upon it in subsequent years when his income was far lower as a result of his having sold off his income generating capacity because of the drought. Tax was not payable on the income in the year of the sale of the stock, but was spread out over the following years and paid on the money as it was withdrawn and utilised to support the pastoralist and eventually, when things began to look up, to restock the property. This meant that the tax burden on the pastoralist was reduced at a particularly difficult time. Of course, tax still had to be paid. There was no question of avoidance of tax liability. The scheme was a sensible means by which the man on the land could be assisted in times of economic difficulty. Not only did it assist the man on the land, but it was also of assistance to the nation.

Yet the Labor Party did away with the scheme when it came to government. If the Government's rationale was that the drought had broken and the legislation was no longer required, then I suggest that, in view of the fact that the drought is back, the time has come to reintroduce the scheme. At least it allowed pastoralists to get back on their feet once the worst of the drought had passed. Unless the scheme is reintroduced, there is a risk that this time round pastoralists may have no means by which to pull themselves out of the hole which is created by the drought. They will simply be forced to walk away from the land. That is already happening in the eastern States, particularly on smaller properties. According to the National Australia Bank's study earlier this month, 7 per cent of farmers will find it difficult to survive in the short term and 20 per cent can be expected to be in difficulties in the longer term. The fact is that we are in the hands of `old man drought' and this is affecting all States of Australia. In addition to assisting those farmers who are already in difficulties, the Federal Government must take action to assist those who could and will fall victim to the drought which is settling on this country. An income equalisation scheme is essential if pastoralists and other primary producers are to weather the storm. I urge the Government to reintroduce such a scheme immediately. As I have said before, while this scheme would help the man on the land, it would also help the Government and the nation in the long run. I believe that it is most necessary that this scheme be reintroduced.

I am interested also in the development of rural banks in Australia, including the Victorian Rural Bank. The Commonwealth and State governments have rural banks. The Northern Territory at present does not have a rural bank, but I would like to see one encouraged by the Northern Territory Government because I believe that rural banks have a responsibility to the people on the land, particularly in times of drought. The many schemes which are available now for assistance to the man on the land should be gathered into one group under a rural bank.

This package does not offer much hope, but I believe that there is scope for the Federal Government to take more action because there are ways and means of helping farmers and pastoralists. I hope that the Federal Government, having been told by the National Farmers Federation that the package is not sufficient, will now take real and effective measures to do something to help the man on the land. This paper obviously has not gone far enough, but many thoughts have been put forward in this debate in the interests of all and I hope that something will be gathered out of this debate and put into practice by the Federal Government. I again go back to my suggestion that the income equalisation scheme which was operating, and I believe operating well, should be reintroduced. I believe that all honourable senators believe that the rural industry is, and has been for many decades, the real heart of Australia on which our future prosperity is dependent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the positive contribution of Senator Kilgariff. While Senator Kilgariff was very positive, we found that Senator Boswell had absolutely nothing to contribute. All he had to say was negative, negative, negative. That is appropriate for the Queensland members of the National Party of Australia. Senator Boswell's Party, which cannot come up with anything positive for the rural sector, dares to send representatives into this place-few as they are-and all they can do is stand up and carp and complain about this extensive package. If Senator Boswell is prepared to come back into this place-I note that he has run away-and say that the National Party will vote against this package and will not allow any of these positive proposals to go through, the people listening might consider that Senator Boswell is prepared to put his money where his mouth is.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that it does not matter what the Government does because there will be groups in the community-interest groups and lobby groups-which will say, as Senator Kilgariff did, that the Government's package on this or any other issue does not go far enough. That is the job of lobby groups; to make their demands and to put forward the issues of concern to the people they represent. I support their democratic right to do that, but not to just dismiss this entire document of some 15 chapters of commitment to the rural sector and say: `Take it, we do not want anything to do with it. Take back in excess of $200m and give it to someone else; provincial Australia is not interested'. That is totally unrealistic and simply demonstrates that the National Party is no longer committed to rural Australia. I am not the only person who believes that the National Party, especially in Queensland, no longer represents the interest of the rural sector. I should know because I spend more time than many people on the other side in rural Queensland. Honourable senators should remember that my only colleague on the other side who bothers to live in rural Queensland is Senator Collard. Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Boswell spend most of their time in Brisbane; their offices are in Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: —I live in rural Queensland.

—Where is the honourable senator's office? If she is so concerned about the rural sector in Queensland why does she not have an office in Kingaroy, out there in rural Australia where she is needed? I next come to the views of the people in rural Queensland in regard to the Queensland National Party. I refer to a document prepared by the James Cook University entitled `Sugar People Take a Caning-A report on the impact of the decline of the sugar industry on families in the Mulgrave Shire, North Queensland'. I have quoted from this document previously in this place, but it seems that I have to repeat it again and again to get the message through to the Queensland National Party that it is not communicating with the rural people in that State.
—Who represents Mulgrave? The National Party.

—I wonder who will represent Mulgrave next time. Senator Sheil was not there when the Queensland Premier was virtually run out of Babinda and Innisfail. Mr Turner, who has been forced to resign because he has not been able to implement sensible policies to rescue the sugar industry, had to come to the rescue of the Premier because he was almost drummed out of the meeting. I come back to the quote from the report, which comes through again and again. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: `Joh should try to get along better with the federal government' . . . `Unless extra money comes from somewhere we won't survive'.

Again and again through this report comes the message that Queensland people, especially in the rural sector, are fed up with the Queensland National Party not representing their interests. I refer to some of the recommendations and conclusions in relation to the Queensland Government. Senator Boswell is always quick to say that the Federal Government does nothing, even though there is this document. I guess Senator Boswell would not bother to read it-if indeed he can read as extensive a document as this. Let us look at the recommendations of this report which were directed to the Queensland Government and let the members of the Queensland National Party tell me what the Queensland Government is prepared to do in response to these recommendations. The first recommendation states, in relation to the Queensland Government:

Use the powers of the Sugar Board and the Central Sugar Cane Prices Board, to control the production of sugar in accord with advice from the ``Sugar Industry Social and Economic Research and Information Service''. Co-ordinate reductions in sugar production with the Commonwealth scheme to subsidise canegrowers . . .
Subsidise interest payments on loans to canegrowers experiencing financial difficulties . . .
Subsidise interest payments on loans to sugar milling enterprises . . .
Subsidise interest payments on loans to small businesses . . .
Grant concessional railway freight rates on the transport of raw sugar.
Grant concessional railway freight rates for canegrowers on cargo related to sugar production.
Extend increased service to canegrowers through the Queensland Department of Primary Industries . . .

I do not hear anything from the Queensland National Party that indicates that it is listening to recommendations such as those. In fact, all I hear in this place and in Queensland is consistent, carping criticism against the Federal Government. The Federal Hawke Labor Government is the first government to be prepared to set down a comprehensive policy for rural and provincial Australia. Let no one on the opposite side of this chamber forget that fact. Do not come into this place and pretend that this is something that does not count, that this has all happened before. This is a very historic document, but I do not suppose that many honourable senators on the other side of this place have much of a sense of history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they have not read it; they have only had material prepared for them.

—They have not bothered to read it and they do not want to recognise and acknowledge-which at least Senator Kilgariff was prepared to do-that this document is important in making a start in ways that have never been considered by a Federal government before. It is quite disgraceful that members of Parliament who pretend to represent rural Australia-they call themselves the National Party-attempt to say that they are the only people who can represent rural Australia. They have never come up with a document such as this. They have never been prepared to put forward genuine policies for rural and provincial Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I come next to an issue that I am particularly interested in-the role of rural women. Of course, this document recognises rural women. We heard from Senator Boswell in Question Time today that a $100,000 grant scheme was nothing-it was peanuts, if I may be forgiven for the expression-and that rural women did not want $100,000 to help them develop particular programs. I remind Senator Boswell that in 1985, the year of the family, when we had in Queensland a great campaign about how important families were, the Queensland Government, from memory, put up only something like $20,000 for all families in Queensland. Here we are with five times that amount to recognise the needs of rural women, and Senator Boswell comes into this place and says that it is not enough, that they do not want anything to do with it. Has the Queensland Government got a women's policy? No. Has the Queensland Government got any plans to assist rural women? No. Many people in this place would not be aware that almost every mainland government in this country has an Office of the Status of Women under the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-but not in Queensland, because Queensland treats its animals better than it treats women.

When I spoke recently at a rural women's conference in Mount Isa, the women were absolutely horrified to find that in every other mainland State the State Government has introduced a toll-free telephone line for rural women to have direct access to the women's policy co-ordination unit to get information about education, health, employment, law, et cetera. This has been provided for every state except Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a Federal thing. If you are going to have a toll-free telephone, it has to come from the Commonwealth Government, you donkey.
—Oh, Senator Boswell, who pays for it?
—Order! There are too many interjections from my left.

—I say to all those rural women in Queensland that I suggest that, if they really imagine that the National Party Government represents them in rural Queensland, they should make very strong and immediate representations about two things in Queensland: First, recognition of the fact that 51 per cent of the population in Queensland are women; secondly, that there is no women's policy, and no women's programs. All we have is Yvonne Chapman, and the Minister for Welfare Services, harassing single mothers.
—And 80 per cent of the people support her in Queensland.

—I will tell Senator Bos- well something else about 80 per cent, if he really wants to quote that figure. If the honourable senator remembers, 80 per cent was a figure that he was not so proud of last year when the Queensland National Party ordered the seizure of 33,000 medical files from fertility control clinics. Eighty per cent of Queenslanders condemned those raids, so the honourable senator should not quote 80 per cent to me because it seems that he is very selective in using the figure of 80 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I would like to know when the Queensland National Party will develop policies for the rural sector and for women, particularly for rural women.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you go to north Queensland you will be gone.

—As Senator Boswell is so interested in north Queensland, I ask him: When is the Premier going to respond to north Queensland's demands to hold a referendum in regard to a separate State in Queensland? Senator Boswell is keen to represent and speak on behalf of north Queensland, but I do not notice any particular policies in relation to north Queensland, and I do not notice his Premier ever--
—They are looking after the sugar industry. That is the number one priority. That is our policy.
—Senator Boswell, you are interjecting far too much.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I am glad that you are able to acknowledge the common sense that is spoken in this chamber. I ask Senator Boswell: If the Queensland National Party is so committed-
—Senator Reynolds, do not ask Senator Boswell questions, he might reply to them.

—I ask through the Chair for the Queensland National Party to consider this: If the sugar industry is its number one priority; why has it taken since last September to even start to talk sense about what should be done in terms of agreeing to the Federal Government's proposal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my Liberal-National Party colleagues. I strongly support the Opposition's motion of concern at the irrational, illogical, piecemeal and overall unhelpful package of so-called rural measures announced yesterday by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). Let there be no mistake about what the Government has done with this package. It has disgracefully and quite untruthfully absolved itself from any blame for the grave problems being suffered by many rural industries in Australia. It has shown an arrogance towards, and a lack of concern for Australia's rural sector and its people. It has completely ignored the fundamental causes of the problem facing the rural sector, problems I might say that are common to all sectors of Australian industry and economic activity.

SPEECH.PARA: I will illustrate some of these criticisms, but first let me point out just how small in actual volume the package is. The package represents an increase in government expenditure of less than $110m, and $35m of that is to be spread over 10 to 15 years. That increased expenditure compares with an amount of $442m which this Hawke Government has taken away from the rural sector over the three years that it has been in office. As far as being a positive contributor to the rural sector over its period of office, the Hawke Government has been a very significant taker away from the rural sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —An amount of $442m.

—As Senator Brownhill has said, it has taken away $442m. I understand that later in the debate Senator Brownhill will be following up this matter. In addition to that $108m, the Government is claiming credit for another $65m which results from its decision to reverse its earlier decision on the tax quarantining of farm losses. That $65m should not be included in the package at all because it is not something that was in place anyway. We on this side of the House welcome the decision on the quarantining of farm losses.
—But Senator Walsh said today that he might be doing a bit more with it.

—One cannot tell with Senator Walsh and one cannot tell with the Government of today because what it does one day is contrary to what it has said on the preceding day. That is symptomatic of the very grave splits within the Hawke Government in regard to the whole area of economic policy.
—Ha, ha!

—If Senator Zakharov doubts that, I commend to her the totally conflicting statements of Senator Walsh and Mr Kerin in relation to this aspect of the rural policy. As I said, the Opposition welcomes the decision not to go ahead with the quarantining of farm losses. However, it is quite wrong for the Government to say that it has given the rural sector something in that regard. In other words, the package is very small indeed. The benefits it will provide to the average farmer are minuscule.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has absolved itself of any blame for the present rural crisis. The Minister said in his statement:
The simple fact is that adverse world market trends are the reason for the failure of the farm sector to share fully in Australia's general economic growth.
He also said:
Our overall economic policies cannot be blamed--
He said also:
World prices are the problem.
He said:
The problem is not high rural debt levels-

These statements simply are not true. The problem is not just related to adverse world market trends. The problem is a vicious cost-price squeeze on farmers with the cost factor being much more important than the price factor. The cost-price squeeze is due almost solely to the policies of this Government. It is due to a blind adherence to a wage fixing system which has no flexibility and which takes no account of the capacity of the economy to pay. This is despite a situation in which for climatic and other reasons, including Government policies, the real income of the rural sector of this country, which provides 40 per cent of Australia's total exports and which, therefore, is a vital part of the overall funding of our economy, has fallen dramatically over each of the last two years.

The Government has imposed taxes and charges which are at the highest level in our history. Borrowings by the Federal Government mean that every man, woman and child in this nation has an individual personal debt of $7,000. Many of those borrowings have been made to prop up the Australian dollar. The Australian dollar needs propping up because, quite frankly, the rest of the world has lost confidence in Australia and in the value of our currency. Because of the economic and foreign policies of the Hawke Government, Australia's reputation around the world as a reliable supplier of exports, as a safe haven for investment, as a growth economy and as a country in which to invest money, despite the very high borrowings and capital inflow, has been very sadly and very damagingly eroded. It has been damaged by the economic and foreign policies of this Government.

Those borrowings, both domestic and foreign, have pushed real interest rates in Australia to their highest level in at least 60 years. However, Mr Kerin says that the high debt burden is not a problem today in Australian rural economies. What absolute nonsense! The wage burden, the interest rate burden, the tax burden and the government charges burden are all a result of this Government's economic policies. For the Minister to say on behalf of the Hawke Government that the economic policies of this Government have not caused any problems for the rural sector is a statement which every rural producer knows is untrue. Any person with half an ounce of nous in terms of following what is going on in this country knows that that is not true. The matters that concern the rural sector are the basic, fundamental problems facing the Australian economy, an economy which is suffering an inflation rate twice that of the rest of the Western world and which has a current account deficit in its balance of payments of $13 billion to $14 billion a year. As I said, the wages policies are completely inflexible and take no account of capacity to pay. These are the matters that concern the rural sector. These are the matters that the Government should have addressed if it were serious about assisting the rural sector.

The rural sector is not looking for handouts. It has said from day one that it is not looking for handouts. What it is looking for is a government which will take account of the fundamental problems and tackle them in the long term interests of this country. The Government has totally ignored this in its latest statement. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), together with the Premiers of the States and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, launched the first phase of a $100m three-year campaign to combat drug abuse. I feel sure that all honourable senators would agree that something must be done to rid Australia of the menace of the drug threat. I certainly hope that the campaign will be made meaningful and will not be just another gabfest to impress the unwary. The drug problem is one which I have mentioned in this place on other occasions. More usually it is in the context of preventive measures for the north to stop drug runners bringing in their lethal merchandise in the first place. I stand by my earlier calls for increased northern coastal surveillance, which would make life more difficult for drug runners bringing in narcotics from Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: The hard drug problem is not as severe in the Northern Territory as it is in some of the eastern States. However, the Territory has its own particular drug problem, with a higher alcohol consumption rate than the Australian average and with problems such as petrol sniffing in some of the Aboriginal communities. The Select Committee on Volatile Substance Fumes has looked into that aspect and it has now reported. These problems are, of course, of great concern to health workers in the Northern Territory. We are fortunate to have the Northern Territory Drug and Alcohol Bureau, which is researching these problems and looking at ways of reducing them. Recently the Northern Territory Drug and Alcohol Bureau turned its attention to another potential drug threat in the Territory. That threat is a substance called kava and it is this matter which I wish to deal with briefly this evening.

At the outset, I should make clear that there is a good deal of disagreement over the impact of the substance on those who use it. There are some who maintain that it does users no damage, while there are other conflicting reports which indicate that it is having a detrimental effect upon users and the Aboriginal communities to which they belong. Kava is prepared from the plant piper methysticum forst, a tropical shrub of the family piperracea-pepper. The generic name piper comes from the Latin for pepper and the species name methysticum comes from a Greek word meaning intoxicant. The plant has thus become known as the intoxicating pepper. The plant grows naturally throughout Melanesia, Polynesia and Micronesia and it is cultivated for domestic use on many of the islands. The plant is prepared as a beverage either by chewing, grating or pounding of the flesh root until it is fine and fibrous, then soaking the chewed or shredded root in water, which is strained and then drunk. Alternatively, the root and other plant matter is dried and pulverised. The powder is then wrapped in cloth and infused in water, much like a giant tea bag. This is the most common method of preparation today, and in several countries the powder is produced commercially and sold in small bags. I will discuss that in a moment. With both methods, the beverage is usually mixed in a large bowl and shared by a group of drinkers using a single cup.

As to the pharmacological qualities of the drink, the results of extensive animal studies have shown the major pharmacological actions of kava are, firstly, mild, centrally acting relaxant properties which induce generalised muscle relaxation and ultimately a deep natural sleep, and, secondly, local anaesthetic properties which are experienced as a numbing of the mucous membranes of the mouth and tongue when the beverage is drunk. While these descriptions certainly do not represent the substance as a dangerous hard drug, there is increasing evidence that since its introduction into the Northern Territory some years ago, kava, in certain Aboriginal communities in the Arnhem Land, is having a highly detrimental effect upon the people in those communities.

The matter is one which has been under much investigation by the Northern Territory Drug and Alcohol Bureau and it has long been a concern of the Uniting Church in the Territory. Indeed, the Uniting Church has produced an extensive report on the problem. I feel that this report could be most valuable to any person with an interest in the matter. This particular report on the use of kava by Aboriginals in Arnhem Land was prepared by the Board of Church and Community for the Standing Committee of the Northern Synod of the Uniting Church. It has given permission that this report be made public. Therefore, I seek leave to have the paper tabled.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have requested that this report be tabled because I believe it is too long and too comprehensive to have incorporated in Hansard. However, I hope that interested senators will avail themselves of it. Honourable senators are no doubt familiar with the alcohol and petrol sniffing problems of Aboriginal people because, as I said before, this problem has been highlighted in the Senate over this last year.
—A lot of alcohol sniffing goes on over there too.

—It seems to have some effect at times, too, as does petrol sniffing. As I have indicated, in some communities the problems of petrol sniffing are extreme. By comparison, I suppose, kava seems a fairly innocuous substance. Indeed, I believe there are those who feel that, as the lesser of two evils, perhaps it should be ignored. However, even though kava does not induce the violent and aggressive behaviour often associated with alcohol abuse, there are problems associated with its use. To begin with, it costs money, and the money used is that which would otherwise have been spent by communities on food, clothing or some other essential items.

SPEECH.PARA: It also seems that there may be some racketeering going on in the sale of kava, with Sydney and Canberra sources making large profits at the expense of Aboriginal people. In Galuwinku I have been told that kava is referred to as a million dollar industry. It is rather amazing to see that the sale of kava in Arnhem Land has grown to such huge proportions that it really is a million dollar industry. I believe there are people in Sydney and Canberra who are taking a huge rake-off from the sale of kava to the Aboriginal people. When one sees small plastic packets of kava which are sold at something like $10 to $20 a packet and when one sees people purchasing kava by the carton-perhaps 16 to 20 plastic bags to a carton-one can understand the immense amount of money that is going out of a community and into kava.

There is increasing evidence that the use of kava is having a detrimental effect upon Aboriginal children, with adults neglecting their children and preferring to sit around drinking kava. We have heard of this practice over in the islands of Java and such other places. The incidence of nutritional problems in children and the incidence of truancy in communities where kava has a foothold is considerably higher than in other communities because the adults would rather just sit around the kava bowl than look after their children.

There is still a great amount of disagreement over the relative merits or otherwise of the substance. I believe that the Federal Government, together with the Northern Territory Government and perhaps Queensland, should look at examining the qualities of the beverage, its psychological effect upon the users and its social effects upon the people who use it in the Aboriginal communities in the more isolated areas such as Arnhem Land. To that end, I have approached the Federal Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) as well as the Northern Territory Government. The responses I have received indicate that there is a belief that this matter should be monitored. I believe there is sufficient evidence which shows that governments should follow this matter up and I urge honourable senators to take an interest in this matter in order to ensure that no preventable damage to Aboriginal people is allowed to occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening in the news service on the Canberra television station Channel 7 it was stated that at a meeting held yesterday at the new Parliament House I made a statement to the effect that the passing of the recent legislation relating to the Builders Labourers Federation was `a mistake'.

SPEECH.PARA: I did attend a meeting of workers held at the site of the new Parliament House yesterday where I made an ex tempore address. Though it was an ex tempore address, I am confident that my recollection of what I said is accurate. I cannot recall the precise words I used but I said that I supported the Caucus decision in respect of the legislation, that it was proper for me as a politician associated with the legislation to go and see the consequences of it and that the legislation may set an unhappy precedent because unions and workers in general were put at risk in the future of having similar legislation passed against them. I did not say that the legislation was a mistake.

The honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan) in the other place attended the meeting with me. He delivered an address and according to my audience of that address and Mr Duncan's assurances to me, he did not say that the legislation was a mistake. Mr Duncan and I attended the meeting by invitation. We did not arrange it and we were able to stay a short time only as we both had another meeting to attend. Though I have raised this matter, I do not want to make a great issue of it. Of those reports of the meeting, the only one I know of in which I am identified, is the one I have referred to. At meetings which are public and in the open air it is no doubt difficult for reporters to apprehend everything with precision. However, I would like to correct any impression that in a public forum I stated that the Government's legislation was a mistake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address a matter which came to my notice because of the Report on the State of the Automotive Industry 1985 tabled today, which was written by the Automotive Industry Authority. This report is very welcome as it highlights some of the long-term problems which have bugged the Australian car industry for so long and it attempts to address these problems. The problems are not new. In particular, Australia's small local market does not provide economic manufacturing volumes, so our car industry has always required government props. It is the very availability of these props that has made the local industry sufficiently attractive to keep overseas manufacturing companies here. Over the years they have mopped up the indigenous manu- facturers so that now the Australian car manu- facturing industry is totally controlled by subsidiaries of overseas companies; and by too many of these overseas companies anyway. There are essentially three companies and the Government wants two. The total employment in the passenger vehicle and component parts industry has gone down from 1982 to 1985 and the imports of completely built up cars rose last year by 16 per cent, according to the report. The particular drawback is the disincentive to export in competition with the parent company of the operations in Australia and the tendency too look for compensatory handouts from the Australian taxpayer. The Government must solve this problem if Australia is to have a car industry that has a will to export.

SPEECH.PARA: I see the first requirement for a successful car exporting industry as the will to export. I believe that we need to look for increasing control of parts of the industry at least by Australian interests and at getting this industry into Australian hands. To export successfully, Australian industry must compete on open world markets in terms of price, quality and design. Price has always been a hurdle for Australia with such a small domestic market. The only alternative is to offer sufficient advantages so that prices are no longer relevant. Other small countries have successfully built up car manufacturing enterprises. Volvo and Saab in Sweden are shining examples. The quality of the product makes them highly competitive on world markets.

In order for us to establish an export car industry Australia needs, above all, a novel product. Innovation is the key to successful market penetration. No amount of compression of local manufacturers will succeed in exporting, unless they adopt a new design which is unique in world markets. The subsidiary companies of overseas manufacturers do little real research and development in Australia. If a subsidiary develops an innovative product, it is quickly exploited overseas. For export success we need to promote local innovative companies. I welcome the Government's promise of design grants to such enterprises.

I now come to the reason why I have risen to speak in the adjournment debate. While investigating my speech on this report I rang the Sarich orbital engine company in Western Australia. We already have a very innovative product in the Sarich orbital engine. This engine has an efficiency advantage over conventional engines of 25 to 30 per cent. It is super light, super small and offers a cost advantage over equivalent engines of between $200 and $600 per car. Sarich Enterprises has also developed a fuel injection system which is able to reduce fuel usage in marine, industrial and car engines to less than half that of conventional systems. Its claim is a 50 per cent to 70 per cent saving. These designs are proven, tested in the most advanced laboratories in the world and ready to enter the market place.

It amazes me that the Federal Government has not found its way clear to help establish a manufacturing plant for these products in Australia. Sarich Technologies Trust and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd are even now considering approaches from three overseas corporations seeking joint ventures to manufacture the Sarich engine overseas. One of the largest countries in the European Economic Community has directed its largest car manufacturer to approach Sarich with a view to incorporating his engine in its latest range of cars. I have it on good authority that Sarich Technologies Trust and BHP are almost certain to accept one of these joint venture offers in the next few weeks. So another Australian invention will be lost to overseas production unless we can find some way to keep such a venture within Australia.

Once again, the difficulty for Sarich Technologies Trust and BHP is the requirement for a large initial investment. This will take a few years to get off the ground and it will be in competition with much heavier capital investment which will be out against them. It should be feasible to assist such an enterprise to get off the ground in Australia by offering a tax holiday or some such similar scheme for the first few years of its operation until export markets and contracts have been established. This is already on the way. To continue to pour taxpayer's money in at a rate of between $8,500 and $14,000 per worker per year, or around $100m a year, into supporting subsidiaries of overseas corporations with little will to export competitively is no solution for our car industry. The $100m to $150m in grants for research in design areas should not go solely to foreign-owned or controlled organisations because of the conflict of interest that I raised earlier. Technology transfer must be controlled so that Australia gets the benefit of Australian investment in education, research and development. I am also pleased to note the Government's intention to try to control transfer pricing and duty evasion by certain of the large car manufacturers who receive such generous support already for their local assembly operations. In order to save time, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an article from the Australian Financial Review of 16 October 1985 on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long is the thing you want to incorporate?
—It is just a very small article.
—It would be courteous to show it to the Minister.
—I am sorry, Senator Button was not in the chamber when I came in.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
NATIONAL AFFAIRS
BUTTON ASKS FORD, AMI TO SHOW IMPORT PRICES FAIR
By John Durie
The Federal Government has asked Australian Motor Industries Ltd and the Ford Motor Co of Australia to justify that some of their import prices under the Car Industry Plan were fair.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has written to the companies' chief executives-the first time he has exercised his power to formally question the import pricing policies of any of the five plan producers.
If both companies cannot justify their actions satisfactorily, they are liable to penalties.
The plan says the minister may impose penalties by refusing concessional duty entry for imports and by implementing a 150 per cent penalty duty.
At present there is no question that either company has imported goods at unfair prices as Senator Button has simply sought justification.

In a letter dated October 7 to all plan producers, component producers and industry bodies like the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries, Senator Button said at the time the plan was announced there were allegations of unfair import pricing.
At the time, he said it was not possible to substantiate the claims but a monitoring process was established through a special unit of Customs and the Automotive Industry Authority.

Senator Button said as a result of the monitoring, questions had been raised concerning the price of some imports and ``I have written to the relevant manufacturers seeking justification for the prices charged for those imports''.
He did not refer to the companies concerned but both Ford and AMI yesterday confirmed that they had received a specific letter from Senator Button seeking justification of prices.

In his letter, Senator Button was understood to have drawn the attention of both producers to the sections of the plan relating to unfair import pricing and to have sought details concerning specific import shipments.
The other three manufacturers deny having received the first letter and this claim is backed by government sources in Canberra.
Ford declined to comment further while AMI said it had acknowledged Senator Button's letter and said it would be happy to provide the relevant information.
A company spokesman denied it had engaged in any transfer pricing.
AMI primarily imports from its parent, the Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan, while most Ford imports are supplied by Mazda in Japan, a company 25 per cent owned by Ford Motor Co in the US.
While the Federal Government has monitored motor vehicle import pricing policies, the present plan has included the first comprehensive pro- cess through the authority and a special unit of Customs.
The latter primarily monitors component imports and so-called completely knocked down packs while the authority monitors imports of completely built up vehicles.
They have closely monitored import policies with detailed requests for company figures and have co-operated in their efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that we also have a problem with the offsets program, but it is very difficult to obtain any information on this area. I rose tonight to seek some reply from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) who is in the chamber. I believe it is extremely important that we should preserve and nurture the inventions within the Australian community and that organisations, such as the Sarich organisation, should be supported rather than our trying to support the very large multi-national organisations to which we are currently giving aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make some comments about a booklet that arrived in my office today. The cover of the booklet features a picture of one of the Government Ministers, the Minister for Science, Mr Barry Jones. It has the title: Living by our Wits.
—It is hot off the presses, Senator.

—Senator Button says that it is hot off the press, so I have not had time to read it. I make it quite clear to the Senate that the comments I am making do not relate to the substantive content of the book at all. My comments are in a different area.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know Barry Jones. I have never met him and I have no personal complaint with him at all. I remember him from Bob and Dolly Dyer's Pick-a-Box days. I can only say: What a prize he has selected for himself here to get the Government to print an anthology of his speeches. I am disgusted at what I regard as a total misuse of government funds whereby the Government is paying for a Minister to present an anthology of his speeches to the community. I remind honourable senators that this is not the Prime Minister, this is not even the Deputy Prime Minister, and it is not even someone close to that; this is someone who is twenty-first in the Ministry, which is a fair way down. There are only four or five under that. For somebody who is not in Cabinet to make a decision that his speeches are of such importance that they should be packaged up, given a glossy cover and distributed by the Australian Government Publishing Service, I think is a disgrace. I say that for a number of reasons. Firstly, the Minister has ample opportunity and the free right to make whatever speeches he wants in the Parliament. Anyone who wants to see what he said can read the Hansard report. Secondly, there is the Ministerial Document Service. Any speech by a Minister that is considered to be of some note will be widely published through the document service and those who want to have access to the thoughts of Barry Jones can pore over the material that the service has to offer. If that is not enough, if the Minister makes speeches that are good enough they will probably be put in the Commonwealth Record. Anyone who wants to read them can read them in there. If the Minister who is twenty-first in the Ministry is not satisfied with that, there is the good old Press. This is the last resort. The real market forces come into operation in that. If he says something of substance, there is a real chance-not a 99 per cent chance but a fair chance-that the Press will report it. The public can then have the benefit of Mr Jones's wisdom through the Press.

Apparently Mr Jones is not happy with this arrangement. He is not happy to select an individual speech of his of meritorious quality and have it widely distributed. He thinks that so far nine speeches of his are of sufficiently meritorious quality that they should be selected ahead of the other speeches he has made and reproduced by the Government at the taxpayers' expense in a book with his picture on a nice glossy cover entitled Living by our Wits. He thinks that this book should be sent around to every parliamentarian and anyone else who is on the free list and then made available for sale in the government bookshops.

I want to know whether this is now Government practice. Can I look forward to anthologies from other Ministers? Can I look forward to the collective thoughts of Arthur Gietzelt or books of the collective thoughts of Peter Morris, John Brown or Stewart West?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Senator Button.
—Or Senator Button-although, with respect, I have left out a number of senators. I would be interested in reading the collective thoughts of a number of senators on the other side.
—I don't think he would print his.

—The honourable senator is quite right. A number of honourable senators would not choose to make the decision, presumably within the Department and funded by the Government, to use taxpayers' funds to publish nine or so of their collective thoughts.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in the day I thought that I might spend time going through the book with one of the new-fangled highlighters marking the word `I' just to see how many times that word was used in this egocentric booklet. However, after a quick glance I decided that it was not worth proceeding. An indication of the whole nature of this egocentric exercise is the cover of the book, which contains a picture of Barry Jones. Heavens above, this man does not know where to stop! What community interest is there for the people to know that:

The major influences on my thinking in writing Sleepers were Karl Marx, especially in his Grundrisse', the three dedicatees, Lewis Memford, author of The Myth of the Machine and The Pentagon of Power . . .

And so on. What boring drivel! I do not know of one member of the public who wants to know the titles of the books that have influenced this man's thinking. I think this is an absolute disgrace. It is a total waste of government money. The Government should make a decision that in future no other Minister will be given the monopoly of using government money to publish his own speeches. If their speeches are so good, let Griffin Press Ltd or somebody else come clamouring to them and say: `You're words are pearls of wisdom. We will publish them because the public wants them'. That has not happened. The public obviously does not give two hoots about what Barry Jones has to say, so he has to resort to using taxpayers' funds to publish his speeches. I regret that he has chosen to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put to the Senate that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) failed in his responsibility not to issue a warning to Australian travellers in the region of Libya prior to the American attack yesterday. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will recall that in the Senate on Monday the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, advised the Senate, in answer to a question from Senator Foreman, that the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Minister had not in March issued a travel warning at a time of heightened tension. Furthermore, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not considered appropriate to issue a travel warning at this time.
This was on Monday, a few hours before the attack. The Minister went on with the reassuring words:
However, the Department of Foreign Affairs is closely monitoring the situation.

Madam Acting Deputy President, you will similarly recall that yesterday, a few hours after the attack, when I asked Senator Evans, in his capacity as representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, whether he considered that the Government had failed in its responsibility to Australians travelling in the area by not offering such warnings, he replied in the following terms:
There are a number of sensitive diplomatic considerations, as well as practical ones, governing the issuing of warnings of that kind.
He was not prepared or was not able to give any further information.

Today Senator Evans certainly did not clarify the matter as to what the sensitive diplomatic considerations were, but he indicated to the Senate that now the Department and the Minister had in fact issued a travel warning-that is, several hours after the attack. To have issued that after the bombing is clearly a joke. The Minister, of course, tells us of his close relationship with the United States of America. I presume that he was therefore aware for some time of the possibility of an attack. Even if he does not have that close relationship, presumably our intelligence could tell us of the imminence of such an attack. Madam Acting Deputy President, I remind you again that on Monday the Minister said that the Department of Foreign Affairs was closely monitoring the situation. Even if we do not have such intelligence, it was clearly public knowledge that there was the possibility of such an attack. The whole of the world seemed to know, simply by reading newspapers or listening to the radio. Therefore, it was public knowledge of which the Minister was aware.

As I said, the Minister spoke about diplomatic sensitivities being involved but failed today to explain what those diplomatic sensitivities were. Prudence would suggest that the Department and the Minister should have issued a note of warning, probably at the time of the last United States attack. It certainly should have done so in the weeks in between and certainly when General Walters, who is known to everyone, headed off to Europe to put to European allies the fact that America was considering--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Shirley Walters or somebody else?

—No, this is a different General Walters. General Walters went to Europe to give European allies notice of what the United States intended. Furthermore, it was public knowledge that United States naval vessels were again heading towards the Libyan coast.

SPEECH.PARA: Arguably, an Australian could believe that, in view of the Minister not considering it necessary to issue a warning, he and the Department considered that it was safe to travel to Libya and to be in Tripoli. Obviously it was not safe. Therefore, in my opinion, the Minister was grossly negligent and put diplomatic sensitivities, whatever they may have been, ahead of questions of safety of Australian citizens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. I have some sort of ill-informed comments to make about what has been said. First of all, I will convey Senator Hill's views to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). It may just well have been that if the Minister had made any such announcement, it would have been interpreted as a breach of the United States alliance in view of the claims about--
—You have to balance these things out, don't you, Senator?
—Yes, you do-in view of our claims about prescience and prior knowledge of what was likely to take place. I can only convey the honourable senator's views to the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to examine Senator Vanstone's views. I think we should bring down a rule about the matter she raised-probably after my book has been published. I will certainly take on board the points raised by Senator Vanstone, and something might happen as a result.

Listening to Senator Vigor's speech I was reminded that somebody once said that even death is a learning experience. The honourable senator's speech was that sort of learning experience for me. His research into the motor vehicle industry should have revealed such things as the fact that there are five major manufacturers in Australia, not three. There were lots of factually inconsistent points in the comments which he made. I want to deal with what he sees as the essential issue, which is that the Government should somehow be supporting the Sarich engine and not giving money to multinationals such as Ford and General Motors, as the car plan does for their local design scheme.

A lot of government money has gone into the Sarich engine over the years, as has a lot of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd money. Whatever happens, the ultimate commercial decision which is likely to be made is that if that engine is as successful as people say it will be, its success will be recognised by the major manufacturers of the world and they will tend to want to manufacture it near where the majority of cars are made. For example, Toyota in Japan makes 4 million engines a year. The whole of the Australian car industry makes 400,000 cars a year. Similar figures are available in respect of the larger United States companies.

It would tend to be both an economic and a commercial decision, if the Sarich engine were seen as a solution to all their problems, to manufacture it near the major car industries. I guess that is something that will be sorted out. I do not think the Sarich engine, manufactured in Kalgoorlie, Bunbury or somewhere else and exported round the world to the car industry, would really have the same benefits to the world car industry or the same scope as it would if the other course were adopted. I do not think it is true to say that we have a motor vehicle industry that is totally unwilling to export. I think the honourable senator will see some significant exports by the motor vehicle industry in the next two or three years, and that is important. The juxtaposition of the two sides of the honourable senator's argument, if I may say so, needs further examination.

Senator Cooney explained his presence yesterday at the meeting of the Builders Labourers Federation outside the new Parliament House site. I guess if one goes into the cave with the troglodytes, one tends to get into trouble, and I note his explanation.

Senator Kilgariff warned us against the dangers of Aboriginals drinking kava. The only thing that worries me about his conclusion is that he ought to have a look at the Australian tourists in Fiji who are drinking it by the bucketfull and having a terrific time. I do not think the honourable senator can single out the Aboriginals and say: `We must protect the Aboriginals from the habit of drinking kava'. We have first to decide whether it constitutes a drug of addiction and a drug which is damaging. If we so decide, we might make the same rules in relation to people generally and not just the poor old Aboriginals who have to be stopped doing any of those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not suggesting it should be stopped. I am saying it should be looked at. But I reckon there is a racket going on and they are paying thousands and thousands of dollars for something that is dirt cheap.

—The racket is going on in Fiji. Australian tourists pay thousands and thousands of dollars over there to drink kava. It is the highlight of their experience. I note what has been said. I am not sure that it is the solution to the Aboriginal problem, however. I thank honourable senators for their comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.35 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 4 December 1985:

May, is able to exercise unbiased and independent judgment on the 2 Airline system, given the considerable financial links between Alltrans, TNT and Ansett.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:
