QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many statutory authorities currently exist under the auspices of the Minister's Department.
(2) What are the names of these authorities.
(3) What appeal mechanisms, if any, exist for the general public to lodge a complaint against these authorities.

(4) If it is proved that any member of staff of any of these authorities is guilty of incompetence, what action, if any, could be taken by a member of the public to sue the authority for compensation; if it is not possible to sue the authority, why is that the case.

(5) How many cases concerning these authorities are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and what is the delay at present between the listing of a case and its hearing before the Tribunal.
(6) If any statutory authority under the Minister's Department cannot be sued, will the Minister consider amending the relevant legislation to make this possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One.
(2) The Australian Trade Commission.
(3) The public has, depending on the nature of complaint, recourse to the courts, the A.A.T., the A.D.J.R., and ombudsman.

(4) The Attorney-General's Department has advised that, unless an authority is statutorily protected, it is liable for the torts of its servants committed in the course of their duty. Where employees, acting in the course of their duty are incompetent and, as a consequence, loss is suffered by a member of the public, it will commonly be found that the act or omission which was seen as incompetent was also tortious. In the absence of a denial of liability the negligent giving of erroneous advice is tortious where the advice is given by a person having a duty of care to one who suffers foreseeable damage as a result of reasonably relying on that advice. Many other forms of incompetence would also be tortious, but each case would need to be considered on its own facts. The Australian Trade Commission is not statutorily protected against general liability in tort.

(5) There are currently 31 cases before the A.A.T. all relating to grants determinations made under the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974. The EMDG Act is administered by the Commission. Listing of a case may take four to six weeks and a hearing generally follows eight to ten weeks thereafter.
(6) Section 7(2)(d) of the Australian Trade Commission Act 1985 provides that the Commission may sue and be sued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 1986;

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many members of the Australian Defence Force hold the rank of colonel, or its equivalent.
(2) What is the number of such officers in each of the 3 Defence Services.
(3) How many members of the Australian Defence Force hold ranks higher than the rank of colonel, or its equivalent.
(4) What is the number of such officers in each of the 3 Defence Services.
(5) How many civilian members of the Department of Defence ancillary bodies have Public Service classifications equivalent to or higher than the rank of colonel.

(6) How do numbers of officers holding ranks of colonel or its equivalent or higher, expressed as a proportion of the total Australian Defence Force, compare with the proportions of officers of the level of colonel or higher, in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At 30 June 1985, 335 members of the Australian Defence Force held the rank of colonel or its equivalent.
(2) The number of such officers in each of the 3 Defence Services were:
Navy 92; Army 128; Air Force 115.
(3) 148 members of the Australian Defence Force held ranks higher than the rank of colonel, or its equivalent.
(4) The number of such officers in each of the 3 Defence Services were:
Navy 42; Army 62; Air Force 44.

(5) There is no formal equivalence between Public Service and military classifications. As a working arrangement for integrated areas of the Department the following guidelines are used to specify organizational relationship: `that the highest rank of service subordinate for Clerical Administrative Class 11 should be LTCOL(E) and the highest civilian subordinate for a COL(E) should be Clerical Administrative Class 10.'
Within the Department of Defence and ancillary bodies, there are 414 civilian members with a classification of Clerical Administrative Class 10 (or professional equivalent) and above.

(6) 0.68% of the total Australian Defence Force held the rank of colonel or its equivalent or higher. Com- parable ranks within the United States Defence Forces accounted for 0.74%. Rank details relating to other countries' Defence Forces are not available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 13 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has the Minister for Science taken to ensure that piles of neglected garbage, debris and derelict buildings are removed from Australia's research stations in the Antarctic.
(2) Why haven't adequate steps been taken to minimise the disturbance and contamination of unique plant life at Casey.

(3) How will the Minister answer the stinging attack on the conduct and operation of Australia's Antarctic Bases and the outright neglect and lack of scientific achievement of the people employed at the Bases, delivered by Dr Ron Lewis-Smith, a leading British scientist.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (3) Many of the environmental problems reported by Dr Lewis-Smith refer only to Casey and the abandoned Wilkes Stations. Environmental management at Mawson and Davis is good.

The Antarctic Division has a policy of returning non-combustible waste to Australia, a policy which has only become possible with the long-term charter of the Icebird in 1985. This practice will continue with every effort being made to not only return waste generated each year, but also to gradually decrease waste accumulated over preceding years. Combustible waste will be disposed of in high temperature incinerators which are virtually pollution free and have been in use since March at Casey and are expected to be in use by December at Davis and Mawson stations.

The Antarctic Division has been aware for some time of the need to clean-up Wilkes Station which was abandoned in 1969. This was considered in late 1984 by the Division's Environment Committee which recommended a clean-up; limited restoration of the transmitter building and radome for use as a refuge and display centre; installation of a commemorative plaque; installation of a small display if possible; and allowing the remaining buildings to decay under the effect of the elements. However, most of the buildings at Wilkes are owned by the United States. Permission to go ahead with the policy was therefore sought from the US, and received in May 1985.

The Department of Housing and Construction undertook an inspection of Wilkes for the Division during the 1985-86 season and a report on their findings and a work program is being prepared. Appropriate action will then be programmed for next season. However, a clean-up of the area could be hampered by the presence of undetonated and potentially dangerous explosives.

A recent meeting of the Antarctic Division Environment Committee recognised that problems exist at Casey and convened a special meeting of the Committee to consider appropriate remedial action and preventative measures to be adopted in future.

(2) The disturbance to plant life in the vicinity of Casey occurred some years prior to the significance of the area being recognised. Subsequently, the Antarctic Division developed a proposal for two areas around Casey to be designated as Sites of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI) under the Antarctic Treaty. A recommendation to this effect was accepted at the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting in October 1985 and the two Sites will be proclaimed under the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Commonwealth Department of Education post application forms for Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) allowances to all candidates for the Higher School Certificate as well as the continuing students who have received TEAS in the past and all people who have applied for admission to universities or colleges through the Universities and Colleges Admissions Centre.
(2) What proportion of the posted application forms are converted into successful applications under TEAS.
(3) What is the cost, including administrative cost, of posting these forms each year to such a large number of people.
(4) Are such application forms readily available on request at all universities and colleges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As the combination of Higher School Certificate and Universities and Colleges Admissions Centre applies only in New South Wales, it is assumed that the question relates to arrangements for sending TEAS application forms to potential applicants in New South Wales.
The New South Wales Office of the Department of education sends a TEAS application form and information booklet to the following categories of people:
(a) All TEAS recipients, not in their final year and therefore likely to be continuing full-time study in the following year.
(b) All Higher School Certificate candidates.

(c) All applicants who have applied for admission to a university or college through the Universities and Colleges Admissions Centre (UCAC) other than on the basis of the previous year's Higher School Certificate results.
(2) The proportion of posted application forms used by recipients to apply for assistance in 1985 was as follows:
Continuing students: 68.5%
HSC candidates: 17.3%
UCAC applicants not HSC candidates: 15.7%
Proportion returned-all categories: 29.4%
(3) The cost of posting the material relating to 1985 applications was:
Postage-$21,455
Labour-$7,028
(4) Application forms and booklets are available at educational institutions.

In other States, there are some variations depending on arrangements negotiated with education authorities. Application forms are usually posted direct to people sitting the examination at the end of secondary school or those who have made application with tertiary admission centres. In all States, the material is posted to beneficiaries in the previous year who might be continuing full time study, and is available at tertiary institutions.

There are a number of advantages in sending application forms direct to the categories of people referred to above. As well as facilitating an early lodgment of the application, the practice ensures that information about the Scheme is received by potential applicants particularly those who are embarking on tertiary study for the first time.

There would not necessarily be economies if the only method of distribution was to make the application forms available at educational institutions. The possible savings in printing and postage would be easily offset by additional labour costs of handling additional inquiries and dispatching forms on a one by one basis. This case would particularly arise with students whose homes are not within easy access to the tertiary institution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 February 1986 (Hansard, page 266), Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, a question without notice regarding the ready-mixed concrete industry in the Australian Capital Territory concerning restrictions on the number of concrete agitator trucks operating in the Australian Capital Territory, the level of income of owner-drivers operating these trucks, and whether the Government intended to intervene in the matter. Senator Lewis also asked whether the Builders Labourers Federation and the Transport Workers Union had imposed bans in the Australian Capital Territory on trucks on building sites being unloaded other than by their respective members. In my reply I undertook to refer the matter to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to see whether he wished to add anything to what I had to say. The Minister has provided the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: In respect of the ready-mixed concrete industry in the ACT, I am aware of disagreement between the Transport Workers' Union (TWU) and the National Ready-Mixed Concrete Association (NRMCA) of the ACT over the number of concrete agitator trucks currently operating in the ACT and over a number of other matters. In that context I understand that the TWU has been approached by the Confederation of ACT Industry, on behalf of the NRMCA of the ACT, seeking discussions on this issue. The TWU is yet to respond to that approach. The matter has also been before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on a number of occasions, most recently on 29 January 1986. In view of the complexity of the issues involved and the significance of the building and construction industry to the ACT economy, the Government urges the parties to enter into meaningful negotiations with a view to overcoming any areas of disagreement. The Government is hopeful that those issues can be resolved by negotiations between the parties, with recourse to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for further assistance if required.

As to the earnings of these owner-drivers, I would point out that the rates are determined by a tripartite board, comprising an independent chairman and representatives of the owner-drivers and the NRMCA of the ACT. More specifically, those rates applying in the ACT are determined in accordance with a reimbursement formula which was calculated and agreed to a number of years ago by the tripartite board. The tripartite board continues to meet in April and October of each year to determine rates in accordance with variations to costs comprehended by the agreed reimbursement formula. It is my understanding that the reimbursement formula is not a matter of dispute.

In respect of the unloading of trucks on building sites in the ACT, I am advised that no industrial action is presently occurring in support of BLF and TWU claims for exclusive coverage and that trucks are presently being unloaded by a number of different unions in accordance with accepted practice.
